Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: PSYCHIATRY
 
Allergies: 
Penicillins / Doxepin / Haldol
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
"I'm not safe on my own."

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
This is a ___ y/o female with a long-history of mood d/o NOS
complicated by PSA who came to ___ ED by public transportation
with active suicidal ideation including plan to run into 
oncoming
traffic. The patient was just recently released from jail after
she was arrested secondary to multiple outstanding warrants for
her arrest as a result of prior assaults, public intoxication,
and prostitution. She is due to follow up in court on ___.
While in jail, she reportedly attempted to hang herself using 
her
bra. Since her release, she has been abusing methadone, 
klonopin,
and cocaine while engaging in prostitution. 

When asked why the patient wants to end her life, she says that
she is upset that she can't see her son ever since her mother
took custody. She also has not been able to see her Therapist
___ ___ in what she considers a timely 
fashion.
Lastly, she cites her prostitution as a factor in her poor mood. 


She endorses poor sleep, low energy, irritability, excessive
feelings of guilt, and psychomotor retardation. She indicates
that her concentration is unaffected, citing her ability to read
the Bible. 

She denies any pertinent positives related to mania or 
psychosis.
 
Past Medical History:
Past Psychiatric History:
The patient's
first hospitalization occurred at age ___ at a time when she was
being molested by her brother. Since then, she has been admitted
to ___, and ___ as well as the
___. She reports approximately 10 prior suicide attempts. 

She has in the past been diagnosed as having PTSD, anxiety, BPD,
MDD v. Bipolar d/o. 

She was most recently being prescribed Prozac, Ativan, 
Trazodone,
and Seroquel (unknown doses). The patient self-discontinued 
these
medications approximately 3 months ago because she felt they 
were
causing her to gain weight.

* Eczema

Brief Hospital Course:
# Psychiatric: 
The patient demonstrated generally good behavioral control on 
the unit, despite occasions of low frustration tolerance; the 
patient could become angry with staff for perceived slights or 
perceived neglect but managed to self-seclude and self-soothe 
effectively. She denied suicidal ideation on the unit and 
verbalized her wish to be admitted to substance-abuse treatment, 
preferably in an inpatient setting. She also acknowledged that, 
in light of her current legal problems, the court would look 
favorably on her placement in treatment. Although on initial 
interview the patient endorsed hopelessness and presented as 
labile, irritable, and somewhat evasive, she subsequently became 
quite reliably euthymic and often bright in affect, with little 
affective lability apparent during interactions with the 
treatment team and a cooperative demeanor. As is her wont, 
however, she remained focused on externalization, preoccupied 
typically with her medication regimen, including the short 
lorazepam taper instituted to facilitate her transition away 
from benzodiazepine abuse and off of cocaine. She tolerated this 
taper without adverse effects and completed it on ___. For 
management of insomnia and nocturnal anxiety in the context of 
PTSD, the patient tolerated a trial of amitriptyline, titrated 
up to a maintenance dose of 100 mg PO QHS, although this dose 
might require further titration in the future to optimize 
efficacy. On the unit, at least, this dose of amitriptyline has, 
by her report, helped with sleep. She was written for clonidine 
PRN at HS for persistent sleeplessness; she found clonidine 
helpful for anxiolysis, so it was advanced to 0.1 mg PO BID PRN 
with good effect. Diphenhydramine PRN nasal congestion likely 
provided additional anxiolysis and hypnotic benefit without 
excessive sedation. 

# Medical:
- Asthma: The patient reported occasional shortness of breath; 
at her request, she was written for albuterol MDI PRN shortness 
of breath, which she used intermittently. She was not observed 
to be overtly dyspneic in house, and her oxygen saturation was 
within normal limits on routine vital-signs monitoring.
- Seasonal allergies: The patient complained of "hay fever," 
with rhinorrhea and nasal congestion, and requested loratadine, 
which she reports using at home. This was not on hospital 
formulary; fexofenadine was offered but, per patient report, was 
ineffective. She was switched to diphenhydramine PRN, with good 
effect.
- Eczema: The patient was provided with hydrocortisone and 
triamcinolone creams PRN itching; she had no complaints of 
breakthrough dermatologic symptoms.
- Nutritional Status: In light of the patient's history of 
polysubstance abuse, she was maintained on a multivitamin, 
thiamine, and folate.
 
# Legal/Safety:
- Legal Status: The patient was admitted on Conditional 
Voluntary status (Secs. 10, 11) and remained on that status for 
the duration of her hospital stay
- Safety Monitoring: The patient was maintained on routine 
q15minute safety checks, as she denied SI, felt safe on the 
unit, and demonstrated good behavioral control.
- Outstanding Legal Issues: The patient reported having a court 
hearing scheduled for ___ related to outstanding warrants 
for assault and battery, prostitution, and drug possession. Her 
attorney, ___, reports that the patient does not have 
outstanding warrants per se and that her attendance at the 
___ hearing was not required. He indicates that he is 
continuing work to "settle" the patient's legal issues. Both he 
and the patient indicated that the court wishes the patient to 
be actively engaged in substance-abuse treatment. The treatment 
team provided the patient and Mr. ___ with a letter confirming 
the patient's presence on this psychiatric inpatient unit and 
her acceptance of treatment while here.

# Disposition:
- Substance-abuse treatment: The patient was accepted for 
admission to ___ for inpatient substance-abuse 
treatment. She was amenable to this treatment plan, however 
declined at the last moment, stating "I want to smoke a 
cigarette."
- Mental Health: The patient has been instructed to follow up 
with her therapist of long standing, ___, Director of 
Mental Health at ___. Mr. ___ visited 
with the patient on the unit and has been in communication with 
the treatment team during her stay. Mr. ___ will receive a 
faxed copy of the patient's discharge summary.
- Primary Care: The patient has been instructed to follow up 
with her primary care physician, ___, M.D., also of 
___. Dr. ___ will receive a faxed 
copy of the patient's discharge summary.
- Family/Domestic: The patient's plan is to live with her father 
after completing inpatient treatment, then continue with 
outpatient recovery services. Her father reportedly is willing 
to allow her to live in his home only if she is in treatment.
 
Medications on Admission:
None. The patient was most recently being prescribed Prozac, 
Ativan, Trazodone,
and Seroquel (unknown doses). The patient self-discontinued 
these
medications approximately 3 months ago because she felt they 
were
causing her to gain weight. 
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Multivitamin     Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 
 
2. Thiamine HCl 100 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
3. Folic Acid 1 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  

4. Cortisone 1 % Cream Sig: One (1) Appl Topical QID (4 times a 
day) as needed for eczema.  
5. Triamcinolone Acetonide 0.025 % Cream Sig: One (1) Appl 
Topical BID (2 times a day) as needed for itching.  
6. Albuterol Sulfate 90 mcg/Actuation HFA Aerosol Inhaler Sig: 
One (1) Puff Inhalation Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for 
shortness of breath.  
7. Clonidine 0.1 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a 
day) as needed for anxiety, insomnia.  
8. Diphenhydramine HCl 25 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO Q8H 
(every 8 hours) as needed for nasal congestion.  
9. Amitriptyline 100 mg PO QHS (at bedtime).  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Axis I: 
Polysubstance dependence
Mood Disorder not otherwise specified
Rule out Substance-Induced Mood Disorder
history of Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder
Axis II: mixed cluster B traits (Borderline and Antisocial 
features)
Axis III: Asthma, eczema, seasonal allergies
Axis IV: Unemployment, financial problems, scant social support
Axis V: 35
 
Discharge Condition:
Ambulatory without assistive device or activity restrictions.
Alert and oriented.
No acute medical issues at discharge.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please take all discharge medications as directed. If you have 
questions about medication, please contact your doctor.

Please attend all scheduled follow-up appointments. If you need 
to reschedule an appointment, please call your doctor in 
advance.

Please avoid alcohol, cocaine, and other substances of abuse. In 
addition, please avoid misuse of prescription drugs. In the 
hospital, we tapered you off of benzodiazepines using lorazepam 
(Ativan). You have expressed to us your understanding that you 
will be discharged from this facility without a prescription for 
benzodiazepines.

Please consult with your lawyer, ___ (___), 
to discuss ongoing legal issues.
 
Followup Instructions:

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ yo female with non-healing wound at right ___ 
toe amputation site who was admitted to the ___ 
___ on ___ for prehydration. The patient 
was taken to the endovascular suite on ___ and underwent RLE 
angiogram. For details of the procedure, please see the 
surgeon's operative note. The patient tolerated the procedure 
well without complications and was brought to the 
post-anesthesia care unit in stable condition. After a brief 
stay, the patient was transferred to the vascular surgery floor 
where she remained through the rest of the hospitalization.

Post-operatively, she did well without any groin swelling. 
Nephrology was consulted regarding her peritoneal dialysis and 
she received treatments while in house. Phosphate levels were 
found to be elevated. Per nephrology recommendations, calcitriol 
was stopped and patient was started on PhosLo 1334mg TID with 
meals. She was able to tolerate a regular diet, get out of bed 
and ambulate without assistance, void without issues, and pain 
was controlled on oral medications alone. She was deemed ready 
for discharge, and was given the appropriate discharge and 
follow-up instructions.

heavy lifting for 1 week

PVD
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Uses prosthesis on RLE
 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___ 
___.  You were admitted to the hospital after a 
peripheral angiogram.   To do the test, a small puncture was 
made in one of your arteries.  The puncture site heals on its 
own: there are no stitches to remove.   The procedure did find 
that you have poor blood flow to your right leg, and Dr. 
___ is recommending a procedure to improve the circulation 
to this leg. You will be contacted about scheduling this 
procedure. 

You tolerated the procedure well and are now ready to be 
discharged from the hospital.   Please follow the 
recommendations below to ensure a speedy and uneventful 
recovery. Please resume your dialysis treatments as you have 
been doing prior to this admission.

Sincerely, 
Your ___ Care Team

Peripheral Angiography
Puncture Site Care
For one week:
Do not take a tub bath, go swimming or use a Jacuzzi or hot 
tub.
Use only mild soap and water to gently clean the area around 
the puncture site. 
Gently pat the puncture site dry after showering. 
Do not use powders, lotions, or ointments in the area of the 
puncture site. 

You may remove the bandage and shower the day after the 
procedure.  You may leave the bandage off. 
You may have a small bruise around the puncture site.  This is 
normal and will go away one-two weeks. 

Activity 
For the first 48 hours: 
Do not drive for 48 hours after the procedure
For the first week:
Do not lift, push , pull or carry anything heavier than 10 
pounds
Do not do any exercises or activity that causes you to hold 
your breath or bear down with abdominal muscles.   Take care not 
to put strain on your abdominal muscles when coughing, sneezing, 
or moving your bowels.
After one week:
You may go back to all your regular activities, including 
sexual activity.  We suggest you begin your exercise program at 
half of your usual routine for the first few days.   You may 
then gradually work back to your full routine.

Medications:
Before you leave the hospital, you will be given a list of all 
the medicine you should take at home.  If a medication that you 
normally take is not on the list or a medication that you do not 
take is on the list please discuss it with the team!  

For  Problems or Questions:
Call ___ in an emergency such as:
Sudden, brisk bleeding or swelling at the groin puncture site 
that does not stop after applying pressure for ___ minutes
Bleeding that is associated with nausea, weakness, or 
fainting.
Call the vascular surgery office (___) right away if 
you have any of the following. (Please note that someone is 
available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week)
Swelling, bleeding, drainage, or discomfort at the puncture 
site that is new or increasing since discharge from the hospital
Any change in sensation or temperature in your legs
Fever of 101 or greater
Any questions or concerns about recovery from your angiogram 

Sincerely,
Your ___ Care Team
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Abdominal Pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___: Laparoscopic Appendectomy 

 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old woman with a history of obesity 
(BMI 37.7), HTN, anxiety, presenting with RLQ abdominal pain, 
WBC 13.6, CT scan concerning for acute appendicitis. Patient had 
abdominal pain starting this AM, initially periumbilical then 
localized to the RLQ. She denies fevers/chills, nausea/vomiting. 
She has had a poor appetite. She presented to the ED today for 
evaluation of these symptoms with workup showing a WBC 13.6, and 
CT abd/pelvis showing a dilated appendix with mild 
periappendiceal stranding consistent with appendicitis, without 
abscess or evidence of perforation, no appendicolith.

Brief Hospital Course:
Patient is a ___ year old female with pmh significant for acne 
and anxiety. Patient presented to the emergency department with 
complaints of abdominal pain. Imaging was completed which 
demonstrated acute appendicitis. She initially requested 
non-operative management, therefore she was treated with 
antibiotics and bowel rest, however, later in the day on ___ 
she requested surgical intervention. 

She was then consented and taken to the operating room and 
underwent laparoscopic appendectomy on ___. (Please see 
operative report for details of this procedure). She tolerated 
the procedure well, was extubated upon completion, and was 
subsequently taken to the PACU for recovery.

Once pain was well controlled, and the patient experienced a 
return of bowel function, their diet was advanced as tolerated. 
During this hospitalization, the patient voided without 
difficulty and ambulated early and frequently. The patient was 
adherent with respiratory toilet and incentive spirometry and 
actively participated in the plan of care. The patient received 
subcutaneous heparin and venodyne boots were used during this 
stay.

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well. She was 
afebrile and her vital signs were stable.  The patient was 
tolerating a regular diet, ambulating, voiding without 
assistance, and her pain was well controlled.  The patient was 
discharged home without services and follow up care was 
arranged. Discharge teaching was completed and follow-up 
instructions were reviewed with reported understanding and 
agreement.

 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. erythromycin with ethanol 2 % topical Other 
2. Tretinoin 0.05% Cream 1 Appl TP QHS 
3. Spironolactone 100 mg PO BID 
4. Cetirizine 10 mg PO DAILY 
5. Escitalopram Oxalate 25 mg PO DAILY 
6. TraZODone 50 mg PO QHS:PRN insomnia 

 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q8H 
please limit to 4000mg in 24 hour period.  
2.  Ibuprofen 400 mg PO Q8H:PRN Pain - Mild 
  Reason for PRN duplicate override: Alternating agents for 
similar severity
Please limit to 3000mg in 24 hour period.  
3.  OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) 5 mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain - 
Moderate 
  Reason for PRN duplicate override: Alternating agents for 
similar severity
Medication may cause drowsiness 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every four (4) hours 
Disp #*5 Tablet Refills:*0 
4.  Cetirizine 10 mg PO DAILY  
5.  erythromycin with ethanol 2 % topical Other  
6.  Escitalopram Oxalate 25 mg PO DAILY  
7.  Spironolactone 100 mg PO BID  
8.  TraZODone 50 mg PO QHS:PRN insomnia  
9.  Tretinoin 0.05% Cream 1 Appl TP QHS  
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Acute Appendicitis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to ___ for 
evaluation of abdominal pain and were found to have acute 
appendicitis. You were treated with antibiotics and then taken 
to the operating room and underwent removal of your appendix 
laparoscopically. You are recovering well and are now ready for 
discharge. Please follow the instructions below to continue your 
recovery:

General Surgery:

Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.

Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting 
weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your 
surgeon.
Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.

Incision Care:
*Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner if you have 
increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the incision 
site.
*Avoid swimming and baths until your follow-up appointment.
*You may shower, and wash surgical incisions with a mild soap 
and warm water. Gently pat the area dry.
*If you have staples, they will be removed at your follow-up 
appointment.
*If you have steri-strips, they will fall off on their own. 
Please remove any remaining strips ___ days after surgery.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___.                Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Phenergan ___
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Worsening cellulitis
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None.

 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ woman with history of 
insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus, ___'s thyroiditis, 
vitamin D deficiency, and recurrent lower extremity cellulitis 
who presented to the emergency room overnight with chief 
complaint of worsening left leg cellulitis. The patient has had 
pain over the last few days, throbbing ache at rest and sharp 
___ with ambulation. She had been seen in the emergency room 
two days prior to admission. She did not have any erythema but 
given her history was discharged with a prescription for Vicodin 
for pain control and Keflex and completed four doses. However, 
beginning last night, she noticed the development of gradually 
enlarging red areas - initially over medial thigh, now also on 
calf. Additionally, she had a temperature to 100.7 on day prior 
admission.  
.  
Her initial vital signs in the emergency ward were T 98.9, HR 
100, BP 160/55, RR 16, satting 100% on RA. Review of systems was 
positive for fevers and chills. Labs were notable for white 
count of 22 with 90% polys and no bands. Hematocrit was 32.6 
(down from baseline high ___ with MCV of 77. Chemistry showed 
creatinine of 1.1 (slightly above baseline of ~0.9). Lactate was 
1.5. Notably, the serum blood glucose was 331. Blood cultures 
were drawn, the patient was given 1 gram of IV vancomycin, 4 mg 
of IV morphine, and admitted for treatment of cellulitis. Her 
vitals at time of admission were 98.8, 97, 134/61, 18, 97% RA.  
.  
Currently, patient endorses spreading redness in the right leg. 
Pain improved with morphine, ___ ___nd ___ with movement. 
No recent falls or trauma, no obvious portal of entry. She 
reports a history of at least 13 episodes of cellulitis - first 
time at age ___ s/p spider bite but subsequently with no clear 
triggers. Her last hospitalization was here in ___ for RLE 
cellulitis, for which she was treated with vanc/zosyn and also 
had an echo to r/o endocarditis given murmur. Pt reports an 
immunodeficiency work-up in the past by ID has been negative.  
.  
ROS: Chronic leg edema (R>L) stable. Also with mild nausea ___ 
vicodin, no vomiting. Chronic diarrhea from gastroparesis ___ 
loose stools daily). Patient does endorse decreased appetite due 
to general unwell feeling. Also mild tension headache earlier. 
No cold symptoms. No urinary symptoms.  
 
Past Medical History:
Diabetes Mellitus Type I (diagnosed in childhood)
Hypertension
PCOS
Recurrent RLE cellulitis
L foot tinea pedis
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Mother with hypothyroidism, celiac disease, age ___. Father with 
OA, anemia, age ___. Sister with superficial venous thrombosis. 
Paternal grandmother with protein S deficiency (pt checked and 
negative). Maternal great-aunt with skin cancer. Another 
maternal grand-aunt bladder cancer in ___. Maternal grandfather 
with lung ca, smoker. No immunodeficiencies. 
 
Physical Exam:
General: Well appearing female in NAD.  
Vitals: T 98.8, P 97, BP 134/96, RR 18, O2sat 97RA.  
HEENT: NCAT, sclera anicteric, mmm, oropharynx clear.  
Neck: Supple, no LAD.  
Heart: RRR, normal S1-S2, ___ systolic mm loudest at upper 
sternal border, no rubs or gallops.  
Lungs: CTA b/l.  
Abdomen: BS+, soft, obese, NT, ND.  
Extremities: WWP, 2+ pulses, nonpitting edema b/l, 15x25cm patch 
of erythema on medial left thigh and 8x7cm patch of erythema on 
left medial calf extending beyond old outlines, +TTP. Central 
area on left thigh more erythematous and tender but no 
appreciable fluctuance. Dry eczematous patch on foot but not 
contiguous to cellulitic area. No stigmata of endocarditis.  
Neurological: AAOx3. Nonfocal. 
 
Pertinent Results:

MRI thigh:
Subcutaneous edema, mainly in the upper/inner left thigh, 
extends to
myofascial margin, with mildly increased signal in adductor and 
sartorius
muscles. No abscess or fluid collection. Normal marrow signal. 
Findings
most consistent with cellulitis with mild myositis.
.
Preliminary Report !! WET READ !!
Edema in L calf subcutaneous tissues, but no fluid collection or 
other sign of
abscess. Mild edema in left medial gastrocnemius muscle. Normal 
bone marrow
signal. Findings most consistent with cellulitis/myositis.
.
Ultrasound:
LEFT LOWER EXTREMITY
 
FINDINGS: Areas of marked redness with marker were evaluated 
with ultrasound.
There is no evidence of fluid collection in the left medial 
proximal, mid anddistal thigh and left medial, proximal and mid 
calf.
IMPRESSION: No fluid collection at marked areas of skin redness 
(left medial proximal, mid and distal thigh) and left 
proximal-mid medial calf.
The study and the report were reviewed by the staff radiologist.
.
Lenis:
IMPRESSION: No evidence of deep venous thrombosis in the left 
lower
extremity. Left peroneal veins not visualized
 
Brief Hospital Course:
# Left thigh cellulitis: Pt has history of >10 episodes of 
cellulitis. There was no clear precipitant that injured the 
epidermis. ? if shaving introduced skin pathogen Patient 
initially presented to ED and discharged with course of Keflex. 
Infection progressed and patient represented and started on IV 
vanc and zosyn on night of admission, cellulitis was marked. 
Exam improved and PIV access lost. Patient then transitioned to 
PO regimen linezolid/cipro. Spiked on ___ however WBC 
downtrending. US obtained which was negative for DVT and fluid 
collection. ID consulted who favored continuing PO antibiotics 
and foregoing PICC placement.MRI of leg ordered to definitely 
rule out infection which was negative for fluid 
collection/abscess with reading consistent with 
cellulitis/myositis. CK added on. Pending at time of discharge. 
Patient discharged with plan to complete an additional 14days of 
linezolid and cipro. Discharged with 5days of dilaudid for pain 
controlled.   
.
# HA - Pt with mild frontal HA on admission. Normal fundoscopic 
exam, no N/v/photphobia. Most likely secondarily to poor sleep 
and infection. She was stable throught admission.
.  
# Diabetes mellitus, insulin dependent:  Most recent A1c 8. 
Serum glucose elevated on admission up to mid ___. ___ was 
consulted per protocol (insulin pump) and her basal rate was 
increased for 24 hours. Then her sugars were well controlled and 
she was discharged in her home regimen.
.
#. Thyroid: TSH <0.1, so levothyroxine was decreased from 50 to 
25 mg daily. She was instructed in taking it in empty stomach 
without any calcium.
.  
# Hypertension. Normotensive in house on home regimen of 
lisinopril 5mg daily, labetalol 200mg bid.  
.  
.  
# Gastroparesis. Cont nortriptyline 5 mg qhs and omeprazole 20 
mg once daily  
.  

# Communication: With patient. Husband ___ is HCP 
(___)  
.
# Code status: Full (confirmed)

Primary Diagnosis:
Left leg cellultiis
.
Secondary Diagnosis
Diabetes Mellitus 1; uncontrolled.

Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms ___, you were admitted to ___ due to recurrent lower 
extremity skin infection known as cellutis.
.
You were initially seen in the ED and discharged home with PO 
Keflex. However symptoms did not improve and you were admitted 
for IV antibiotics, vancomycin and ciprofloxacin. Improvement 
was noted on your exam and you were switched to linezolid and 
ciprofloxacin PO.
Imaging was negative for deeper infection. 
.
Regarding your diabetes, your sugars were found to be high on 
admission. ___ was consulted who recommended increasing your 
basal insulin while you were infected. Your sugars were well 
controlled in house and at time of discharge.
.
.
Regarding your hypothyroidism, your thyroid hormone was checked 
while hospitalized and found to be elevated so your dose was 
decreased by half.
.
Your medication changes were as follows:
* we cut your levothyroxine in half (25 mg daily) given that 
your thyroid was high (TSH low)
* We started you on two antibiotics (linezolid and 
ciprofloxacin) that you will need for an additional 14 days 
course
* We started you on iron supplementation. Take one tablet twice 
daily.
.
If yours symptoms worsen you will need to return to the 
emergency room.

Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___

Chief Complaint:
headache and diarrhea

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none

 
History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ is a ___ y/o male with hx of pituitary
microadenoma, hyperprolactinemia, hypogonadotropic
hypogonadism, anxiety, depression, chronic low back pain and a
recent hospitalization at ___ for HA, fever, and diarrhea who
had returned to his usual state of health prior to abrupt
recurrence of these symptoms two days ago.  He had a recent 
admission to ___ from ___ with similar
symptoms.  During his previous hospitalization in ___, head CT
and MRI were reassuring. LP was performed after abx
administration because of elevated INR; results were
inconclusive. He received abx and acyclovir. HSV came back
negative. Lyme and C diff were negative.  He reported that he 
had
returned to his usual state of health, which is notable for
chronic back pain, prior to recurrence of these symptoms.

In the ED, his BP was in the mid-90s. On the ED team's initial
evaluation: the patient was A&Ox3 and able to answer all
questions appropriately, his neuro exam was reassuring, no neck
stiffness. He does endorse abdominal pain on the right side with
palpation. He received IVF, cipro, flagyl. Stool guaiac was
positive. Labs showed normal WBC 6.7, slight anemia with Hgb
12.1. 

On my evaluation in the ED, he reports that he had sudden onset
of the "exact same symptoms" for which he was recently
hospitalized.  Says that over the course of 60 minutes ___
night (___) from ___ ___ he developed:

# Headache: generalized, was severe, throbbing, without vision
changes or radiation down the neck or back; not worse with
positional changes. He took Tylenol ___ mg), ibuprofen (400 
mg),
and aspirin (365 mg) which did alleviate the pain significantly.
Was ___ before meds; after meds was nearly gone (___).
Currently, HA is a bit worse, ___.  Denies associated vision
changes, double vision, vomiting, gait instability, falls, or
recent head trauma.

# Fevers & chills: Tm ___ yesterday when measured at home prior
to taking meds for HA and then normalized.  Didn't take Tylenol
or NSAIDs this AM because he didn't want to mask the symptoms
when he decided to come to the ED. Endorses associated mild dry
cough. Denies associated sore throat, new joint pains, rashes. 
Says that his chronic back pain was worsened and he was unable 
to
lay on his right side during this time. 

# Exhaustion: just felt tired, more sleepy, gets cold more
easily, and b/l hands hurt a little, and had trouble focusing. 
This is much better today than it was yesterday.  Denies any
associated chest pain, SOB, palpitations, or flushing sensation.

The following day (yesterday) he developed:
# Diarrhea: nearly "nonstop," orange colored thin watery stool 
in
varying quantities throughout the day and night.  This is what
led him to come to the ED.  Hasn't had any BMs since arrival to
ED, which he says feels like a minor miracle.  He endorses
associated RLQ pain.

ROS: Denies any other active or recent issues.  10 systems
reviewed and negative except as noted in HPI above.

IMPRESSION:  
  
1. Mild inflammatory changes involving the cecum and ascending

Brief Hospital Course:
A&P: Mr. ___ is a ___ y/o male with hx of pituitary
microadenoma, hyperprolactinemia, hypogonadotropic
hypogonadism, anxiety, depression, chronic low back pain and a
recent hospitalization at ___ for HA, fever, and diarrhea who
had returned to his usual state of health prior to abrupt
recurrence of these symptoms two days ago.  Presents to the ED
primarily with ongoing diarrhea and RLQ pain, with resolving
generalized headache and malaise and found to have C. diff.  

# Hypotension: in ED BPs as low as ___ (MAPs ___ during my
exam; was completely asymptomatic and mentating normally at that
time.  He received 2 liters of IVF as well as Cipro/flagyl in 
ED.  There was concern for adrenal insufficiency, but he was 
able to have normal pressures without the need for stress dose 
steroids.  There was no evidence of blood or urine infection, 
though final results were pending at the time of this writing.  

#C. diff colitis - he was started on Vancomycin 125mg PO q6 on 
___ ___.  This will continue for a total of 14 days for severe 
infection.  He was counseled not to use Imodium and that 
symptoms can persist for days.  He should adhere to strict hand 
washing as well as should those around him.  His CT showed 
colonic inflammation.  

# ___: Cr 1.1 (up from baseline of 0.7), suspect
hypovolemic/pre-renal ___ and improved with IVF.  

# Coagulopathy (INR 1.4)
- Last hospitalization, he arrived and had INR of 1.5, given
Vitamin K and INR came down to 1.2, now just 2 weeks later his
INR is back up to 1.4.  This is likely in the setting of poor PO 
intacke given his concurrent low Albumin of 3.1.  He was given a 
repeat dose of Vitamin K 10mg IV and can discuss this issue as 
an outpatient.  

# Headache: mild, improved w/ Tylenol and NSAIDs and in the 
setting of acute illness.  There are no alarm features and the 
patient states that it is improving.  

# Pituitary microadenoma
  # Hyperprolactinemia
  # Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism -continued home meds

# Depression: continue home Sertraline 
# Anxiety: patient recently stopped Risperidone (~3 weeks ago)
# Insomnia: continue home lorazepam and trazodone (takes these
every night for sleep)

#Incidental finding of mild inflammation in SI joint - PCP can 
discuss this if he were to develop symptoms.

Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___

redness/swelling in RUE

none

 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ yo F with PMH stage IIIa melanoma s/p
resection and LN resection/interferon in remission since ___,
chronic R arm lymphedema presents to ___ ED on ___ with 
R
upper extremity redness consistent with cellulitis. 

Ms. ___ states she woke up this morning with redness and mild
swelling close to her elbow. Denies any trauma, insect bite,
scratch, or pruritis prior to sleeping. No recent travel.
Erythema spread rapidly around her elbow then down her foream 
and
later up towards her axillae. At that time she went to the ED
where she was found to have a fever of 101.3 but no other sepsis
criteria. She denies night sweats, weight loss, and only has
minimal pain in the arm. 

Describes 2 other similar events, last ___ where she was
treated for 4 days inpatient with iv abx and dc'd with still 
mild
erythema. She was then given zithro by her PCP ___ ? cat scratch
disease and the rash cleared immediately. Prior to that she had
another episode ___ year prior with similar results, attempted po
outpatient abx with continued spread and required inpatient stay
with iv antibiotics. 

Given unasyn and vancomycin in the ED at 14:25 with markings of
RUE with mild spread up arm

Onc history: 
Ms. ___ presented with an erythematous papule above her right
breast in late ___. Excisional biopsy performed on ___
demonstrated a 0.80 mm thick, early ___ IV, superficial
spreading melanoma, without ulceration and with 5 mitoses/mm2. 
On ___, she underwent wide local excision and sentinel lymph
node biopsy performed by Dr. ___.  Pathology from this 
procedure
revealed no residual melanoma at the primary site, but one right
axillary sentinel lymph node was positive for micrometastatic
melanoma.  On ___, she underwent completion right axillary
lymph node dissection with 12 lymph nodes removed, revealing no
melanoma. She commenced a course of adjuvant interferon on
___, completed in ___. She has been followed in
observation since then without evidence of recurrence.
 
Review of systems:  
(+) erythema, swelling R arm, fever
(-) Denies night sweats, weight loss, vomiting,a bd pain,
diarrhea, hematochezia, chest pain, SOA, confusion, dizziness,
loss of appetite, numbness/tingling
10 pt ROS otherwise neg

 
Past Medical History:

remission
RUE Lymphedema

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY:

essential htn
hld

___
Family History:
___ has a complex family history of cancer.  Her mother 
apparently had breast cancer at age ___ and died of ovarian 
cancer at age ___.  The maternal aunt had breast cancer in her 
___, but apparently died from pancreatic cancer later in life.  
The daughter of the same aunt, the patient's first cousin, had 
breast cancer at age ___.  A maternal uncle died of pancreatic 
cancer at age ___.  There are no other maternal aunts.  The 
paternal grandmother had breast cancer.  The paternal 
grandfather was fine as were the maternal grandparents.  The 
patient's father died in an accident.  Two brothers and two 
sisters are well.  Both sisters apparently have been tested for 
BRCA, but the results
were "inconclusive."  The patient is not aware of any other 
genetic testing.  She has a ___ daughter who is doing 
well in her first year of college.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ yo F with PMH stage IIIa melanoma s/p 
resection and LN resection/interferon in remission since ___, 
chronic R arm lymphedema presents to ___ ED on ___ with 
R upper extremity redness consistent with cellulitis. 

# RUE Cellulitis-- Pt presents with RUE swelling, erythema, and 
fevers c/w recurrent cellulitis.  Has been treated with IV abx 
at least 2x in the past and per her report, with azithro by her 
PCP ___ "cat scratch" given persistent swelling.  Pt started on 
IV vancomycin and azithro initially, with erythema tracking past 
demarcated borders.  She was seen by ID who recommended changing 
her abx to Vanc and Unasyn as appearance c/w Strep infection and 
low suspicion for cat-scratch.  Vanc also stopped on ___.  Pt 
continued to improve on Unasyn alone with marked improvement in 
erythema and swelling.  She will continue Augmentin on discharge 
for completion of 7-day course.

# Recurrent lymphedema-- h/o LN biopsy in ___, lymphedema 
without e/o
trauma. Unclear cause as pt has not had significant lymph node 
dissection.  ___ be increasing pt's risk of recurrent 
cellulitis.  Pt encouraged to discuss further w/u if warranted 
with OP Oncologist.
 
# h/o Stage IIIa melanoma in remission - s/p resection with LN 
biopsy/resection and 3 months interferon. Follows closely with 
dermatology and oncology.

# Essential Hypertension - controlled - continued enalapril 20, 
metop 100 ER

# Reflux - continued omeprazole 40

# hld - continued atorvastatin 40
 
Billing: greater than 30 minutes spent on discharge counseling 
and coordination of care

6.  Omeprazole 40 mg PO DAILY

Home

R arm cellulitis
Recurrent lymphedema

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You came in with a cellulitis of your right arm.  We treated you 
with an antibiotic called Unasyn to cover a bacteria called 
Strep and this improved your infection.  Please finish the 
course of antibiotics and continue to monitor your arm and 
return if you notice worsening redness, swelling, pain, fevers 
or chills.

It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___ 
___.

units.  Intrapartum, she was on an insulin drip, and was 
transitioned to lantus, Humalog, and a Humalog insulin sliding

discontinued and she voided spontaneously. Her diet was advanced 
without incident.

ambulating independently, and pain was controlled with oral 
medications. She was afebrile with stable vital signs. She was 
then discharged home in stable condition with postpartum 
outpatient follow-up scheduled.

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
rituximab / prochlorperazine
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Rituxamab desensitization 

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none
 
History of Present Illness:
Ms ___ is a ___ female with a history of breast cancer, 
psoriasis and Waldenstrom's Macroglobulinemia admitted for 
planned Rituximab desensitization. This is her ___ 
desensitization treatment of 4 total. She was just discharged 
___ from our service where she received her ___ infusion of 
Rituxamab without incident. Since her initial reaction to full 
dose Rituxamab she has not experienced any reactions during 
desensitization.
    
During the patient's first infusion, she developed erythema and 
hives on her back and around her ears, conjunctival injection, 
nasal congestion, throat swelling (subjective). She had a rise 
in her systolic blood pressure and her lungs remained clear 
without changes in her voice. She received steroids 
(Hydrocortisone 100mg, dexamethasone 20mg), benadryl 50mg IV, 
and pepcid 20mg IV with resolution of symptoms within 60 minutes 
later. Since then she has received desensitization therapy 
without issue
    
On current admission she appears well and has no new complaints. 
She 
is is slightly anxious but she feels well overall. She does 
report that during her desensitization period she has been 
having fluctuations in mood, increaseing anxiety and 
tearfullness. She reports after receiving desensitization on 
___ she is usually agitated and "angry" over the weekends, 
resolving by ___ the following week only to restart again 
after next round. She thinks this is the Dexamethasone effect. 
She has never had similar symptoms before desensitization. 
Patient also reports 3 falls in the last week. Once was a slip 
out of a chair when attempting to turn around. The other two 
were when trying to get out of bed. She reports no prodrome of 
symptoms including dizziness, lightheadedness, nausea, 
diaphoresis, tunnel vision, muffled hearing etc. She reports no 
loss of conciousness or "blacking out" She reports hitting the 
ground and hitting her head on the corner previously. She is 
having no neuro symptoms, no motor or sensory losses, no double 
vision, blurred vision etc.

 
Past Medical History:
-- With a history of breast cancer, she was found to have on
routine mammogram in ___ multiple abnormal-appearing
lymph nodes in the left inframammary and bilateral axillary
chains.
-- On ___, a fine needle aspirations of nodes in both the R
and L axilla were performed. Immunophenotypic findings were
consistent with a kappa-restricted B-cell lymphoproliferative
disorder that was negative for CD5 and CD10, suggesting a
possible marginal zone or lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma.
-- On ___, CT of the torso and neck were performed. Neck CT
reported numerous bilateral cervical lymph nodes with abnormal
morphology at all levels measuring up to 8 mm in short axis.
Torso CT found lymphadenopathy involving L axillary, 
mediastinal, L hilar, retrocrural, retroperitoneal, pelvic and
inguinal chains. In the chest, the largest focus was an
infracarinal lymph node measuring 3.2 x 1.3 cm. In the abdomen,
the largest focus was a conglomerate of lymph nodes at the level
of the left renal hilum measuring 2.5 x 2.9 cm. In the pelvis,
the largest foci were a lymph node on the right measuring 1.8 x
1.6 cm and a lymph node on the left measuring 2.0 x 1.7 cm. 
-- On ___, excisional lymph node biopsy procedure in the 
left axilla yielded 2 firm and large rubbery LNs ~1.2 cm in 
size.
-- Histologic sections revealed an enlarged lymph node that was
entirely effaced by an atypical nodular lymphoid population.
Cellularity was composed of small mature appearing lymphocytes,
lymphoplasmacytoid cells, and many conspicuous plasma cells.
___ bodies were seen. By immunohistochemistry, B cells were
highlighted by CD20 and BCL2 and were the predominant component
of lymphoid population.  They were negative for CD5 and CD10.
PAX5 was positive in a large subset of B cells, and appeared to
be lost in plasma cells, while MUM1 had a reciprocal staining
pattern. CD3 and CD45 were immunoreactive in a small subset of T
cells. CD23 highlighted several residual follicular dendritic
cell meshworks, and BCL6 and CD10 highlighted occasional 
germinal centers, which appeared reactive and were appropriately 
negative for BCL2. The MIB1 defined proliferation index was low 
overall, ___.
-- On ___, SPEP documented a monoclonal IgM-kappa 
representing 19% (1630 mg/dL) of total protein. Serum viscosity
was 2.3. UPEP was negative for protein including BJP. Serum FLC
assay showed normal free kappa and free lambda levels, with a
slightly increased ratio of 1.78.
-- On ___, diagnostic lymph node biopsy in the left axilla
confirmed the diagnosis of a low-grade, indolent lymphoma,
characterized by our pathologists as nodal marginal zone
lymphoma, not lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma as might be seen with
IgM-kappa in the range associated with smoldering ___.
-- ___, bone marrow biopsy and blood tests revealed 
worsening IgM levels and increasing serum viscosity. She started
plasmapharesis on ___ and then started rituximab on ___
but she developed an allergic reaction and thus was seen by
allergy to undergo recommended desensitization protocol.
-- ___: Rituxan infused per desensitization protocol without
incident
-- ___ Rituxamab desensitization protocol
    
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:  
-- s/p R poorly differentiated, ER-negative, 0.3 X 0.5 cm
infiltrating ductal carcinoma in ___, treated with R 
lumpectomy,
R axillary node dissection followed by XRT.
-- HTN.
-- Macular scarring.
-- Psoriasis.
-- Hx of Lyme disease ___ years ago, tx with 1 month course of
doxycycline.

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
- Both parents had rheumatoid arthritis. 
- Father died of metastatic melanoma at age ___ yrs, hx of 
lymphoma; mother with hx of retroperitoneal fibrosis, lymphoma 
s/p chemotherapy, which included rituximab. 4 sisters/1 brother 
alive & well.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ female with Waldenstrom's Macroglobulinemia admitted for 
planned Rituximab desensitization.  
   
# Mood lability and falls: No concerning neuro signs or symptoms 
on examintation. In setting of distant breast Ca as well as 
B-Cell lymphocytic process her symptoms were concerning for 
frontal lobe involvement. Head MRI and CTH were both normal and 
without mets. Ritux desensitixation mood changes and lability 
may be related to Dexamethasone possibly exacerbated by 
improving energy while on Sertraline. She has outpatient 
Onco-psychiatry and General Psychiatry already scheduled.
    
# Rituximab Desensitization: Admitted electively for ___ 
infusion of desensitization which she tolerated well without 
incident. She was premedicated with Diphenhydramine 50mg IV, 
Acetaminophen 650mg PO, Famotidine 20mg IV and Dexamethasone 
10mg IV all 30 min prior to infusion. Continued Cetirizine per 
home regimen. 
      
# Anxiety: Chronic and poorly controlled, recently restarted on 
Sertraline in the outpatient setting. Continued Sertraline 50mg 
PO daily and home Clonazepam PRN
    
# Neuropathy: Chronic, stable. Continued Gabapentin  
  
  
Transitional Issues:
- CONTACT: ___, daughter, ___  
- CODE: Full Code 
- Has follow up with outpatiet oncology to determine additional 
course of Rituximab
 
Medications on Admission:

Pertinent Results:

T bili 16 and direct bili 13. AST/ALT: 124/103; AP 303. INR 5.4. 
 
.  
Imaging:  
CT showed a 7x6x5 cm cystic lesion with calcification at the 
head of pancreas.  
ERCP-CBD and PD were dilated.  
CXR-LLL infiltrate 
.
ERCP ___ neoplasia of pancreas. Unable to access bile 
duct.
.
EKG NSR Q III, TWI III, AVF
.
CT ___ ventilation of the intereim bilary 
ducts as well as the main pancreatitic duct. multiloculated 
cystic lesion in the head of the pancreas associated with small 
punctate calcifications that can be related to a pancreatic 
neoplasia like serous cystadenoma of the pancreas. Suboptimal 
evaluation due to the lack of IV contrast. ERCP or MRCP is 
recommended for further eval. MIld free fluid in pelvis. 
Diverticulosis without diverticulitis. b/l cortical renal cysts.
.
RUQ u/s ___ intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary ductal 
dilatation of ? etiology. 
.
CXR ___ LLL infiltrate otherwise no significant acute 
finding.
.
WBC 13, HCT 29, plt 167. INR 1.3, ap 343, tbili 23.3, direct 
13.1, bun 26, ca 9 creat 0.81, gluc 95, lip 33, ast 166, alt 
110, TSH 0.___ yo F with HTN, skin melanoma in ___ and skin squamous cell 
cancer in ___ who developed new onset jaundice, nausea with 
vomiting and was found to have a cystic pancreatic mass at OSH.
.
# CMO: Patient was made comfort measure after discussion with 
family. Palliative care saw patient and it was decided that she 
would go home with hospice care. She was comfortable at the time 
of discharge. She was sent home on oxycodone, zofran, 
promethazine, compazine, & ativan for symptom management. 
Patient medications were reviewed and non-palliative medications 
were removed from regimen. We called the PCP ___ couple of times 
during this stay and were only able to reach his answering 
machine. We left messages with the new changes in care goals and 
with numbers for him to contact us. Family (very involved) has 
also said that they will be in touch with her PCP as well. She 
will continue to have her foley and oxygen with N as needed at 
home, which hospice can provide.
.
#bile duct obstruction with obstructive jaundice/cystic 
pancreatic head lesion-Etiology of patients symptoms, abdominal 
distention, nausea, jaundice is likely related to obstruction 
from pancreatic head mass. DDX includes malignancy vs. cyst. Pt 
does have h.o skin cancer, but unlikely to metastasize to 
pancreas. Pt may also have stricture or stones. She had an ERCP 
with 8cm by 10mm Wallflex fully covered biliary stent which was 
successfully placed with large amounts of mucin which drained. 
Patient presented with nausea and continued to have nausea 
intermittently throughout stay. Have increased regimen as above 
to control nausea, able to tolerate PO meds, gingerale, and some 
soft foods.
.
#Hypoxia-?LLL infiltrate--Pt thought to have PNA at OSH. CXR 
found streaky LLL infiltrate. Pt does have a leukocytosis, but 
denies cough. On exam, pt with elevated JVP/crackles more c/w 
volume overload. Pt does have suspicion of malignancy, and will 
consider if continued hypoxia. Will continue to cover for 
suspected pna including atypicals with levofloxacin to end on 
___. Able to tolerate PO so will go home with PO regimen.
.
#Transient bacteremia s/p ERCP: will treat with flagyl in 
addition to levoflox as above for total of 2 wk course, to end 
on ___. have been tolerating PO as well. 
.
#h.o skin cancer/squamous ___ f/u outpt 
if necessary but CMO at this point
.
#Afib: patient found to have atrial fibrillation ___ to 
procedure, which has resolved and has not recurred. No need for 
any anticoagulation especially given goals of care.
.
#Hypothyroidism: will continue home levothyroxine as it might 
help patient feel better, more energetic.
.
#code-DNR/DNI, CMO, d/w patient in presence of HCP.

text:
Name:  ___        Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Isordil / Procardia
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
rash
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none

 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ ___ woman DM, HTN, CAD with 
?MI about ___ years ago who presented to the ED with c/o rash and 
hives x 2 days. She reports eating a chicken taquito at ___ and 
soon after had red spots all over her body. +difficulty 
breathing, +sensation of her throat closing up. She states she 
was trembling, nauseated, and started having a lot of diarrhea. 
She has never had similar symptoms before and has not had any 
new medications or detergents. Of note, she had mild chest pain 
at the time of presentation.  
  
VS on presentation to the ED: 97.5 77 159/112 24 99% RA.  
She received solumedrol 125mg, benadryl 50mg, and pepcid 20mg IV 
overnight with improvement in her hives. In the morning, the ED 
nurse noted that the patient was in atrial fibrillation with 
elevated BP up to 180 systolic. The patient was complaining of 
___ chest pain associated with diaphoresis. Repeat EKG showed 
AFib/Flutter with question of TWI in V5-V6. She was given ASA 
325mg, clonidine 0.1mg, and lopressor 5mg IV followed by 
morphine 4mg IV and SL NTG and the patient was noted to be 
sleeping soon after, although she continued to report ___ pain 
when asked.  
 
Upon presentation to the floor, the patient stated she had a 
pain in her mid chest like a needle. She denied any palpitations 
or shortness of breath, although she does feel dizzy when 
standing.  
 
Past Medical History:
CAD s/p possible MI ___ yrs. ago (according to prior notes in 
chart)  
HTN  
DM II -- Hgb A1C ___ 6.9%  
Atrial fibrillation diagnosed ___, on coumadin in the past  
Depression  
OA  
GERD  
h/o anemia  
h/o colon polyps  
s/p TAHBSO ___ for symtomatic uterine fibroids  
s/p tarsal tunnel procedure (tunnel release?)  

PCP: ___ 

ALLERGIES: NKDA 
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
There is a positive family history of premature coronary artery 
disease. Her mother reportedly died of an MI at the age of ___ 
and her father at the age of ___. She has a daughter with HTN. 
 
Physical Exam:
VS - 97.2 146/78 82 20 99% 2L  
Gen: Pleasant overweight ___ woman sitting on edge 
of bed eating lunch. Oriented x3. Mood, affect appropriate.  
HEENT: Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were pink, no 
pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthalesma.  
Neck: Supple with JVP of 5-6 cm.  
CV: PMI located in ___ intercostal space, midclavicular line. 
Irregularly irregular with normal S1, S2. No m/r/g. No thrills, 
lifts. No S3 or S4. Marked tenderness to palpation of chest wall 
over sternum.  
Chest: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. Resp 
were unlabored, no accessory muscle use. CTAB, no crackles, 
wheezes or rhonchi.  
Abd: Soft, NTND. No HSM or tenderness. Abd aorta not enlarged by 
palpation. No abdominial bruits.  
Ext: No c/c/e. No femoral bruits. +Dupuytren's contracture of 
right pinky.  
Skin: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas. 
+Seborrheic keratoses. No hives.  
Pulses:  
Right: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ Popliteal 2+ DP 2+ ___ 2+  
Left: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ Popliteal 2+ DP 2+ ___ 2+ 
 
Pertinent Results:
LABORATORY DATA:  
Na/K 138/3.2  
BUN/Cr ___  
  
CK 42  
Trop < 0.01  
  
WBC 6.9  
Hct 42.7  
Plt 287  
  
Cholesterol ___:  
LDL 106  
HDL 41  

LABS DURING HOSPITAL COURSE:
___ 12:50PM BLOOD Glucose-142* UreaN-30* Creat-1.1 Na-141 
K-3.7 Cl-105 HCO3-29 AnGap-11
___ 06:25AM BLOOD CK(CPK)-42
___ 01:00PM BLOOD CK(CPK)-33
___ 09:22PM BLOOD CK(CPK)-36
___ 06:25AM BLOOD CK-MB-NotDone cTropnT-<0.01
___ 01:00PM BLOOD cTropnT-<0.01
___ 09:22PM BLOOD CK-MB-NotDone cTropnT-<0.01
___ 12:50PM BLOOD TSH-0.85

EKG demonstrated AFib/Flutter with normal axis and poor R wave 
progression. As compared with prior dated ___, she has new 
TWI in I, aVL, and V6.

Imaging:  
CXR ___:  
Moderate cardiomegaly is stable. Mediastinal and hilar contours 
are within normal limits. Allowing for low lung volumes, no 
focal consolidation is seen to suggest underlying pneumonia. No 
pleural effusion or pneumothorax is identified. The pulmonary 
vasculature is normal. Mild degenerative changes are seen in the 
spine.  
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient is a ___ woman with h/o DM, HTN, AFib apparently not 
coumadin, and ?CAD admitted with hives and found to have chest 
pain with lateral T wave inversions on EKG.  
  
#. Hives:  
Resolved with solumedrol and benadryl. Most likely was a 
reaction to something in the ___ and not any medication, but 
unclear what the trigger was.  Provided her with a prescription 
for benadryl as well as an EpiPen and reviewed the use of these 
medications with a translator prior to her discharge.  She 
understood that she needs to call ___ if she has trouble 
breathing. 

#. Chest pain/Costochondritis:  
Pain was reproducible on exam so was felt to be 
musculoskeletal/costochondritis.  Given her many risk factors 
for CAD, including family history, DM, HTN, and possible 
dyslipidemia, it was felt that she should discuss obtaining a 
stress test with her primary physician on an outpatient basis.  
Her personal history of CAD was unclear from the chart and the 
patient was unable to confirm if she had an MI in the past. 
Serial cardiac enzymes were negative and EKGs were stable.  She 
was continued on ASA, beta blocker, statin, and zetia.  She also 
received some NSAIDs for costochondritis.
  
#. Paroxysmal AFib/AFlutter  
Patient has been on coumadin in the past, but she was unable to 
confirm her medications and her pharmacy stated she had not 
filled coumadin prescription since ___.  Her CHADS2 score is 2. 
 Per discussion with PCP, the patient has been resistant to 
restarting coumadin and he has been unable to convince her to go 
back on it.  TSH was checked and was normal and rate was well 
controlled on beta blocker. 
   
#. DM--A1C 6.9% in ___  
Held metformin and glipizide while inpatient; covered with 
sliding scale during stay. 
 
#. HTN:  
Continued patient's beta blocker, HCTZ, and nifedipine.  Her ___ 
was held in the setting of her ARF but restarted on discharge.
  
#. Acute renal failure:   
Most likely due to dehydration in setting of diarrhea.  She was 
given IV fluids and her ___ was held.  Her renal failure 
resolved by the time of discharge.  

#. Diarrhea:  Volume resuscitation with IV fluids.  

#. Depression: continued fluoxetine  
 
#. Asthma: continued albuterol  
 
#. Code: Full code  
  
#. Comm: ___ (daughter): ___  
 
Medications on Admission:
CURRENT MEDICATIONS (Patient does not know her meds; list per 
her ___ in ___):  
Diclofenac 75mg BID  
Zetia 10mg daily  
Metoprolol succ 100mg daily  
Simvastatin 80mg daily  
HCTZ 25mg daily  
Cozaar 100mg daily  
Nifedical 60mg daily  
ASA 81  
Calcium plus Vitamin D BID  
Fluoxetine 20mg daily  
Fosamax 70mg qweek  
Tramadol 50mg TID PRN pain  
Metformin 500mg daily  
Glipizide XL 5mg daily  
Albuterol 90mcg 2 puffs Q4-6hr  
Warfarin 5mg--last filled in ___  
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Diclofenac Sodium 75 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: 
One (1) Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO twice a day.  
2. Ezetimibe 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  

3. Metoprolol Succinate 100 mg Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr 
Sig: One (1) Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr PO once a day.  
4. Simvastatin 80 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day.  
5. Hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO 
DAILY (Daily).  
6. Aspirin 81 mg Tablet, Chewable Sig: One (1) Tablet, Chewable 
PO DAILY (Daily).  
7. CALCIUM 500+D 500 (1,250)-200 mg-unit Tablet Sig: One (1) 
Tablet PO twice a day.  
8. Fluoxetine 20 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
9. Tramadol 50 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO three times a 
day as needed for pain.  
10. Albuterol 90 mcg/Actuation Aerosol Sig: Two (2) Puff 
Inhalation Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for shortness of breath 
or wheezing.  
11. Nifedical XL 60 mg Tab,Sust Rel Osmotic Push 24hr Sig: One 
(1) Tab,Sust Rel Osmotic Push 24hr PO once a day.  
12. Metformin 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day.  
13. Glipizide 5 mg Tab,Sust Rel Osmotic Push 24hr Sig: One (1) 
Tab,Sust Rel Osmotic Push 24hr PO once a day.  
14. Cozaar 100 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day.  
15. Fosamax 70 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a week.  
16. EpiPen 0.3 mg/0.3 mL Pen Injector Sig: One (1) pen 
Intramuscular once as needed for sudden difficulty 
breathing/facial swelling: Please inject yourself with EpiPen if 
you have facial swelling and sudden difficulty breathing.  Call 
___ right away.
Disp:*2 pens* Refills:*0*
17. Benadryl 25 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO three times a 
day as needed for hives.
Disp:*30 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary Diagnosis:  Urticaria
Secondary Diagnoses:  Chest pain, Costochondritis, Diabetes, 
Atrial fibrillation, Hypertension, Acute renal failure, 
Dehydration

 
Discharge Condition:
Vital signs stable, urticaria resolved.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted after you had an allergic reaction that caused 
hives.  Your symptoms improved with solumedrol and benadryl.  
You were also dehydrated and were given IV fluids to protect 
your kidneys.  Because you had some pain in your chest, we did 
tests that showed there was no damage to your heart.

1. Please take all medications as prescribed.  We did not make 
any changes to your regular medications.  

***You were given a prescription for benadryl, which you should 
take if you develop hives (the red spots you saw on your skin).  
If you have any difficulty breathing or feel like your throat is 
swelling up, please inject yourself with your EpiPen as you were 
shown AND call ___ right away.***

2. Please attend all follow-up appointments listed below.

3. Please call your doctor or return to the hospital if you 
develop chest pain, shortness of breath, fevers, rash or hives, 
difficulty breathing, facial swelling, or any other concerning 
symptom.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

ECHO
The left atrium is elongated. The right atrium is moderately 
dilated. No atrial septal defect is seen by 2D or color Doppler. 
There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal 
cavity size and regional/global systolic function (LVEF>55%). 
Tissue Doppler imaging suggests a normal left ventricular 
filling pressure (PCWP<12mmHg). Right ventricular chamber size 
and free wall motion are normal. The right ventricular cavity is 
mildly dilated with normal free wall contractility. The aortic 
valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is 
not present. Mild (1+) aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral 
valve leaflets are mildly thickened. There is no mitral valve 
prolapse. Mild to moderate (___) mitral regurgitation is seen. 
Moderate [2+] tricuspid regurgitation is seen. There is severe 
pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is a 
trivial/physiologic pericardial effusion. 

IMPRESSION: Mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with 
preserved biventricular function. Biatrial enlargement. Mild 
aortic regurgitation. Mild to moderate mitral regurgitation. 
Moderate tricuspid regurgitation. Severe pulmonary artery 
systolic hypertension.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ h/o CAD, CHF, Afib, OSA, IDDM, PE, PVD now p/w acute 
dyspnea, cough, and AFib with RVR, WBC of 15, +u/a and CXR 
concerning initially for infectious process leading to RVR 
causing CHF exacerbation and acute pulm edema. Infx etiologies 
were thought to include UTI or PNA. Also with some TW inversions 
could not exclude coronary ischemic process leading to heart 
failure (CEs neg x3). 
.  
# Dyspnea: likely secondary to AFib with RVR which may be 
incited by infection given WBC 15. CXR c/w edema, although 
infiltrates may be obscured. pt has h/o COPD, OSA, pulm 
hypertension. during her stay the pt received 40IV lasix x2 
followed by her home dose of 100mg PO lasix with net output of 
nearly 3L. she was then further diuresed with a lasix drip, 
requiring 9mg/hr for 24 hrs. her O2 requirement returned to her 
normal level of 2L NC at home. she was also treated with 
combivent nebs and her home inhalers. on discharge the pt's 
respiratory status was improved, and she was feeling better. she 
was discharged with instructions to stop taking her home lasix 
and to start taking torsemide 60 qd. notably, during her 
hospitalization she was fluid restricted, but it is thought at 
rehab she drinks quite a bit of fluids so her fluid status 
should be closely monitored as an outpatient.
.
# AFib: initially pt was in AFib RVR up to 120s, she was given 
5mg lopressor IV in the ED and again on the floor. she was also 
titrated up on her metoprolol to 100mg TID and was also started 
on digoxin due to an episode of Afib with RVR where the patient 
was asymptomatic. she was sent home with digoxin 0.0625mg daily. 
her rate was then stabilized to sinus rhythm 60-80. she was 
monitored on telemetry without subsequent events.
.  
# Leukocytosis: last WBC was 15 in ___ at that time thought 
to be due to UTI and/or steroid cream. unknown if there was 
interval change in WBC. now pt has U/A c/w mild UTI and CXR may 
be concerning for PNA (edema may obscure infiltrate). 
blood/urine cultures were obtained (negative to date). sputum 
could not be obtained as pt did not have any productive cough. 
she was started on levoquin 500mg daily to cover her for UTI and 
possible health care associated pneumonia. after one day of 
antibiotics, her WBC returned to normal range 9. she is advised 
to continue her antibiotics for a total of 7 days (2 more days 
remaining).
.  
# CAD/CHF: known multivessel disease, has h/o STEMI and multiple 
stents (see PMH). EF>50% with inf/post wall hypokinesis on last 
echo in ___. Last MIBI in ___ was negative. Last cath ___ 
showed multivessel disease. Ischemic coronary event leading to 
heart failure was ruled out as Trp was stable at 0.07 for all 3 
sets of cardiac enzymes, and CK's were negative. We continued 
her home ASA and lasix 100mg PO daily. We did not feel that a 
stress test was necessary. A repeat ECHO did not show 
significant change from her prior with the exception that her 
pulmonary hypertension has worsened. 
.  
# h/o PE: stable currently, coumadin was titrated to 3mg daily 
for goal INR ___. she is instructed to continue her coumadin 2mg 
daily and to have her INR's checked within ___ days as levoquin 
can sometimes interfere with coumadin metabolism. 
.  
# PVD: has chronic LLE pain and ulcerations seen by vasc surgery 
as outpt. pain controlled by home meds: oxycontine 30 bid 
standing, morphine liq prn, tylenol prn. she received necessary 
wound care for her ulcerations. 
.  
# IDDM: seen by ___, currently stable. we continued her home 
standing dose glargine and ISS.
.  
# Hypothyroid: stable, her TSH was normal. we continued her home 
levothyroxine.
.

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital due to shortness of breath and 
a rapid heart rate. You were treated with lasix and medications 
for your heart rate. You were also given antibiotics for a 
bladder infection. Your breathing improved and you felt better 
upon discharge. You were not requiring any more than your usual 
home oxygen. Your echocardiogram did not show any concerns for 
acute causes of pulmonary edema. Please note the following 
changes to your medications: please stop taking lasix, and 
ativan (as it may over sedate you); please begin taking 
torsemide 60mg once a day, metoprolol 100mg three times a day, 
digoxin 0.0625mg daily, coumadin 3mg daily, levofloxacin 500mg 
once a day for 2 more days. 
.
Please keep your follow up appointments.
.
Please take all medications as prescribed.
.
If you have chest pain, shortness of breath, fever, or other 
concerning symptoms please seek medical attention or go to the 
ER.

Weigh yourself every morning, call MD if weight goes up more 
than 3 lbs.
Adhere to 2 gm sodium diet
Fluid Restriction: 2 liters.

Name:  ___                     Unit No:   ___

Chief Complaint:
Hypoxia
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Central Line placement
Arterial Line placement
 
History of Present Illness:
___ yo F PMH of chronic respiratory failure s/p trach/peg, 
chronic afib, subdural hematoma s/p fall, status epileticus, DM 
presents as a transfer from ___ with sepsis, hypoxemia. 
History was obtained by multiple soruces including Kindred 
rehab, ___ and ___ ED records. At her SNF (Kindred), pt was 
found today to have hypotension, hypoxia (O2 as low as 70%) with 
increased respiratory secretions, fever (Tmax100.8) and pus in 
her foley. Pt was transferred to ___ for intial 
evaluation and was transferred to ___ for ICU care. On 
presentation to ___ pt had femoral CVL was placed, 5L NS was 
given, peripheral levophed was started as well as CFTX, flagyl, 
azithromycin. 

 

Of note, pt mental status is limited at baseline. Nursing at 
___ notes that pt is nonverbal, does not follow commands, 
and has no movement. Pt does open eyes to voice. 

 

 In ED initial VS:  no temperature recorded, HR 130, BP: 108/62, 
RR: 22, SO2: 92% vent 

 Exam:  afib w/ RVR, vomitus versus thick brown secretions being 
suctioned from her trach

 Labs significant for:  no leukocytosis, anemia (10.9); crt: 
1.3, INR 1.2, UA: cloudy, nitrite positive, large ___, 30 WBC, 
moderate bacteria. VBG pH 7.12 lactate 6.9

 Patient was given:  Piperacillin-Tazobactam, NORepinephrine 
(0.03-0.4 mcg/kg/min ordered)

 Imaging notable for:   CXR w/ hazy opacity projecting over the 
right lower lung c/f layering pleural effusion. 

 Consults:  none
 
Past Medical History:
Chronic resp failure s/p trach and peg
Atrial fibrillation
Depressive disorder
Subdural hematoma
Seizure disorder
Diabetes Mellitus
Orthostatic hypotension 
Intestinal infection due to Clostridium difficile 
Malignant neoplasm of ovary 
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Not obtainable or relevant

 HEENT: Sclera anicteric, pupils reactive
 NECK: supple  
 LUNGS: Coarse bilaterally 
 CV: Tachycardic and irregular
 ABD: soft, diffusely tender to palpation, distended 
 EXT: cool and poorly perfused on pressors

Glucose-NEG Ketone-NEG Bilirub-NEG Urobiln-NEG pH-8.5* Leuks-LG*
___ 05:30AM URINE RBC-0 WBC-30* Bacteri-MOD* Yeast-NONE 
Epi-0

Microbiology
- Blood and urine cultures pending at time of death

Abdominal X-Ray ___
Within the limitations of the study the findings are highly 
suspicious of 
pneumoperitoneum. CT may be considered for further 
characterization. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ y/o F with a h/o chronic resp failure s/p trach/PEG, A-fib, 
DM, Seizure disorder, who presented with shock, afib/RVR, UTI, 
acute hypoxemic and hypercarbic respiratory failure.

She was intubated and started on pressor and broad spectrum 
antibiotics in the ___ ED.  Central line was placed.  
Urinalysis was consistent with a urinary tract infection.  She 
was admitted to the ___ ICU.

After arrival in the medical ICU, A-Fib with RVR continued with 
rates to as high as the 180's.  She required escalating doses of 
vasopressors.  She was also started on amiodarone to control her 
rates.  After ICU admission, her ED Chest X-Ray was reviewed, 
and looked concerning for free air under the diaphragm 
(initially read as a loop of bowel).  She was noted to be tender 
on exam of the abdomen.  A stat portable abdominal XR confirmed 
the high suspicion for perforated viscous.  Surgery was 
consulted, recommending CT scan.

During this time, her lactate rose to 8.0.  Vasopressor 
requirement rose.  Continuous IV fluid boluses were given.  The 
son/HCP was contacted.  The patient was already DNR, per MOLST.  
After discussion with him, opted to defer on CT given low 
likelihood of being a good surgical candidate anyway, and the 
dangers involved in transporting a critically ill patient to 
radiology, and to focus on comfort.

Vasopressor medications were stopped, and she passed away 
shortly thereafter.
 
Medications on Admission:
Reviewed in nursing home records

deceased

Expired

deceased

deceased

deceased

text:
Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
vancomycin / Kefzol / Cipro / Sulfa (Sulfonamide Antibiotics)
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Chest Pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Deployment of 4 drug-eluting stents in the RCA ___
 
History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ is a ___ y/o M with H/O CAD s/p CABG ___ LIMA-D1-LAD 
and LIMA-Radial->OM1-RCA), with prior proximal RCA stent in ___ 
and mild LV systolic dysfunction with LVEF of 45% who presents 
with chest pain after a recent elective angioplasty procedure to 
his LAD.

The patient underwent stress echocardiogram on ___ which showed 
new anteroseptal hypokinesis which was thought to be indicative 
of LAD region ischemia. Outpatient coronary angiography on ___ 
showed native LMCA+3 vessel CAD. The LMCA had a focal 70% 
stenosis. The LAD had an 80% proximal and a 80% distal stenoses 
before the LIMA touchdown. The LCx was patent with an occluded 
large OM1. The RCA had a 70% mid lesion with a 70% distal lesion 
into the PL branch. The LIMA graft was a modest caliber vessel 
that was patent onto a diffusely disease distal LAD and D1 
branches. There was a radial conduit taking off the distal LIMA 
to the OM1, which was open and a jump graft to the RCA, which 
was occluded. The proximal LAD and distal LM were treated with 
overlapping 2.5x12 and 3.0 x 16 mm PROMUS PREMIER drug eluting 
stents post-dilated to 3.0 and 3.5mm respectively. The procedure 
was without complications and the patient returned home the day 
after the procedure.

The patient was going to work this AM. He got on the train from 
___ to ___. When he got off the train in ___, he 
began to feel weakness in his chest, right shoulder, and legs 
similar to symptoms he was having before stent placement with 
associated shortness of breath. The pain lasted almost ___ hours 
and was worsening, prompting him to come to the ED around noon.

On arrival to the ED, the patient's VS were T 98.6 HR 60 BP 
160/80 RR 18 SaO2 98% on RA. The patient described ___ pain and 
received morphine.  ECG showed sinus bradycardia @ 54; Q-waves 
in II,III, AVF; inverted t-waves in III, AVF, and v6, ___, 
submillimeter ST elevation in the anterior leads. First 
troponin-T was negative and the remainder of his lab tests were 
unremarkable. He was admitted to the CMed service for further 
evaluation.  On arrival to the cardiology floor, patient had no 
complaints.

Review of sytems:  
(+) Per HPI. A 12-point ROS was otherwise negative.
 
Past Medical History:
1.  CAD s/p CABG: LIMA-D1 and LAD, left radial artery from LIMA 
to OM1, and RCA at ___ E's in ___ inferior MI and RCA 
stent ___ with EF 45%, IPMI inferolateral 
scarring/thinning. ___ PCI of the distal LM and proximal LAD 
with drug eluting stents
2. Cardiomegaly
3. Gout
4. PAD with aneurysm
5. NSSVT
6. RBBB
7. Hypertension
8. Dyslipidemia
9. Tobacco abuse
10. Hyperkalemia
11. OSA, unable to tolerate CPAP
12. New diagnosis of ocular migraines at Mass Eye and Ear ED ___ 
wks ago
13. Gallbladder
14. Hernia repair w/ mesh; s/p later mesh removal
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Father heart problem in his ___; mother with heart problems at 
age ___
 
Physical Exam:
On Admission
General: Middle-aged Caucasian man in NAD, comfortable, pleasant

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old woman with a h/o chronic AF on 
Coumadin and DCIS s/p right partial mastectomy on ___ who 
presented ___ with pain and swelling over the surgical site 
and was found to have a 7.0cm hematoma. She was taken to the 
operating room and underwent hematoma evacuation that same day 
with electrocautery of bleeding vessel(s), and ultimately 
received 1 unit of FFP and PRBCs in the perioperative period. 
She tolerated the procedure well and was transferred to the 
floor for postoperative care. 

Cardiology was consulted for assistance in management of 
anticoagulation who felt it would be reasonable for patient to 
restart her Coumadin without bridge. Therefore, her Coumadin was 
restarted on ___ and INR levels were monitored daily. 
___, she was transfused with 1 unit PRBC for hematocrit of 
21.3. Of note, there was no obvious source of bleeding from her 
surgical site and her JP drain was exuding acceptable amounts of 
serosanguinous drainage. Her post-transfusion hematocrit was 
24.3. ___, she was discharged home with ___ for wound 
assessment and JP drain monitoring. Pt will follow-up 
appointment in breast clinic and have next INR level checked on 
___.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,
You presented to ___ ED with right breast swelling following 
your right breast excisional biopsy and was found to have a 
right breast hematoma and was subsequently taken back to the 
operating room for evacuation of hematoma and placement of a JP 
drain. Because you had postoperative surgical site bleeding, 
your blood thinners were held and you were evaluated cardiology. 
Per cardiology recommendations your Coumadin was ultimately 
restarted on ___ for management of your Afib. Please go to 
___ lab and have your INR level checked on ___ ___ and 
follow-up with your ___ clinic for dosing. Please note that 
your Lovenox has been discontinued.
You have adequate pain control and your surgical wound is 
healing well without any evidence of infection or bleeding and 
you may return home to finish your recovery. You are being 
discharged home with a drain in place and we have arranged for a 
visiting nurse to assist you with drain care. Drain care is a 
clean procedure. Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and warm 
water before performing drain care. Perform drainage care twice 
a day. Try to empty the drain at the same time each day. Pull 
the stopper out of the drainage bottle and empty the drainage 
fluid into the measuring cup. Record the amount of drainage 
fluid on the record sheet. Reestablish drain suction.

Please Call the office IMMEDIATELY if you have any of the 
following: 
1. Signs of infection: fever with chills, increased redness, 
swelling, warmth or tenderness at the surgical site, or unusual 
drainage from the incision(s). 
2. A large amount of bleeding from the incision(s) or drain(s). 
3. Fever greater than 101.5 oF 
4. Severe pain NOT relieved by your medication. 

Return to the ER if: 
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications. 
* If you have shaking chills, fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38 (C) degrees, increased redness, swelling or 
discharge from incision, chest pain, shortness of breath, or 
anything else that is troubling you. 
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
concern you. 
* Weigh yourself every morning, call MD if weight goes up more 
than 3 lbs.

Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care.
Your ___ Team
