Chief Complaint: left knee pain Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure: ___: s/p Left total knee replacement History of Present Illness: ___ y/o with advanced OA, presents for surgical management. Past Medical History: CKD, stage ___, with GFR been around ___ Hx of ANEMIA, recently Hb has been stable, 12.8 in ___ HYPERCHOLESTEROLEMIA, controlled HYPERTENSION, stage 2 Social History: ___ Family History: NC Physical Exam: Well appearing in no acute distress Afebrile with stable vital signs Pain well-controlled Respiratory: CTAB Cardiovascular: RRR Gastrointestinal: NT/ND Genitourinary: Voiding independently Neurologic: Intact with no focal deficits Psychiatric: Pleasant, A&O x3 Musculoskeletal Lower Extremity: * Incision healing well with staples * Scant serosanguinous drainage * Thigh full but soft * No calf tenderness * ___ strength * SILT, NVI distally * Toes warm Pertinent Results: ___ 06:25AM BLOOD WBC-12.1* RBC-3.17*# Hgb-9.0*# Hct-28.3*# MCV-89 MCH-28.5 MCHC-32.0 RDW-14.4 Plt ___ ___ 07:10AM BLOOD WBC-14.4* RBC-3.03* Hgb-8.7* Hct-26.6* MCV-88 MCH-28.9 MCHC-32.9 RDW-14.4 Plt ___ ___ 06:30AM BLOOD WBC-12.3* RBC-2.71* Hgb-7.9* Hct-23.8* MCV-88 MCH-29.3 MCHC-33.3 RDW-13.3 Plt ___ ___ 06:25AM BLOOD Glucose-113* UreaN-31* Creat-1.4* Na-136 K-4.7 Cl-105 HCO3-24 AnGap-12 ___ 10:25AM BLOOD Glucose-128* UreaN-30* Creat-1.6* Na-135 K-4.6 Cl-103 HCO3-24 AnGap-13 ___ 06:30AM BLOOD Glucose-90 UreaN-29* Creat-1.4* Na-137 K-4.4 Cl-104 HCO3-25 AnGap-12 Brief Hospital Course: The patient was admitted to the orthopaedic surgery service and was taken to the operating room for above described procedure. Please see separately dictated operative report for details. The surgery was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated the procedure well. Patient received perioperative IV antibiotics. Postoperative course was remarkable for the following: 1. increased WBCs - UA positive for large leuks. started on cipro 250 BID x 3 days. 2. post op blood loss anemia - HCT 23.8 on POD3 -> transfused 1u PRBCs Otherwise, pain was initially controlled with a PCA followed by a transition to oral pain medications on POD#1. The patient received lovenox for DVT prophylaxis starting on the morning of POD#1. The foley was removed on POD#2 and the patient was voiding independently thereafter. The surgical dressing was changed on POD#2 and the surgical incision was found to be clean and intact without erythema or abnormal drainage. The patient was seen daily by physical therapy. Labs were checked throughout the hospital course and repleted accordingly. At the time of discharge the patient was tolerating a regular diet and feeling well. The patient was afebrile with stable vital signs. The patient's hematocrit was acceptable and pain was adequately controlled on an oral regimen. The operative extremity was neurovascularly intact and the wound was benign. The patient's weight-bearing status is weight bearing as tolerated on the operative extremity. Enoxaparin Sodium 30 mg SC Q24H 14. HYDROmorphone (Dilaudid) ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain 15. Senna 1 TAB PO BID 16. Nasonex *NF* (mometasone) 50 mcg/actuation NU prn allergies 17. Ciprofloxacin HCl 250 mg PO Q12H Duration: 3 Days Discharge Disposition: Extended Care Facility: ___ Discharge Diagnosis: Left knee OA Discharge Condition: Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker or cane). Discharge Instructions: 1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns. 2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this admission and any new medications and refills. 3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed. 4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily and take a stool softener (such as colace) as needed to prevent this side effect. Call your surgeons office 3 days before you are out of medication so that it can be refilled. These medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house. Please allow an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your home. 5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your surgeon. 6. Please keep your wounds clean. You may shower starting five (5) days after surgery, but no tub baths or swimming for at least four (4) weeks. No dressing is needed if wound continues to be non-draining. Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken out at first follow up appointment two weeks after your surgery. 7. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your follow-up appointment in two (2) weeks. 8. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDs such as celebrex, ibuprofen, advil, aleve, motrin, etc). 9. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue your lovenox for four (4) weeks to help prevent deep vein thrombosis (blood clots). If you were taking aspirin prior to your surgery, it is OK to continue at your previous dose while taking this medication. ___ STOCKINGS x 6 WEEKS. 10. WOUND CARE: Please keep your incision clean and dry. It is okay to shower five days after surgery but no tub baths, swimming, or submerging your incision until after your four (4) week checkup. Please place a dry sterile dressing on the wound each day if there is drainage, otherwise leave it open to air. Check wound regularly for signs of infection such as redness or thick yellow drainage. Staples will be removed AT FIRST POST OP APPOINTMENT in two (2) weeks. 11. ___ (once at home): Home ___, dressing changes as instructed, wound checks. 12. ACTIVITY: Weight bearing as tolerated on the operative extremity. Mobilize. CPM/ROM as tolerated. No strenuous exercise or heavy lifting until follow up appointment. Physical Therapy: LLE WBAT ROM unrestricted CPM ___ for 2hr sessions, maximum flexion Mobilize Treatments Frequency: Dry sterile dressing daily as needed for drainage Wound checks Ice and elevation TEDs *Staples will be remoaved at follow-up appointment in 2 weeks* Followup Instructions: ___

text:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Chloroquine / Barium Sulfate
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Direct admission from clinic for atrial fibrillation - pt 
asymptomatic.
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
Pt states he recently had an ablation proceedure for his thyroid 
disease on ___. He was seen in ___ clinic as a 
follow-up this AM where he was found to have an elevated and 
irregular heart rate. He was sent to his PCP's office where he 
was found to be in a-fib on exam and on EKG. Pt's cardiologist 
was contacted who recommended coming to the hospital for beter 
rate control.
.
Patient denies CP, SOB, palpitations, lightheadedness. Says he 
is not sure why he is here and that he feels normal. Mentions 
the following positives on ROS:
+ cough: worsening over past 2 weeks. wife reports they were 
both sick in ___, it seemed to improve, and it has intervally 
worsened since traveling to S. ___ in ___. Cough is 
non-productive.
+ night sweats: wife reports pt has been suffering from night 
sweats for last 6 months or perhaps longer
+ wt loss: very minor - 5lbs over last six months
+ fatigue: worse over last few months. family wonders if related 
to worsening dementia
+ increased forgetfullness over last year
.
Other review of systems negative: he denies any prior history of 
stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, 
bleeding at the time of surgery, myalgias, hemoptysis, black 
stools or red stools. He denies recent fevers. He denies 
exertional buttock or calf pain. All of the other review of 
systems were negative.
*** Cardiac review of systems is notable for absence of chest 
pain, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, ankle edema, 
palpitations, syncope or presyncope. 
 
Past Medical History:
-Hyperthyroidism now s/p radioactive ablation
-Hyperlipidemia
-CAD
-Likely Mild Alzheimers
-Urinary Frequency and urethral strictures
-Hx of + PPD in ___
-Distant Polio as kid 
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Mom: ___
Dad: ___ heart issues (died in ___ 
 
Physical Exam:
VS - 98.8 / 141/84 / 101 / 18 / 99% RA
Gen: elderly white male who looks good for age. Oriented x3. 
Mood, affect appropriate.
HEENT: Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were pink, no 
pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. ___ Mucous mem.
Neck: Supple with No JVD
CV: IRIR, normal S1, S2. No m/r/g. No thrills, lifts. No S3 or 
S4.
Chest: CTAB, no crackles, wheezes or rhonchi.
Abd: Soft, NTND. No HSM or tenderness. Normoactive BS
Ext: No c/c/e. No rashes.
Skin: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas. 
 
Pertinent Results:
Admission Labs:
CBC: WBC-9.5 RBC-4.19* Hgb-13.2* Hct-38.8* MCV-93 MCH-31.5 
MCHC-34.0 RDW-13.9 Plt ___
Coags: ___ PTT-22.9 ___
Chem: Glucose-140* UreaN-28* Creat-1.1 Na-138 K-4.2 Cl-102 
HCO3-29 AnGap-11
ALT-19 AST-18 CK(CPK)-36* Calcium-9.3 Phos-4.5 Mg-2.1
Cardiac Markers:
CK-MB-2 cTropnT-LESS THAN 
CK-MB-2 cTropnT-LESS THAN 
CK-MB-2 cTropnT-<0.01
Thyroid Markers:
TSH-<0.02*
T3-132 Free T4-3.1*
.
Other Studies:
CXR ___: Clear lungs with no signs of infection. 
Chronic, non-progressingndeviation of the mid trachea, possibly 
due to thyroid mass.
.
Discharge Labs:
CBC: WBC-8.8 RBC-4.19* Hgb-13.2* Hct-38.6* MCV-92 MCH-31.4 
MCHC-34.1 RDW-14.0 Plt ___
Coags: ___ PTT-95.1* ___
Chem: Glucose-133* UreaN-25* Creat-0.9 Na-139 K-4.5 Cl-102 
HCO3-29 AnGap-13
 
Brief Hospital Course:
ID: Patient is a ___ yr/o M with Hx of Hyperthyroidism (s/p 
recent radioactive ablation), CAD, HLD, mild dementia who 
presents directly from clinic in Afib with mild RVR.
.
#. Atrial fibrillation:
Likely new onset although since pt has no symptoms hard to know 
when this rhythm started. Pt asymptomatic. VSS. Inciting causes 
was believed to be ___ to hyperthyroidism in pt with recent 
ablation and most recent T4 elevated from previous. Since pt had 
CHADS score of 1, it makes benefit of anticoagulation on 
warfarin questionable. Since unsure how long pt in Afib, would 
need TEE or 4 weeks anticoagulation before any cardioconversion 
attempted. It was also decided that there would be no point to 
cardioversion until thyroid issues addressed. Metoprolol was 
increased to 25mg tatrate BID while in hospital. This succeeded 
in controlling pt rate overnight and the next morning so he was 
discharged with metoprolol succinate 50mg (increased from 
previous dose of 25mg) for rate control.
.
#. Hyperthyroidism: 
Free T4 elevated at 3.1 today. T3 WNL. TSH depressed. Pt 
received radio ablation on ___ (20 mCi of I-131). Dr. 
___ that pt methimazole dose be increased to 
20mg total per day, so prescription was changed to give 10mg BID 
and pt was discharged on this dose to follow-up with Dr. ___ 
in ___ weeks.
.
 
Medications on Admission:
-Atorvastatin 40mg PO Qhs
-Donepezil 10mg PO Qam (pt reports he has not taken recently)
-Memantine 10mg PO BID (pt reports he has not taken recently)
-Methimazole 5mg PO Qd
-Metoprolol XL 25mg PO Qd
-Omeprazole 20mg PO Qd
-Tolterodine SR 4mg PO Qd
-Zolpidem 5mg PO Qhs PRN: sleep
-ASA 81mg PO Qd
-Cholecalciferol (Vitamin D3) 1,000 units daily
-Glucosamine-Chondroitin 750 mg-600 mg Tablet 2 Tabs Qd
-Prasterone 50mg PO Qd
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Metoprolol Succinate 50 mg Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr 
Sig: One (1) Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr PO once a day.
Disp:*30 Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr(s)* Refills:*1*
2. Atorvastatin 40 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO HS (at 
bedtime).  
3. Omeprazole 20 mg Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) Sig: One (1) 
Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily).  
4. Tolterodine 4 mg Capsule, Sust. Release 24 hr Sig: One (1) 
Capsule, Sust. Release 24 hr PO once a day.  
5. Zolpidem 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO HS (at bedtime) 
as needed for sleep.  
6. Vitamin D 1,000 unit Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a 
day.  
7. Methimazole 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a day.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
8. Aspirin 325 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
9. Memantine 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a day.  
10. Donepezil 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO QAM: take with 
food.  
11. Ativan 0.5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO at bedtime as 
needed for sleep.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary Diagnosis:
1) Atrial Fibrillation 
2) Hyperthyroidism

Secondary Diagnosis:
1) Mild dementia

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to the hospital from clinic with an irregular 
and rapid heart rate. You were found to be in atrial 
fibrillation and your metoprolol was increased. Your thyroid 
levels were also elevated so your methimazole was increased per 
your endocrinologists recommendations. Finally, your aspirin 
dose was increased to help protect against clotting. When your 
heart rate was controlled with metoprolol, you were discharged 
home.
.
Medication changes:
-Aspirin changed from 81mg by mouth once each day to 325mg by 
mouth once each day
-Methimazole increased from 5mg by mouth once each day to 10mg 
by mouth twice each day
-Metoprolol XL increased from 25mg by mouth once each day to 
50mg by mouth once each day.
.
You will have the following follow-up appointments:
Endocrinologist Dr. ___ in 1 week. Her office will call you 
with appointment time, but if you do not hear from them please 
call her office.
.
We have contacted your PCP and cardiologist regarding what 
happened this admission. They may contact you regarding 
follow-up appointments if they believe such an appointment is 
needed.

History of Present Illness:
___ with history of Hep C cirrhosis complicated by ascites and 
encephalopathy, now admitted for the same.  Patient recently 
admitted from ___ - ___ for increasing ascites with 
questionable compliance with medications and fluid restriction 
at her nursing home.  She had 9 liter LVP that admission with 75 
g albumin.
.
Patient reports increasing distension since her discharge, but 
particularly worse during the last ___ days.  Feels distended 
and diffusely sore but without severe or focal pain.  Reports 
compliance with her diuretic regimen but does admit to drinking 
at least 4 liters of fluids per day due to thirst and constantly 
feeling hot at her SNF.  No jaundice.  No significant change in 
her ankle edema.  Taking lactulose usually twice per day 
(sometimes three times) but will have >10 bowel movements per 
day with TID dosing.  Does note poor appetite associated with 
feeling significant distension.  No fevers.  Does not feel that 
she has been significantly confused, though others have noted it 
today.  She states she is simply tired.
.
Sent from Liver Clinic today after scheduled appointment with 
Dr. ___ large volume para and readdressing meds and 
compliance issues.

focal tenderness to palpation.
EXT:  ___ lower extremity edema with venous stasis changes.
Neuro:  Alert and appropriate, with slightly slowed speech as 
above.  CN II-XII intact.  Mild asterixis present.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient is a ___ yo female with Hep C cirrhosis and a long 
history of noncompliance w/ medications now p/w reaccumulation 
of ascites and mild encephalopathy.
.  
# Ascites:  The patient presented with a recent reaccumulation 
of large ascites.  The patient states that she has been 
compliant with her medications, but she admits to drinking 4+ 
liters of water daily.  She had an abdominal ultrasound on 
admission, which did not demonstrate evidence of portal vein 
thrombosis.  She had therapeutic paracenteses on ___, and ___, 
with 11L and 5.5L removed, respectively.  The patient was given 
75 g and 37.5 g of albumin, respectively, after the 
paracenteses.  The patient was continued on her home doses of 
Spironolactone and Lasix during this admission. 
.
# Hepatic encephalopathy:  On admission, the patient had 
asterixis and slightly slowed speech.  She was restarted on her 
home dose of Lactulose, and she had five to seven bowel 
movements daily.  The patient continued to appear confused on 
this admission, so she was started on Rifaximin 400 mg TID.  Her 
mental status remained at baseline, and she was discharged on 
Lactulose and Rifaximin TID.  
.
# Hepatitis C cirrhosis: The patient has a history of HepC 
cirrhosis, complicated by asterixis and encephalopathy, as 
described above.  The patient was continued on her home doses of 
Nadolol, Lasix, Spironolactone, and Lactulose, and she did not 
have any acute events during this admission.   
.  
# Migraines: The patient has a history of migraines, for which 
she takes Fioricet at home.  The patient was continued on her 
home regimen of Fioricet and Sumatriptan prn, and she did not 
have any evidence of migraines on this admission.    
.  
# Seizure disorder: The patient has a history of a seizure 
disorder, for which she takes Dilantin and Topamax at home.  The 
patient was continued on these medications, and she did not have 
any acute events during this admission.  
.  
# Depression: The patient has a history of depression, for which 
she takes Celexa daily.  She was continued on this medication, 
and she did not have any acute events.
 
Medications on Admission:
Nadolol 20mg daily  
Thiamine 100 mg daily  
MVI  
Celexa 20mg daily  
Spironolactone 100mg daily  
Lasix 60mg daily

Fioricet 2 tabs PO PRN  
Imitrex 0.5ml SQ PRN  
Maxair INH 1 puff q6h PRN  
Simethicone 80mg QID PRN  
Trazodone 50mg qHS

Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary:
Hepatitis C cirrhosis complicated by ascites and hepatic 
encephalopathy

Secondary:
Depression
Migraines

 
Discharge Condition:
Good.  The patient's VS are stable, and she is able to ambulate 
with a walker, as is her baseline.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital because you had increased 
ascites.  While you were here, we did therapeutic paracenteses 
on ___ and ___.  We also started you on a new medication 
for hepatic encephalopathy, Rifaximin.  

While you were here, we made the following changes to your 
medications:
1.

Please take all medications as prescribed.

Please keep all previously scheduled appointments.

Please return to the ED or your healthcare provider if you 
experience shortness of breath, chest pain, increasing 
confusion, increasing fatigue, abdominal pain, fevers, chills, 
or any other concerning symptoms.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old man with a history of atrial fibrillation, recent 
multiple embolic stroke, and history of alveolar hemorrhage who 
was re-admitted to the hospitalist service because of 
hypertension and tachycardia. He had evidence of uncontrolled 
atrial fibrillation with RVR, volume overload from fluid 
administration, and acute diastolic heart failure. He received 
some IV metoprolol with good response, and his heart rate 
responded to an increase in his atenolol to BID. He also 
received Lasix and he became no longer hypoxic.  His lung exam 
was clear after one injection of Lasix, and he did not receive 
further diuresis. He was seen by neurology who recommended 
anticoagulation with warfarin. The treatment was complicated by 
a history of diffuse alveolar hemorrhage in the context of 
community acquired pneumonia, the details of which were unclear. 
However, after talking to the primary care physician and family, 
the risks of anticoagulation were weighed against the risk of 
further embolic stroke, and the decision to anticoagulate was 
made. A heparin drip was initiated and then was started on 
warfarin. During the last admission, he had decreased level of 
consciousness. He had a LP which was negative. This was believed 
to be multifactorial: sedating medications (trazodone/zolpidem 
at rehab), infection (aspiration pneumonia), and thalamic 
stroke. This resolved over the course of the last hospital stay, 
and upon discharge he was interactive and responsive, moving all 
extremities, and participatory in rehab. During this hospital 
stay, he became more lethargic and lost his consciousness. His 
eye became closed, with spasticity of the upper extremities. He 
had no verbal communication, was not eating, and did not move 
his extremities. He had CT of head, MRI, and EEG. These tests 
did not show bleed, new stroke, or clear evidence of seizure. 
He, however, was treated with Keppra IV because of high risk of 
seizures and arm spasticity. Despite Keppra and several doses of 
Ativan, he did not improve. We had several family meetings. The 
code status and goals of care reviewed with patient's son and 
wife during the previous hospitalization and this 
hospitalization; he became DNR/DNI. The wife stated that patient 
had expressed wishes not to have any life prolonging therapies, 
but she is stating that she wishes that he be treated for this 
acute illness. However, after he became unconscious for several 
days, she decided on comfort measures. The son agreed with the 
plan and they decided against artifical feeding. During his 
hospitalization, he was treated for aspiration pneumonia and 
with Cefepime and metronidazole and completed a total ___ll CSF, urine and blood cultures remained negative 
throughout admission except one urine culture that showed 
enterococcus ( VRE) in small amounts. Subsequent urine culture 
was negative. The patient was transferred to hospice.

text:
Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Sulfa (Sulfonamide Antibiotics)
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Diarrhea
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ with history of seizures, HTN, HLD, DM, CAD 
s/p CABG, now presenting with ___ weeks of diarrhea.

She has had diarrhea for the past ___ weeks. The loose stools 
started approximately 4 days after her last discharge (She was 
recently admitted from ___ to ___ for seizure monitoring. At 
that time she was switched from dilantin to gabapentin). She has 
loose stools approximately every other day, and on some days she 
has no bowel movements. She describes the stools as 
watery/clumpy, with small streaks of blood recently which her 
daughter thinks may be secondary to repeated wiping. She has 
been wearing adult diapers which she has never required before. 
Reportedly yesterday she had ~25 episodes of loose stools. 
Notably she has had constipation at baseline since starting the 
fentanyl patch many years ago. No recent antibiotic use. She has 
had some nausea but no vomiting. She has been able to eat during 
this time but less than her baseline.

She also complains of leg weakness which is worse for the past 2 
weeks. She had a fall 9 days ago when her legs gave out under 
her while she was walking. She was caught by her daughter, did 
not lose consciousness or hit her head.

She also complains of thumb pain, which she attributes to injury 
sustained when trying to push herself up using her hands from a 
seated position.

In the ED, initial VS were 98.7 54 127/49 16 97% RA.   
Exam significant for 1+ pitting edema to ___ bilaterally, up to 
knee. 
Labs significant for WBC 10.8, H/H 10.5/32.4, Cr 1.2 (baseline 
~1.0). No imaging or interventions were performed.
Transfer VS were 98.2 56 119/55 17 99% NC.
  
On arrival to the floor, patient reports mild RLQ abdominal 
pain. Also endorses headache of unknown time course.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:  
Denies fever, chills, night sweats, vision changes, rhinorrhea, 
congestion, sore throat, cough, shortness of breath, chest pain, 
nausea, vomiting, constipation, hematochezia, dysuria, 
hematuria.  
All other 10-system review negative in detail.  
 
Past Medical History:
 
- Diabetes mellitus type II
- Dyslipidemia  
- Hypertension  
- CAD  
- CABG in ___ LIMA to the LAD, s/p PCI in ___
- CVA x 3 with memory deficit and residual weakness in LLE  
- Seizure disorder  
- COPD  
- Peripheral neuropathy  
- Cocaine abuse  
- Nephrolithiasis  
- Chronic pain syndrome  
- Visual loss OD (from glaucoma)  
- s/p cholecystectomy  
- s/p appendectomy  
- s/p hysterectomy  
- S/P right knee surgery  
- S/P right elbow surgery  
- s/p cataract surgery  

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Mother with alcohol dependence, sister with depression and a son 

with ___ abuse.

 
Physical Exam:
ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAM:  
98.1 105/45 60 20 98(2L) FSBG 186
GENERAL: NAD  
HEENT: AT/NC, EOMI, PERRL, anicteric sclera, pink conjunctiva, 
patent nares, MMM, good dentition, nontender supple neck, no 
LAD, no JVD. R eye opacity noted.
CARDIAC: RRR, S1/S2, no murmurs, gallops, or rubs  
LUNG: Coarse breath sounds, exam limited by patient vocalization 
during breaths. Endorses some discomfort with deep breaths. 
Otherwise CTAB, breathing comfortably without use of accessory 
muscles.
ABDOMEN: nondistended, +BS. Endorses RLQ tenderness to 
palpation, no masses noted. No rebound/guarding. Negative 
___ sign.
EXTREMITIES: Moving all extremities well. 1+ pitting edema 
bilaterally to knees.
PULSES: 2+ DP pulses bilaterally  
NEURO: CN II-XII intact. ___ Hz shaking of bilateral arms and 
legs.
SKIN: warm and well perfused, no excoriations or lesions, no 
rashes  
 
DISCHARGE PHYSICAL EXAM:  
98.2 98.6 ___ 18 94RA
GENERAL: Lying in bed, NAD
HEENT: No petechiae. Anicteric sclera, MMM, nontender supple 
neck, no LAD, no JVD. R eye opacity noted.
CARDIAC: Normal S1/S2. No murmurs, gallops, or rubs  
LUNG: CTAB. Breathing comfortably
ABDOMEN: Nondistended, +BS. Nontender, no rebound/guarding.
EXTREMITIES: Moving all extremities well. Peripheral edema 
improved.
PULSES: 2+ DP pulses bilaterally  
NEURO: A/O x3.
SKIN: Warm and well perfused. No rashes.
 
Pertinent Results:
EKG ___:
Sinus rhythm. Poor R wave progression. Compared to the previous 
tracing there are modest lateral ST-T wave changes. Compared to 
the previous tracing of ___ there is no significant 
diagnostic change. 
  Intervals Axes 
Rate PR QRS QT/QTc P QRS T 
60 146 70 ___ 43

MCV-92 MCH-29.7 MCHC-32.5 RDW-13.0 Plt ___
___ 06:05AM BLOOD WBC-11.9* RBC-4.00* Hgb-11.4* Hct-36.1 
MCV-90 MCH-28.4 MCHC-31.5 RDW-13.3 Plt ___

K-4.6 Cl-108 HCO3-22 AnGap-14
___ 06:05AM BLOOD Glucose-190* UreaN-22* Creat-1.1 Na-141 
K-4.3 Cl-101 HCO3-28 AnGap-16
___ 10:00AM BLOOD ALT-30 AST-26 AlkPhos-217* Amylase-30 
TotBili-0.3
___ 06:05AM BLOOD Calcium-9.1 Phos-3.0 Mg-1.5* Iron-PND
___ 03:55AM BLOOD TSH-2.7
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ with history of seizures, HTN, HLD, DM, CAD 
s/p CABG, presenting with ___ weeks of diarrhea and report of 
falls at home.

# Diarrhea:
Resolved. She reported worsening loose stools for ___ weeks. 
However she had no bowel movements during her hospital stay, 
with the exception of one very small stool which she said was 
not saved. She was subsequently restarted on a bowel regimen for 
ongoing constipation (which has been her baseline since starting 
the fentanyl patch).

Differential diagnosis for her history of diarrhea includes 
gabapentin drug effect, IBS, viral infection. Unlikely to be 
new-onset IBD (given questionable history of blood in stools). 
Colon cancer or divertiulitis unlikely given recent colonoscopy 
with single sessile 8mm polyp of benign appearance. Narcotic 
withdrawal unlikely as patient reports stable dose of Fentanyl 
patch, and no other narcotic use recently. She is s/p 
appendectomy and cholecystectomy, with no nausea/vomiting to 
suggest partial bowel obstruction. No recent dietary changes to 
suggest new presentation of lactose intolerance or Celiac 
disease. We were unable to obtain a stool sample to pursue 
continued workup in the inpatient setting. 

# Back pain:
She had back pain on the morning of ___ which woke her from 
sleep. The pain radiated across her back and left shoulder, and 
she reported never having this type of pain before. Cardiac 
workup including EKG and troponin did not reveal evidence of 
cardiac ischemia. Amylase/lipase and AST/ALT/Tbili were in the 
normal range. Her back pain was felt to be most likely 
musculoskeletal in the setting of her recent fall.

# Weakness:
ESR was mildly elevated but not into the range typically 
concerning for polymyalgia rheumatica. CK normal. This symptom 
is most likely related to her known autonomic dysfunction. She 
was evaluated by Physical Therapy and found to be at high fall 
risk. Rehabilitation was recommended, to which patient agreed.

# UTI: She had marginal Dipstick/UA but did report urinary 
frequency. She received ciprofloxacin x3 days (first day was 
___ for empiric treatment of UTI.

CHRONIC ISSUES:
# Ankle swelling:
Chronic. She had ECHO on ___ with elongated left atrium, normal 
left ventricular size, LVEF>55%. Abnormal septal 
motion/position, moderate pulmonary artery systolic hypertension 
were noted. Her albumin is normal, total protein very mildly low 
(6.3). DVT was thought to be unlikely given edema is bilateral.

# Postural instability:
She has known autonomic dysfunction followed by neurology. She 
did have history of recent fall, but did not hurt her head.

# T2DM: On bedtime 25 glargine and humalog sliding scale at 
home. Poorly controlled at baseline. She was seen by ___ 
here, and subsequently we increased her nighttime glargine and 
sliding scale.

# Chronic pain:
- Continued Fentanyl Patch 100 mcg/h TD Q72H 

# Dementia:
- Continued Memantine 5 mg PO BID 
- Continued Donepezil 10 mg PO HS 

# Depression:
- Continued Sertraline 200 mg PO DAILY 

# Seizure disorder:
- Continued Gabapentin 300 mg PO BID 

# CAD:
- Continued Isosorbide Mononitrate (Extended Release) 30 mg PO 
DAILY 
- Continued Aspirin, Atorvastatin, Clopidogrel

# GERD: 
- Received Omeprazole 40 mg daily (on esomeprazole at home)

# Glaucoma:
- Continued Travatan Z (travoprost) 0.004 % ophthalmic QPM to 
left eye
- Continued eye drops

TRANSITION ISSUES:
- She had no episodes of diarrhea during her admission. If this 
problem recurs in the outpatient setting she can have outpatient 
diarrhea workup.
- Continue neurology outpatient follow-up for leg weakness.
- Metoprolol was held at last admission and continued to be held 
given history of falls and dizziness. She may need to be 
restarted on this medication if appropriate in the outpatient 
setting.
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list may be inaccurate and requires 
futher investigation.

Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
possible viral syndrome

Secondary:
DMII uncontrolled with autonomic dysfunction

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

It was a pleasure being part of your care at ___. You were 
admitted to the hospital due to diarrhea. You did not have any 
diarrhea in the hospital, but you did experience back pain which 
was new for you. We underwent workup including cardiac enzymes, 
EKGs and pancreatic/liver enzymes, which did not reveal any 
evidence that dysfunction of the heart, pancreas or liver was 
causing your pain. Your pain improved over the course of your 
admission. You were also found to have a possible urinary tract 
infection, and you were treated with 3 days of antibiotics. You 
were also seen by the ___ diabetes specialists who made 
recommendations regarding your hospital insulin regimen. 

Because you were found to be unsteady on your feet with a high 
fall risk, rehabilitation was recommended and you agreed. We 
hope that their exercises will improve your strength and 
stability. 

Thank you for allowing us to be part of your care. Please ensure 
that you keep your existing medical follow-up appointments 
(details below).
 
Followup Instructions:
___

___ yo F with history of StageIIIa L breast ca, ER positive s/p

.
Recently, the patient has been refusing to see doctors ___ 
anxiety surrounding her diagnosis. The patient has not kept 
follow up appointments for several months. She is unable to 
acknowledge that she has metastatic breast ca, and does not wish 
to talk about it. She has refused further imaging. 
.
Per her daughter, for several months patient has had increasing 
back pain. On ___ patient presented to the ___ ED and w 1d 
extreme low back pain.  She had a CT scan that showed extensive 
lytic process of the sacrum, iliac bones, and lower spine with 
cortical breakthrough. There was attenuation of a soft tissue 
mass extending slightly through the cortical defects. Findings 
were highly concerning for metastatic disease. She was 
discharged w Tylenol 3 qHS. 
.
The results were discussed with her daughter ___, but results 
were not discussed with the patient, at the family's request. 
She had an appointment to follow up with her oncologist but did 
not keep that appointment. 
.
She is now being admitted from home for expidited work up of 
lower back mass including pain control, biopsy, and radiation 
oncology consult. 
.

Past Oncologic History:
___: Patient palpated lump in upper outer quadrant of her L 
breast while showering. Mammogram confirmed a palpable mass in 
the L breast -showed large, irregular, spiculated mass 
containing microcalcifications approximately 2-3cm. In addition, 
there was a dense enlarged lymph node in the L axilla.  No 
abnormalities in the R breast. US of the L breast revealed a 
large irregular shadowing mass at approximately 1 o'clock 
position measuring 2.5 x1.5x1.7cm. Exam of the L axilla revealed 
an iniltrative type of lymph node measuring 1.4 x 0.9 x 1.5cm. 
She underwent a core biopsy of the L breast mass and an FNA of 
the L axillary lymph node. Pathology showed an invasive ductal 
carcinoma, involving all 4 cores, at least 1cm. Tumor was 
moderately differentiated (grade II/III); no DCIS component, no 
LVI. Tumor was ER/PR strongly positive and her-2-neu negative 
(1+ IHC). FNA of the lymph node was suspicious for malignancy. 
Underwent lumpectomy with axillary sampling on ___ by Dr. 
___. Final pathology showed an invasive ductal carcinoma, 
2.6cm, well differentiated, grade I. EIC positive. LV1 present. 
Close margin anterior focally. There is DCIS present. Solid 
cribiform papillary and micropapillary of intermediate grade 
with central necrosis was noted. This was in 5 of 9 blocks. 
There was a close medial margin. Of 9 axillary nodes sampled, 
six were positive for metastatic disease. The largest focus was 
0.9cm, some positive lymph nodes are matted. Extranodal 
extension was present. AJCC classification, T2P N2A M0. ER/PR 
positive, Her-2/neu weakly positive. Completed XRT ___ with ___ 
___ at ___. Received total of ___ planned treatments, last 
one not given due to pt developing afib requiring overnight 
hospitalization. Began Femara ___. 
___ -Pt lost to f/u for over one year. Returned in ___ with 
rising Ca ___.  CT scans did not show evidence of metastatic 
disease. Pt refused bone scan.

refused bone scan. Refused PET scan.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo man with alcoholic cirrhosis, known esophageal varices 
admitted with melena and emesis.  The patient was 
hemodynamically stable throughout his admission.  He had no 
further episodes of melena during this hospital course.  The 
patient was initially maintained with two large bore IVs with a 
plan to transfuse for a hematocrit less than 28.  He had an EGD 
which did not demonstrate any actively bleeding lesions.  

The patient was actively drinking prior to admission.  Although 
he denied a history of withdrawal seizures he was tachycardic, 
hypertensive and nauseated on admission. He was maintained on a 
q2 hour CIWA scale, with decreasing benzo requirements 
throughout his admission.  The patient was also maintained on 
thiamine, folate and a multivitamin.  His clonidine was 
discontinued on admission and restarted once the patient was 
called out to the floor.  

The patient has a coagulopathy secondary to his chronic 
cirrhosis.  His disease is secondary to ETOH with HCC, and he is 
followed by Dr. ___. His disease is complicated by portal 
hypertension, hypertensive gastropathy, esophageal varices s/p 
banding and melena in the past, as well as ascites, 
thrombocytopenia, anemia, and coagulopathy.  His medications 
were initially held but once it was clear the patient was not 
actively bleeding, his nadolol, furosemide, spironolactone and 
lactulose were restarted.

The patient had a stable thrombocytopenia.  He did receive FFP 
prior to a planned RFA for three liver lesions.  The procedure 
went well and the patient was discharged the following day.

The patient was continued on his outpatient pain regimen of 
Neurontin and a lidocaine patch.  

He also had a chronic stable anemia which was macrocytic, likely 
multifactorial given GIB, EtOH use and liver disease. Vitamin 
B12 ___, folate 11.8 ___.  
  
The patient was a full code throughout this admission.  
Communication was as follow: mother ___ (HCP) ___, 
Partner ___ ___, (c) ___.

Pt poor historian, unable to verify meds  
Clonidine 0.1 mg PO TID  
Fluticasone 50 mcg/Actuation Nasal BID  
Folic Acid 1 mg PO DAILY  
Furosemide 40 mg PO DAILY  
Gabapentin 300 mg PO Q8H  
Lactulose 10 gram/15 mL ThirtyML PO four times a day - only 
takes when constipated  
Nadolol 40 mg PO DAILY  
Pantoprazole 40 mg PO Q24H - states bid  
Ferrous Sulfate 325 mg PO DAILY  
Hexavitamin PO DAILY - not likely taking  
Thiamine HCl 100 mg PO DAILY  
Lidocaine 5 %(700 mg/patch) Topical DAILY  
Spironolactone 100 mg PO DAILY  
Nicotine 21 mg/24 hr Transdermal DAILY

8 hours).

times a day).

(1) Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO Q24H (every 24 hours).

You were admitted to the hospital with concern for 
gastrointestinal bleeding.  While you were in the hospital, you 
had an EGD which did not demonstrate any actively bleeding 
vessels.  

You also had radiofrequency ablation of the lesions in your 
liver.  Your blood counts have been stable since your admission 
to the hospital.

Please take all of your medications as prescribed.  Please call 
your physician or come to the emergency room with anyfevers, 
vomiting, blood in your stool or your vomit, confusion or other 
symptoms you find concerning.

Name:  ___                Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F

abdominal pain

History of Present Illness:
HPI: ___ w/ h/o anemia, PUD who presents with a multiple day
history of RUQ pain with bilious emesis this morning as well as
dark stool over the weekend. Her RUQ pain has been present since
at least ___ at which time she was admitted to an OSH with
similar complaints. At that time she underwent EGD which found a
non-bleeding gastric ulcer. RUQ US reportedly with findings of
cholecystitis for which she did not receive antibiotics.
Reportedly her pain improved after having a BM and she was
discharged to home with a PPI. She was taking a PPI for known
ulcer disease but was reportedly noncompliant. She was
subsequently admitted to medicine from ___ with similar RUQ
pain and US at that time found cholelithiasis w/o e/o
cholecystitis. She was discharged to home with plans for surgery
referral as an outpatient. Her pain is not associated with meals
and has been constant. She denies any fevers or chills.

 
Past Medical History:
as per last notes: confirmed with review of OMR

PMHx:  
- ___ syndrome- - diagnosed based genetic testing of son who
has ___. Characterized by minor facial dysmorphism 
(hypertelorism, downward eye slant, and low-set ears), 
proportionate short stature, and heart disease, short webbed 
neck, chest deformity (pectus excavatum), intellectual 
disability (mental retardation), bleeding diathesis, and 
lymphedema
- Presumed diagnosis of Factor V deficiency - s/p multiple
transfusions for asympomatic anemia and FFP for procedures.
Subsequent Factor V level WNL ___.
- Pulmonary stenosis 
- Congenital scoliosis with rod placed then later removed, 
received transfusion on removal 
- Anaemia
- h/o hypoglycemia treated with glucose boost
- h/o DUB given D+C, placed on progesterone, took for 12 months

PSHx:
- s/p Scoliosis surgery x 2 - rod placed in first procedure; it 
was
removed during the second procedure, required transfusion during
___ procedure.
- s/p C section for 1 child, later developed bleeding from wound 
requiring transfusion 
- s/p Lumpectomy of benign breast mass w/ FFP
- s/p D&C - ___ w/ FFP

Haematological history:
Patient initially with what was felt to be Factor V deficiency 
followed in the coagulation and ___ clinic by Dr 
___. She has a documented Factor V level of 11% on 
___. Since than she has received FFP prior to each 
procedure and the factor V level after FFP was documented at 114 
(___) and 96 (___). She was subsequently managed 
___ with FFP prior to D&C and breast biopsy. She 
also reported prolonged bleeding after tooth extraction, and 
heavy menstrual periods. She presented to an outside hospital 
abdominal pain in ___ and had unsuccessful attempt 
at venipuncture in left arm. She then developed left arm pain 
and she returned to outside hospital ___ where ultrasound 
showed LUE DVT. She was transferred to ___ and was seen by 
Hematology consultation service and Factor V level was within 
normal limits at 90%. 

She was initiated on anticoagulation with IV heparin which was 
transitioned to Lovenox, 80mg SC daily on discharge and returned 
to ED the subsequent day, ___, with vaginal bleeding and 
was hospitalized through ___. On ___ she had right upper 
extremity u/s which was notable for thrombus in one of right 
brachial veins, non-occlusive thrombus in right basilic vein. 
Possible thrombus in right subclavian vein. She was seen by 
Ob-GYN, who recommended ten days of PO progesterone, and she was 
discharged on lower dose Lovenox, 50mg SC daily and due to 
bleeding was tretaed for 4 weeks.

She has a previous hx of heavy menstrual periods, significant 
bleeding. She was last seen in clinic in ___

confirmed with patient
son with ___ and klinefelter

K-3.8 Cl-106 HCO3-23 AnGap-10

___:  gallbladder scan:

 Delayed uptake of tracer in the gallbladder, visualized between 
75 
and 105 minutes,  most compatible with chronic cholecystitis. 

___:  liver/gallbladder US;

 Distended gallbladder containing a 2.5 cm stone at the neck 
without 
additional evidence of cholecystitis.  A HIDA scan may be 
helpful for further evaluation if clinically indicated.  
  
2.  Splenomegaly.   

___: US bil. leg veins:

  No evidence of deep vein thrombosis in bilateral lower 
extremities. 
  

  

  

 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with right upper 
quadrant pain and bilious emesis.  She had been worked up at an 
outside hospital for cholelithiasis and ulcer disease.   On 
ultrasound she was reported to have a stone in the neck of the 
gallbladder.  The surgery service was consulted and the patient 
underwent a HIDA scan which showed signs of chronic 
cholecystitis.  Based on these findings, the patient was taken 
to the operating room on HD #3, where she underwent a 
laparoscopic cholecystectomy.  Operative findings were notable 
for inflammation of the gallbladder wall.  The operative course 
was stable with minimal blood loss.  The patient was extubated 
after the procedure and monitored in the recovery room.

During the post-operative course, the patient initially had 
difficulty voiding and she was straight-cathed once for 300cc 
urine.  The patient subsequently voided without difficulty.  She 
was started on clear liquids and advanced to a regular diet.  
Her pain was controlled with oral analgesia. On the 
post-operative assessment, the patient reported right calf pain 
and underwent an ultra-sound of her lower extremities which were 
negative for DVTs.  The patient's vital signs remained stable 
and she was afebrile.  The patient was discharged home on POD 1 
in stable condition. Appointments for follow were made with the 
acute care service and with her primary care provider.         
 
Medications on Admission:
. Pantoprazole 40 mg PO Q12H  
2. Senna 8.6 mg PO BID:PRN constipation  
3. Topiramate (Topamax) 25 mg PO DAILY  
4. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen (5mg-325mg) ___ TAB PO Q6H:PRN Pain  

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain  
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
3. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  5 mg PO Q4H:PRN pain  
4. Pantoprazole 40 mg PO Q24H 
5. Topiramate (Topamax) 25 mg PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
cholecystitis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with right upper 
quadrant pain. An ultrasound of the gallbladder showed 
gallstones. You were taken to the operating room to have your 
gallbladder removed.  You are slowly recovering from your 
surgery and you are  now preparing for discharge home with the 
following instructions:  

 You were admitted to the hospital with acute cholecystitis. You 
were taken to the operating room and had your gallbladder 
removed laparoscopically. You tolerated the procedure well and 
are now being discharged home to continue your recovery with the 
following instructions.
Please follow up in the Acute Care Surgery clinic at the 
appointment listed below.
ACTIVITY:
 
Do not drive until you have stopped taking pain medicine and 
feel you could respond in an emergency.
You may climb stairs. 
You may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until you 
see your surgeon at your next visit.
Don't lift more than ___ lbs for 4 weeks. (This is about the 
weight of a briefcase or a bag of groceries.) This applies to 
lifting children, but they may sit on your lap.
You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable.
You will need to stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools for a 
time while your incision is healing. Ask your doctor when you 
can resume tub baths or swimming.
 
HOW YOU MAY FEEL: 
You may feel weak or "washed out" for a couple of weeks. You 
might want to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you.
You may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your 
throat during surgery.
You might have trouble concentrating or difficulty sleeping. You 
might feel somewhat depressed.
You could have a poor appetite for a while. Food may seem 
unappealing.
All of these feelings and reactions are normal and should go 
away in a short time.  If they do not, tell your surgeon.
 
YOUR INCISION:
Tomorrow you may shower and remove the gauzes over your 
incisions. Under these dressing you have small plastic bandages 
called steristrips. Do not remove steri-strips for 2 weeks. 
(These are the thin paper strips that might be on your 
incision.) But if they fall off before that that's okay).
Your incisions may be slightly red around the stitches. This is 
normal.
You may gently wash away dried material around your incision.
Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area.
Do not use any ointments on the incision unless you were told 
otherwise.
You may see a small amount of clear or light red fluid staining 
your dressing or clothes. If the staining is severe, please call 
your surgeon.
You may shower. As noted above, ask your doctor when you may 
resume tub baths or swimming.
 
YOUR BOWELS:
Constipation is a common side effect of narcotic pain 
medicaitons. If needed, you may take a stool softener (such as 
Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as milk of 
magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. You can get both of these 
medicines without a prescription.
If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain moving 
the bowels, call your surgeon. 
 
PAIN MANAGEMENT:
It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following abdominal 
surgery. This pain is often described as "soreness". 
Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain is 
getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon.
You will receive a prescription for pain medicine to take by 
mouth. It is important to take this medicine as directed. Do not 
take it more frequently than prescribed. Do not take more 
medicine at one time than prescribed.
Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before your 
pain gets too severe.
Talk with your surgeon about how long you will need to take 
prescription pain medicine. Please don't take any other pain 
medicine, including non-prescription pain medicine, unless your 
surgeon has said its okay.
If you are experiencing no pain, it is okay to skip a dose of 
pain medicine.
Remember to use your "cough pillow" for splinting when you cough 
or when you are doing your deep breathing exercises.
If you experience any of the following, please contact your 
surgeon:
- sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours
- pain that is getting worse over time
- pain accompanied by fever of more than 101
- a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain
 
MEDICATIONS:
Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just as 
you did before, unless you have been told differently.
If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not to 
take, please call your surgeon.
 
DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your surgeon if you develop:
- worsening abdominal pain
- sharp or severe pain that lasts several hours
- temperature of 101 degrees or higher
- severe diarrhea
- vomiting
- redness around the incision that is spreading
- increased swelling around the incision
- excessive bruising around the incision
- cloudy fluid coming from the wound
- bright red blood or foul smelling discharge coming from the 
wound
- an increase in drainage from the wound

History of Present Illness:
The patient is a ___ male with PMHx of hypertension, 
hyperlipidemia, gout, potential sleep apnea who presents to the 
ED with substernal chest pain that moves in a diagonal direction 
toward his left shoulder with one episode of noted left jaw pain 
and numbness in the left arm. He has had persistent dyspnea on 
exertion and intermittent left-sided sharp chest pain for the 
last 3 days. Denies pleuritic component, has had a cough for the 
last week, no fevers or chills. Was seen at urgent care where he 
received full aspirin, nitroglycerin in route prior to arrival 
given EKG changes from previous with now anterior TWIs. 
Currently describes chest tightness trending toward pain and no 
SOB at rest but endorses with movement. Negative ROS for 
orthopnea, PND, N/V, changes in BM or urination, does endorse 
difficulty climbing stairs for several days.
 
Past Medical History:

got sleep study, does not seem amenable to CPAP), 
musculoskeletal pain at knees.

___ ECHO
IMPRESSION: Normal left ventricular cavity size with regional 
systolic dysfunction c/w CAD (PDA distribution). Right 
ventricular cavity dilation with hypokinesis of the basal ___ 
of the free wall.
This constellation of findings is suggestive of CAD (proximal 
RCA distribution) or focal myocarditis.

___ RIGHT AND LEFT CATH
 1. Normal coronary arteries.
 2. Normal right sided pressures with preserved CI.

___ CTA CHEST
IMPRESSION: 
1.  Large saddle emboli in both right and left pulmonary 
arteries, extending into the lobar branches. Imaging evidence of 
right heart strain with bowing of the interventricular septum 
toward the left. No pulmonary infarction.
 
2.  Left upper lobe nodular lesion measuring 9 mm. This may be 
infectious or inflammatory in nature, but recommend 3 month 
chest CT followup to ensure that this resolves.

___ BILAT LOWER EXTREMITY U/S
No DVT.

___ CT ABD/PELVIS 
IMPRESSION:
1. No evidence of malignancy in the abdomen or pelvis. However, 
routine CT is not sensitive for detecting colon cancer.
2. Pulmonary emboli still present in the imaged segmental 
branches of the
lower lobe arteries.
3. Diverticulosis without evidence of diverticulitis.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
BRIEF SUMMARY
=============
___ y/o M with h/o HTN, HLD, gout, potential OSA with 3 day 
history of malaise, loss of appetite, chest pain, and DOE p/w 
dynamic EKG changes concerning for ACS. Receied cath, which was 
negative, and subsequently had ECHO showing RH strain and CTA 
showing submassive PE.

ACTIVE ISSUES
===============
# SUBMASSIVE PULMONARY EMBOLISM: Patient presented with chest 
pain and dyspnea on exertion. The patient had negative trops x 3 
but elevated proBNP of 1199. He received TTE on ___ AM, which 
showed right ventricular strain with bowing of septum. Cardiac 
catheterization revealed PS systolic pressure of 45 and clean 
coronaries. The patient had Ddimer elevated to ___ and 
subsequent CTA showing bilateral pulmonary embolism. He was 
started on heparin gtt bridge to coumadin. Throughout his 
course, he remained hemodynamically stable. Bilateral ___ 
ultrasounds were negative for DVT. He received CT 
abdomen/pelvis, which showed no evidence of intrabdominal 
malignancy. His INR on discharge was 3.3 and he was discharged 
on 2 mg daily warfarin with follow-up with his PCP for repeat 
check on ___. He was also recommended to have anticoagulation 
work-up (his father has history of PE) and a colonoscopy. 

# RIGHT HEART STRAIN: Last stress test and ECHO were 5+ years 
ago and were reportedly normal. Anterior TWIs originally 
concerning for ACS but found to have PE as above. Due to initial 
concern for ACS, the patient was started on ACS regimen with 
high dose ASA, metoprolol, lisinopril, and high-dose statin. 
However, this was transitioned to home dose of ASA 81 mg, 
decreased atorastatin 20 mg daily, metoprolol succinate 25 mg 
XL, and home lisinopril 10 mg daily. 

CHRONIC ISSUES
==============
# GOUT: Patient has history of gout. He complained of left big 
toe pain consistent with prior gout flares. Given his 
anticoagulation regimen, the patient was instructed to avoid 
naproxen. He was started on colchicine as inpatient and 
discharged on 0.6 mg daily.

# HTN: stable. Patient was continued on home lisinopril 10 mg 
daily. As above, the patient was started on metoprolol succinate 
25 mg XL daily.

# HLD: stable. Patient was started on atorvastatin 80 mg daily 
in the setting of suspected ACS, but this was decreased to 
atorvastatin 20 mg daily at discharge. 

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
===================
- INR for warfarin dosage adjustments (goal ___. 
Supratherapeutic at 3.3 on day of discharge, being discharged on 
2 mg daily dose (decreased from 10 mg then 5 mg daily to 2 mg). 
Patient being discharged on ___, so could not confirm on day 
of discharge regarding ___ for ___. Attending Dr. 
___ to contact PCP ___. on ___ and patient 
to call PCP ___ ___. 
- Tests as above for hypercoagulable predisposition
- Colonoscopy
- Smokeless tobacco cessation
- Left upper lobe nodular lesion measuring 9 mm. This may be 
infectious or inflammatory in nature, but recommend 3 month 
chest CT followup to ensure that this resolves
- Patient was started on colchicine 0.6 mg for acute gout flare. 
Consider discontinuation of this medication once acute episode 
resolves.

when he is moving or tries to sit down. On imaging he was found 
to have a  7.1 x 12.6 x 14.9 cm right rectus sheath hematoma 
with surrounding fat stranding.  No evidence of active 
extravasation on this non-CTA study. Surgery is consulted for 
further management, and it was decided to admit the patient to 
the surgical ward for observation. After 2 days in the service 
the patient continued to improve and the pain was better 
controlled, and there was no extravasation of blood. He was CV 
stable, pulmonary stable and no signs of infections or DVT. At 
the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile and 
hemodynamically stable.  The patient was tolerating a diet, 
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The patient received discharge teaching and 
follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and 
agreement with the discharge plan.
 
Medications on Admission:
lisinopril, azithromycin (for known pneumonia)
 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q8H:PRN Pain - Mild  
2.  Azithromycin 500 mg PO Q24H  
3.  Lisinopril 20 mg PO DAILY  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Rectus sheath hematoma

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to ___ for a 
hematoma of your abdominal muscles after a coughing episode, you 
were admitted for serial abdominal exams and trending of your 
blood levels. You are recovering well and are now ready for 
discharge. Please follow the instructions below to continue your 
recovery:

Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.

*AVOID contact sports and/or any activity that may cause injury 
to your abdominal area for the next ___ weeks.
 
*If you suddenly become dizzy, lightheaded, feeling as if you 
are going to pass out go to the nearest Emergency Room as this 
could be a sign that you are having internal bleeding from your 
liver or spleen injury.
 
*AVOID any blood thinners such as Motrin, Naprosyn, Indocin, 
Aspirin, Coumadin or Plavix for at least ___ days unless 
otherwise instructed by the MD/NP/PA.

Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting 
weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your 
surgeon.
Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                      Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
C7 fracture with transaminitis 
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none
 
History of Present Illness:
___ HIV+, DM s/p fall from standing onto his chin and
hyperextended his neck.  Reportedly has full memory of the 
event, did
not lose consciousness but could not recall events overnight and 
does not have any complaints except for pain in the right hip. 
Originally presented to OSH, was noted to have a C7 fracture, 
and he was transferred to ___.  In the ambulanceon transfer, 
the patient had two grand mal seizures.  He does not have a 
history of seizure.  
He currently reports pain only "mild" in his neck and in his 
right hip, which he reports is chronic and "not worse" than 
before the fall.

 
Past Medical History:
PMH: DMII, HIV, HTN, anxiety  

PSH: R total hip, L knee surgery, CCY  

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
PHYSICAL EXAM ON ADMISSION:

VS - Temp afebrile, BP 136/79, HR 66, R 16, O2-sat 96% RA  
General: Alert, oriented but forgetful, NAD  
HEENT: PERRL, EOMI, Sclera anicteric, dry MMM, oropharynx clear, 
no petechiae  
Neck: ___ J collar - not further assessed  
Lungs: CTA ant/laterally (not turned ___ to logroll)  
CV: RRR, III/VI sys murmur heard best at the LUSB, no extra 
sounds  
Abdomen: +BS, soft, non-tender, distended ___ to habitus, no 
rebound tenderness or guarding, Non-pulsating hepatomegaly with 
liver edge extending 6cm below the costal border at the 
mid-clavicular line. Spleen tip difficult to palpate ___ to 
current patient positioning  
Ext: Warm, well perfused, 2+ pulses at DP and radial, no 
clubbing or edema  
Skin: No jaundice, No spider angiomas on chest, no petechiae 
seen, no palmar erythema  
Neuro: A&Ox2 (not sure about date - thought ___, also not 
sure about which exact hospital), CN grossly intact, sensation 
intact throughout, moving all extremities without deficit  

PHYSICAL EXAM ON DISCHARGE:

Neuro/Psych: A+Ox3 and less forgetful than on admission, 
numbness/tingling in C6 distribution on arm

 
Pertinent Results:
Lab Results on Admission:
___ 12:45AM BLOOD WBC-6.2 RBC-4.41* Hgb-14.8 Hct-42.7 
MCV-97 MCH-33.6* MCHC-34.7 RDW-14.4 Plt Ct-82*
___ 03:58AM BLOOD Neuts-69.3 ___ Monos-6.5 Eos-0.4 
Baso-0.1

___ 12:45AM BLOOD ___ 12:45AM BLOOD UreaN-13 Creat-0.7
___ 03:58AM BLOOD Glucose-127* UreaN-10 Creat-0.5 Na-139 
K-3.2* Cl-108 HCO3-25 AnGap-9

Bnzodzp-NEG Barbitr-NEG Tricycl-NEG

Cl-103 calHCO3-20*
___ 05:30PM BLOOD Lactate-0.9

Studies: 
___ CT Torso: Partially imaged fx of C7 rt transverse process 
Scoliosis of the lumbar spine. Mild retrolisthesis so L5 on S1 - 
likely degenerative. No acute spine fracture. Right hip 
prosthesis: no evidence of hardward failure or loosening. No 
dislocation. Equivocal focal area of discontinuity along the 
anterior right acetabulum - likely do to streak artifact, though 
given the clinical hx of severe right hip pain - small fracture 
cannot be excluded.

___ Trauma X-ray chest and abdomen: IMPRESSION:
1. Mild pulmonary vascular congestion, though no overt edema or 
effusions.
2. Right hip total arthroplasty in standard position. Please see 
concurrent
CT torso report for details. 

___ CT CHEST ABDOMEN and PELVIS with CONTRAST: IMPRESSION:
1. Partially imaged non-displaced fracture of the right 
transverse process of C7.
2. Scoliosis of the lumbar spine with degenerative changes 
including mild
retrolisthesis of L5 on S1. However, no acute fracture of the 
thoracolumbar
spine.
3. No evidence of hardware loosening, dislocation, or fracture 
at the site of right hip arthroplasty.
4. Lobulated liver contour with splenomegaly and collateral 
vasculature,
findings suggesting underlying chronic liver disease with some 
degree of
portal hypertension.
5. 13 x 16-mm hypoattenuating lesion within the pancreatic body, 
possibly a
pancreatic cystic lesion such as an IPMN or a small adjacent 
lymph node.
Further characterization with MRCP should be considered if 
clinically
indicated.
6. Sigmoid diverticulosis without evidence of acute 
diverticulitis.

___ CT HEAD: IMPRESSION:
1. No evidence of mass, edema, mass effect, or evidence of 
herniation.
2. Evaluation for intracranial hemorrhage is limited due to the
administration of intravenous contrast.
3. Fluid level in the left maxillary sinus without evidence of 
fracture.
However, if there is concern for acute facial bone fracture, 
dedicated CT
could be considered.

___ ECG: Baseline artifact. Sinus bradycardia. Borderline P-R 
interval prolongation. Left ventricular hypertrophy by voltage. 
No previous tracing available for comparison. Clinical 
correlation is suggested. 

___ CTA neck: IMPRESSION:
1. Fracture of right transverse process of C7 with no associated 
vascular
injury.
2. Multilevel degenerative changes of the cervical spine.

___ MR HEAD without contrast: IMPRESSION: Technically limited 
MRI study. Only limited sequences could be obtained which were 
degraded by motion artifacts. Fluid signal seen within the left 
maxillary, ethmoid, and sphenoid sinuses. A repeat MRI is 
suggested after adequately sedating the patient.

___ TTE: IMPRESSION: No structural cardiac cause of syncope 
identified. Preserved global and regional biventricular systolic 
function. No structural valvular abnormality. No resting or 
inducible LVOT obstruction. Biatrial dilation.

Brief Hospital Course:
PRIMARY REASON FOR HOSPITALIZATION: Patient is a ___ yo man with 
HIV on HAART therapy (last CD4 377 and VL neg on ___, DMII, 
and early cirrhosis (thought EtOH) who was admitted to ___ 
after he slipped on a dog pillow at home and was found to have 
C7 fracture. On transfer from OSH, patient had 2 seizures in the 
ambulance ride over. These were felt to possibly be 
post-traumatic vs. benzodiazepine withdrawal seizures and no 
further episodes occurred. In house, his head was imaged with CT 
showing no acute bleed, and neck CTA confirmed C7 fracture and 
no vascular injury. He was discharged with instructions to wear 
a ___ J-Collar and ___ in 6 weeks at the ___.  
. 
ACUTE CARE:
. 
1. C7 Fracture: Patient sustained a C7 vertebral fracture 
following a fall at home. He has mild tingling in the right 
first and second digit extending up in a band up his arm and 
otherwise asymptomatic. Imaging confirmed the non-displaced 
fracture with no associated vascular injury. He was discharged 
with ___ J-Collar and ___ appointment in 6 weeks in the 
___.
.  
2. Fall at home: Patient reports having tripped over an object 
on the ground as the precipitating factor for his fall. This 
would seem to be a purely mechanical fall, but other etiologies 
were considered. Patient did have 2 seizures on the way to ___ 
from OSH, and these were ultimately felt to be benzodiazepine 
withdrawal seizures as patient had stopped taking his standing 
lorazepam. It was felt unlikely that seizure caused fall as he 
remembered the event and no one witnessed convulsions. 
Arrhythmia was felt unlikely as patient's EKG showed no rhythm 
abnormality. Echo showed no valvular disease that could 
contribute to fall. In the end fall was felt to be mechanical 
and patient was discharged with instructions to take lorazepam 
as prescribed by outside provider.
.
3. Seizures: Patient had two 60-90sec self-resolving generalized 
tonic-clonic seizures on transport from OSH to ___. He has no 
prior seizure hx. These were felt to be post-traumatic vs. 
benzodiazepine withdrawal seizures as patient had recently 
stopped taking his scheduled lorazepam as prescribed. Initially 
keppra was loaded but d/c'd once acute intracranial pathology 
was ruled out and patient's scheduled lorazepam restarted. He 
had no further seizure episodes and was discharged with standing 
BID lorazepam.
.
4. Lower Back Pain: Patient experienced exacerbation of his 
chronic lower back/right hip pain following fall. He had no 
neurologic deficits in sensation or strength. His spine was 
cleared by neurosurgery and he was taken off logroll precautions 
which were initially started. Pain was managed with with 
dilaudid and he was transitioned to his home oxycodone dose for 
pain control.
.  
5. Elevated AST/ALT/Tbili:  
Seems to be at baseline. The patient has multiple medications 
that could be cause elevated transaminases, but the differential 
for AST/ALT ratio greater than 1 is small and includes the 
possibilty of cirrhosis vs EtOH. Imaging shows hepatomegaly and 
splenomegaly with past CTs indicating early cirrhosis and INR 
1.5 with Alb 2.9 making cirrhosis most likey. Tbili elevation 
likely due to protease inhibitor and is at chronic baseline. ___ 
have had a recent alcohol induced insult as AST/ALT from ___ 
at PCP ___ 206/116 but current alcohol screen negative.  
.  
6. Elevated Lipase:  
Patient asymptomatic, but found to have hypodense mass in the 
pancreas concerning for IPMN. Unclear if this has been worked up 
in the past. Also possible that recent alcohol use (which bumped 
AST on ___ lead to mild pancreatitis and now seeing lipase 
down-trend. D/C summary to be faxed to PCP for ___  
. 
CHRONIC CARE: 
1. Splenomegaly:  
Most likely cause is liver disease with cirrhosis. Possible that 
HIV may be contributing. Seems to be stable finding per outside 
CT from ___. 
.  
2. Thrombocytopenia:  
At baseline (50-90k). No smear on record. Most likely ___ to 
sequstration from splenic enlargement in setting of cirrhosis.  
.  
3. Hear Murmur:  
No records here on record although the patient says that he has 
been told this in the past. Would defer further management to 
his outpatient provider.  
.  
4. DMII:  
No A1C in records here. Just on Glyburide 5mg BID as outpatient. 
Blood sugars reasonably well controlled since admit on ISS alone 
but not eating. Glyburide restarted on discharge 
.  
5. HTN: On lisinopril + Atenolol as outpt. Briefly managed on IV 
metoprolol but transitioned to home meds with good BP control on 
discharge.
.  
6. Anxiety: Carries dx and was on paroxetine + lorazepam at home 
for this. Not on either since admit. Restarted both before 
discharge
.  
7. HIV:  
Well controlled on Truvada + boosted Darunavir. CD4 377 with VL 
neg. Home meds were continued.
.
TRANSITIONS IN CARE:
1. CODE STATUS: Presumed full
2. MEDICATION CHANGES: no changes made in patient's medications. 
He was told he can choose to discontinue zolpidem QHS
3. ___ APPOINTMENTS: Patient is to ___ with his PCP 
and orthopedics on discharge. Appointments were made for him and 
he was instructed to keep them
4. CT FINDINGS: An incidental finding of a lesion concerning for 
Intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm was made on CT scan. 
This should be followed up with patient's PCP on discharge. D/C 
summary and CT report faxed to PCP.
 
Medications on Admission:
atenolol 50', glyburide 5'', lidoderm patch, lisinopril 10', 
norvir 100', oxycodone 5' lorazepam 1'', truvada 200-300HS, 
paroxetine 10mg', ambien 10mg', Prezista 400mg''  

 
Discharge Medications:
1. lorazepam 1 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a 
day): do not drive or operate machinery while taking this 
medication.  
2. lisinopril 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  

3. glyburide 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a 
day).  
4. atenolol 50 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  
5. emtricitabine-tenofovir 200-300 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet 
PO DAILY (Daily).  
6. darunavir 400 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a 
day).  
7. ritonavir 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
8. paroxetine HCl 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a 
day.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary: 
1. C7 vertebral body fracture.
2. seizures
Secondary:
1. Transaminitis, chronic
2. HIV
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

It was a pleasure taking part in your care. You were admitted to 
the hospital following a fall at home. You fractured your C7 
vertebrae and lost consciousness. You also had 2 seizures on the 
way to the hospital. We found that you did not have a bleed in 
the head, and there were no abnormalities when we looked at your 
heart valves. The seizures were likely from not taking 
lorazepam, and this is a medication you should take as 
prescribed.

Please do not make any changes to your medications, but take as 
prescribed. You may discontinue the zolpidem.

You will need to keep the neck collar on for ___ weeks. You 
will also need to follow up with the ___ in 6 weeks. 
You should follow up with your PCP ___ ___ days for suture 
removal.

Please keep all ___ appointments.

Please avoid taking medications with NSAIDs such as naproxen, 
ibuprofen, and aspirin. You may take up to 2gm of acetaminophen 
daily for pain, but no more for risk of liver damage.

Please make a ___ appointment with your gastroenterologist 
within 2 weeks of discharge.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Name:  ___               Unit ___:   ___

Dyspnea

History of Present Illness:
As per admitting MD
___ is a ___ year old woman with COPD and recurrent
serous ovarian cancer along with recent admission to BID-N for 
PE
and pneumonitis who is admitted from the ED with persistent
dyspnea and hypoxia.

Patient developed increasing dry cough with associate dyspnea on
exertion and occasional nocturnal dyspnea approximately ___ 
weeks
ago. She has ___ known fevers or chills. ___ URTI symptoms. She
notes occasional headaches. She has central pleuritic chest
discomfort. ___ N/V/D and normal BM. ___ new leg pain or swelling
and ___ new rashes. Notably, she restarted smoking about 3 weeks
ago.

She was admitted from ___ to ___ at BID-N for the symptoms and
found to have a PE. She was also noted to have possible
pneumonitis at the time. She was started on Lovenox. She was 
seen
yesterday at ___ clinic and noted to desaturate with
exertion and she was started on steroids given concern for
pneumonitis. She returned to her ___ clinic today with
hypoxia with saturations in the mid ___ in room air. Repeat CTA
showed the previously nonocclusive thrombus in a subsegmental
right upper lobe pulmonary artery which has decreased in size. 
___
new pulmonary embolism was seen. Labs at BID-N pertinent for
negative troponin and normal BNP. Given persistent hypoxia,
transferred here for further eval and admission.

In the ED, initial VS were pain 1, T 97.8, HR 82, BP 110/68, RR
18, O2 97%2LNC. Labs notable for WBC 7.5, HCT 31.9, PLT 164, Na
136, K 4.0, HCO3 29, Cr 0.5, ALT 16, AST 28, ALP 177, Trop 
<0.01.
UA negative. Second trop negative and INR 1.3. Patient was given
duonebs, fuaifenesin-codeine, and oxycodone. VS prior to 
transfer
were pain 2, HR 73, BP 125/71, RR 16, O2 96%2LNC.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: 
A complete 10-point review of systems was performed and was
negative unless otherwise noted in the HPI.

 
Past Medical History:
As per admitting MD
PAST ONCOLOGIC HISTORY:
She had imaging suggestive of carcinomatosis with complex solid
and cystic ovarian masses as well as elevated CA125 to 354. On
___, she underwent a diagnostic laparoscopy converted to
total abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy,
omentectomy, abdominopelvic lymph node dissection, plasma jet
ablation of right diaphragm tumor, and rectosigmoid resection
with reanastomosis. Intraoperative findings were notable for a
10cm omental cake, 7cm left ovary and 6cm right ovary, diffuse
bilateral cul-de-sac and bladder peritoneal infiltrative tumor
plaques, and miliary tumor nodules on the right diaphragm. There
was ___ evidence of pelvic or paraaortic
lymphadenopathy and ___ residual disease at the end of  the
procedure.  

Final pathology showed high grade ovarian serous carcinoma with
parenchymal involvement and with metastasis to the fallopian
tube, uterine serosa, and omentum.  ___ lymph nodes were
involved. Lymphovascular invasion was present. Peritoneal
washings were positive.

She commenced with ___ Taxol on ___.  Completed six cycles
___.

New pelvic pain in late ___ - CA125 elevated 
and
scan confirms recurrent disease

- ___ C1 ___ c/b thrombocytopenia 13k requiring
transfusion
- ___ C2 ___ with GCSF (day 8 omitted), delayed 1
week due to neutropenia
- ___  C3 D1 ___ with coughing
/flushing; 
received Benadryl, Pepcid, solu-cortef.  Closely monitored with
nice recovery.
- ___  Allergy consulted and recommended in patient
desensitization.
