Imaging:
TTE ___:
Mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity 
size and regional/global biventricular systolic function. Mild 
aortic regurgitation with normal valve morphology.High normal 
pulmonary artery systolic pressure. Mild mitral regurgitation 
with normal valvemorphology.
Compared with the prior TTE (images not available for review) of 
___, the findings are similar.

___ CTA Chest (BID-N)
1. Previously seen nonocclusive thrombus in a subsegmental right
upper lobe pulmonary artery has decreased compared to ___ with minimal linear thrombus remaining.  ___ new pulmonary
embolism is seen.
2. Mediastinal lymphadenopathy is stable compared to ___, though slightly progressed compared to ___.
3. Evaluation of the lungs is substantially limited by motion
artifact.  Advanced combined emphysema pulmonary fibrosis
interstitial lung disease is again demonstrated.  Reassessment 
of
ground-glass opacities is limited due to motion artifact. 
Evaluation for pulmonary nodules is also limited by motion
artifact.
4. Splenomegaly is again noted.

___ CTA Chest (BID-N)
1. Subsegmental right upper lobe anterior segment pulmonary
embolus without evidence of heart strain or pulmonary 
infarction.
2. Slightly increased ground-glass opacities and pulmonary
fibrosis.  Ground glass is not specific and could be seen with
edema, inflammation or infection, versus worsening interstitial
disease with active pneumonitis.
3. Moderate to severe centrilobular emphysema.
4. Nonspecific minimal increase in size of two mediastinal lymph
nodes.  Other enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes are unchanged.
5. Previously seen solid pulmonary nodules are ___ longer readily
identifiable.
6. Splenomegaly measuring at least 14 cm, minimally enlarged
since the prior examination.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ ___ COPD and recurrent serous ovarian cancer with recent 
admission to BID-N for PE/pneumonitis, now re-admitted with 
persistent dyspnea/hypoxia, whose workup was suggestive of 
pneumonitis, etiology remains unclear, but patient improved on 
oral steroids so was discharged on slow pred taper with close 
outpatient pulmonary/oncology followup. 

# Acute hypoxic respiratory failure
# Interstitial lung disease
# Pneumonitis
# COPD
Her imaging, exam, and history were concerning for a primary 
pulmonary process, likely drug induced pneumonitis (unclear 
causative agent). Her PE had nearly resolved per imaging and was 
likely not contributing significantly. Recent reintroduction of 
tobacco use in setting of known COPD was likely contributing 
factor. Patient counseled extensively to quit smoking and 
offered tobacco cessation products but she declined. 

Flu negative but full viral panel was unable to be performed as 
sample was insufficient. BGlucan and Galatomannan ordered but 
remained pending at time of discharge and will need to be 
followed up by oncology/pulmonary teams. TTE performed given 
predominance of findings at lung bases but found normal LVEF 
mild AR/MR and high pulmonary pressures. 

Patient improved significantly on 80mg prednisone daily, and was 
able to be weaned off of O2. Cough improved as well, and patient 
was discharged on codeine for symptom control. As per pulmonary, 
plan is to decrease prednisone by 10mg daily each week, and f/u 
in pulmonary clinic for PFTs soon after discharge as serial PFTs 
will be trended in outpatient setting to determine response to 
therapy. She is to be on Bactrim for PCP ppx given prolonged 
course, already takes Prilosec so is covered for GI ppx

# Pulmonary embolus
Her PE had nearly resolved per imaging and was likely not 
contributing significantly to symptoms above. she was continued 
on home lovenox during stay.

# Recurrent stage IIIC ovarian cancer
Per Dr ___ notes, pt planned to switch to olaparib 
due to pneumonitis and PE; though initiation is to be delayed 
until pulmonary status significantly improves. Patient has close 
outpatient f/u already scheduled to make that determination. 

I personally spent 46 minutes preparing discharge paperwork, 
educating patient/family, answering questions, and coordinating 
care with outpatient providers

___: Codeine was needed for cough as 
non-narcotic medications were not potent enough to control 
symptoms.

This patient was prescribed, or continued on, an opioid pain 
medication at the time of discharge (please see the attached 
medication list for details). As part of our safe opioid 
prescribing process, all patients are provided with an opioid 
risks and treatment resource education sheet and encouraged to 
discuss this therapy with their outpatient providers to 
determine if opioid pain medication is still indicated.

Hypoxia ___ Pneumonitis possibly ___ chemotherapy
Cough
Recurrent Ovarian Cancer
Tobacco abuse

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Ms ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you while you were hospitalized 
at ___. As you know, you were admitted for shortness of breath 
and were found to have inflammation of the lungs called 
pneumonitis. It is unclear what caused it, possibly 
chemotherapy, but was certainly worsened by your cigarette 
smoking. 

You need to be sure to quit smoking, your life depends on it!!!

Fortunately, you improved with steroids and will continue them 
on discharge. You will start with 80mg daily for another 5 days, 
then decrease by 10mg every week until you see Dr ___. He 
will then determine how fast the remaining taper should be. To 
prevent a fungal infection while on steroids you will need to 
take Bactrim every day. Dr ___ will contact you to set up 
pulmonary function tests which will be trended over time. 

Dr ___ determine when you are to restart treatment for 
your cancer.

Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE

Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
SOB
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none

 
History of Present Illness:
___ year-old woman with past medical history significant for 
vertebral artery aneurysm, anxiety/depression who presents from 
___ ICU for newly diagnosed PE. She had been having ___ 
weeks of progressive dyspnea on exertion, worsening over last 
weekend with palpitations. She saw her PCP twice last week -- 
CXR showed linear atelectasis without other significant 
findings. No history of travel, recent surgeries, infection, 
clotting disorders. Work-up in ED on ___ notable for elevated 
D-dimer, followed by CTA showing saddle PE. She was admitted to 
the ICU. Work-up in ___ also notable for trop 
<0.01, pro-BNP 1268 -> 1091. EKG with SR @ 73 bpm. TWI in V1-V2. 
No ST changes. PR 200. TTE with LVEF 65%. Markedly enlarged RV 
and moderately reduced RV systolic function. Flattened 
interventricuular septum in systole consistent with RV pressure 
overload. Mildly dilated RA. Trace mitral regurgitation. Mild 
TR. Estimated RVSP increased at 58 mmHg. 

On transfer, vitals were: T 98.5 HR 86 RR 23 BP 121/67 98% on 
___ NC

On arrival to the MICU, the patient was on 2L NC with normal 
vitals, no shortness of breath, chest pain, fevers, pain, N/V/D, 
hemoptysis or extremity pain or swelling.

 
Past Medical History:
Vertebral artery aneurysm 7.5 mm
Anxiety and depression
Hypertension
GERD

___

Mother and uncle on mother's side with blood clots. Mother was 
___ yo and uncle was ___ yo and expired during anticoagulation for 
clot.

Vitals: T: 97.9  BP: 137/78 P: 77 R: 15 O2: 96% on 2L NC
GENERAL: Alert, oriented, no acute distress

rhonchi

gallops

rebound tenderness or guarding, no organomegaly 
GU: Foley in place
EXT: Warm, well perfused, 2+ pulses, no clubbing, cyanosis or 
edema, no tenderness to palpation 
SKIN: No lesions.
NEURO: A&O x3. CN II-XII intact. Sensation, strength intact. 
ACCESS: PIVs

VS:  98.0 PO 122 / 80 71 16 94 RA
Gen: kind but slightly anxious woman appearing her stated age in 
a hospital gown, NAD
HEENT: MMM, thyromegaly, no LAD in cervical or supraclavicular 
chains.
Pulm: lungs clear to auscultation posteriorly with mildly 
increased vesicular breath sounds
CV: heart sounds distant, rrr, no mrg appreciated
Abd: soft, distended abdomen w/o TTP in all 6 quadrants.
Ext: 1+ edema at the ankles b/l, no asymmetry noted. No erythema 
or cords palpated. TTP in middle posterior aspect of L calf. 
WWP, 2+ DP and ___ pulses. No skin lesions appreciated.
CNS: slightly anxious, conversational and cooperative with 
examiner. No facial droop; soft palate rises symmetrically. 
Grossly nonfocal.

IMAGING:
___ TTE: The left atrium and right atrium are normal in 
cavity size. Normal left ventricular wall thickness, cavity 
size, and regional/global systolic function (biplane LVEF = 62 
%). Doppler parameters are most consistent with normal left 
ventricular diastolic function. The right ventricular cavity is 
mildly dilated with normal free wall contractility. There is 
abnormal septal motion/position consistent with right 
ventricular pressure/volume overload. The number of aortic valve 
leaflets cannot be determined. There is no aortic valve 
stenosis. No aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve 
appears structurally normal with trivial mitral regurgitation. 
There is no mitral valve prolapse. The tricuspid valve leaflets 
are mildly thickened. Moderate [2+] tricuspid regurgitation is 
seen. There is severe pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. 
There is a very small pericardial effusion. 
 IMPRESSION: 
 1) Mildly dilated right ventricular function with normal RV 
size in setting of moderate to severe elevation of RV afterload 
and moderate tricuspid regurgitation.  

___ CTA HEAD NECK: 
IMPRESSION: 
1. No acute intracranial abnormality. 
2. Unchanged 5 x 3 mm aneurysm at the origin of the left ___. 
3. Otherwise patent intracranial vasculature without significant 
stenosis, 
occlusion, or new aneurysm. 
4. Patent cervical arterial vasculature without significant 
stenosis, 
occlusion, or dissection. 
5. Segmental and subsegmental bilateral upper lobe pulmonary 
emboli, as seen on the recent prior outside hospital chest CTA. 
6. 1 mm right apical pulmonary nodule. The ___ 
guidelines for pulmonary nodule guidelines suggest no follow-up 
needed in low-risk patients. 

DISCHARGE LABS
==============
___ 06:30AM BLOOD ___

___ 09:05AM BLOOD Free T4-1.___ year-old woman with past medical history significant for 
vertebral artery aneurysm, anxiety/depression who presented from 
___ ICU for newly diagnosed submassive pulmonary embolus.

#Pulmonary embolism: Symptoms x ___ weeks, submassive PE on OSH 
CTA, no obvious provoking factors, hx of smoking ~1 pack q3 
weeks, no new lesions on chest CT to suggest lung cancer, no 
vaginal bleeding, hematochezia, skin lesions, breast masses or 
drainage. Was initiated on heparin bolus and drip, then began 
bridge to Coumadin with Lovenox. This plan was confirmed with Dr 
___ in neurosurgery. TTE was obtained, e/o mild R heart 
strain, but vitals remained stable and wanted to avoid the use 
of tPA given ___ aneurysm. Initially required 4L NC, but weaned 
to RA, amb O2 sat at time of d/c was 92-96% on RA. Continue 
enoxaparin bridge to coumadin, with tentative plan for 3 month 
course pending outpatient hypercoagulable workup. PCP to manage 
INR (confirmed).

#Ascites: small amount noticed on CT scan, likely not enough to 
tap. Liver and spleen unremarkable on imaging, may be OB/GYN 
source. Has had w/u for unclear gyn pathology started as outpt, 
but not in ___ records. Discussed with patient and she plans 
to follow-up with her OB/GYN as outpt.

#Thyromegaly: Patient reports recent weight gain, constipation, 
hair loss, etc c/f hypothyroid. Enlarged thyroid gland on exam 
though TFTs wnl. Consider thyroid u/s as outpatient.

#HTN- sBPs 130-150s throughout admission. continued home 
propranolol. please monitor BPs as outpt, if persistently 
elevated consider adding or changing BP med regimen.

#Vertebral aneurysm- pt had normal neuro exam and no headache, 
vision changes, nausea or vomiting. CTA Head/Neck was obtained 
in anticipation of outpt f/u.

#HTN: continued home propranolol

#Anxiety and Depression: continued home Xanax and Effexor

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
- consider hypercoagulability workup in outpatient setting for 
___ unprovoked PE
- determine duration of anticoagulation based on w/u for 
malignancy, hypercoagulability
- will f/u with PCP ___ ___ for INR check
- 1mm apical pulmonary nodule. Consider f/u imaging given 
history of smoking. 
- outpt NSG f/u for ___ aneurysm (CTA head and neck obtained)
- outpt OB/GYN f/u for uterine biopsy and evaluation of ascites
- consider thyroid u/s for thyromegaly on exam
- mild hypertension this admission. Continue to monitor.
- added pantoprazole for GERD

Discharge Instructions:
Dear ___,

___ were admitted to the hospital due to difficulty breathing 
due to a blood clot in your lungs.

What was done during this hospitalization?
- We took a picture of your chest using a CT scan, which showed 
a blood clot in your lungs.
- We took pictures of your heart using ultrasound, which showed 
that the blood clot was making it more difficult for your heart 
to pump.
- We took a picture of your head and neck using a CT scan to 
evaluate your aneurysm in preparation for your next appointment 
with your neurosurgery team.
- We gave ___ oxygen and blood thinners for your blood clot: 
first with intravenous heparin, and now with injectable heparin 
(brand name ___ and warfarin (brand name ___.

What should ___ do now that ___ are leaving the hospital?
- It is important that ___ continue to take all of your 
medications as prescribed, including warfarin and injectable 
heparin (Lovenox). 
- ___ will continue to take injectable heparin (Lovenox) until 
your warfarin level is high enough.
- ___ will continue to take warfarin (brand name ___ for 
at least 3 months after leaving the hospital.
- Please look below for information about scheduling follow-up 
appointments with your new primary care doctor and specialists 
in:
--Hematology: to monitor ___ while ___ take the blood-thinning 
medication warfarin.
--Endocrinology: to evaluate your enlarged thyroid.
--Obstetrics & Gynecology: to perform a uterine biopsy and 
evaluate your abdominal fluid.
--Neurosurgery: to discuss management of your aneurysm with Dr. 
___.

It was a pleasure taking care of ___.

Sincerely,
Your Care Team at ___

# hypotension - Was worked up for hypovolemic shock with blood 
transfusions and serial hcts. no acute GIB found. Underwent TTE 
which showed worsened CHF. Hypotension did require pressors 
however as patient's family eventually changed goals of care to 
comfort measures this was weaned off. she passed away after a 
few days in the hospital.  

# respiratory failure - pt intubated in the setting of prolonged 
hypotension, resulting on altered mental status, and concern 
over patient's airway.  pre-intubation ABG 7.35/46/340, 
consistent with good lung mechanics. She was quickly extubated 
and tolerated this well, although was clearly uncomfortable. 
After the family changed the goals of care she was kept 
comfortable with morphine PRN and passed away a few weeks later.
 

# Code: Patient came in and family discussion resulted in 
changing from DNR to CMO if patient was extubated. she was 
eventually extubated and tolerated it well for a few days. She 
was transitioned to CMO.

Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: NEUROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
intraparenchymal hemorrhage
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
extubation (intubation done at outside hospital)
PEG placement
 
History of Present Illness:
___ is an ___ M with h/o AFib on Coumadin who is
transferred from ___ where he presented with
dysarthria and L hemiparesis, found to have R basal ganglia IPH. 


Per ___ notes, pt was in his USOH this morning at 6:45am. He is
currently residing at acute rehab after recent OSH admission for
mechanical fall. At 7:30am, staff checked on him and found him
dysarthric with dense L hemiparesis. He was brought to ___,
where BP on arrival was 127/80, INR 2.1. Exam showed extreme R
gaze deviation, left facial droop and left hemiplegia, initially
awake and alert and following commands. Stat NCHCT showed large 
R
basal ganglia hemorrhage. He received Profil 9, 2 units FFP, 10
units vit K, Keppra 1g IV. He became sleepy in the ___ so was
induced with rocuronium/fent/midaz and intubated for airway
protection. Transferred to ___ for further care. On arrival to
___ ___, SBP initially ~100, then became hypotensive to SBP
___ so Propofol was stopped. Neurology was consulted for
assistance with management. 

Of note pt was recently admitted to ___ from ___ after 
a
mechanical fall at home resulting in R rib fracture, then sent 
to
acute rehab on discharge. Had reportedly been doing well at 
rehab
until today. At baseline he is apparently very independent, 
lives
alone and performs all ADLs independently.

- AFib on Coumadin
- Recent admission to ___ for fall, w R rib fx and also 
suspected ileus
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Son had a pulmonary embolism due to provoked DVT and then 
subsequent DVT without clear cause, now anticoagulated for life. 
Other family history unknown.
 
Physical Exam:
ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAM:
- Vitals: 97.3, BP 100-68/50s-80s, P ___, SaO2 100% vent 40% 
FiO2
- General: intubated, off sedation x 30 min
- HEENT: NC/AT
- Neck: Supple, no carotid bruits appreciated.
- Pulmonary: CTABL
- Cardiac: RRR, no murmurs
- Abdomen: soft, nontender, nondistended
- Extremities: no edema, pulses palpated
- Skin: no rashes or lesions noted.
NEURO EXAM:
- Mental Status: intubated, off sedation x 15 min. Doesn't open 
eyes to voice or sternal rub. Initially very sleepy and didn't 
follow any commands, later followed commands to squeeze hand/let 
go and wiggle toes on left. No evidence of neglect.
- Cranial Nerves: Pupils initially 2mm and sluggish, then 
developed fluctuating anisocoria (L pupil ranging from 2-5mm in 
size). No corneals. Face symmetric but limited by ETT. VORs 
sluggish. No cough or gag.
- Motor/Sensory: Withdraws right arm and leg purposefully to 
noxious stim and intermittently follows commands on the right. 
Extensor posturing of LUE to noxious stim, LLE weakly extensor 
posturing. Occasional rigor-like movements diffusely.
- Reflexes: sluggish (1+) and symmetric in upper extrem, absent 
in lower extremities.
- Coordination/Gait: unable to assess 

==================================================

DISCHARGE PHYSICAL EXAM: Oriented x 3. Dysarthric. Left sided 
neglect, starting to recognize left hand as his own. Left 
hemiplegia. Right gaze preference, but able to cross midline.

==============================================

IMAGING: 

CT HEAD ___: Acute parenchymal hemorrhage which appears to 
originate in the right centrum semiovale with associated rim of 
edema and mass effect is unchanged compared to OSH examination 
obtained roughly 5 hours earlier.  No new focus of hemorrhage. 
NOTE ADDED IN ATTENDING REVIEW: The large hemorrhage, above, 
appears centered in the right corona radiata, and could relate 
either to underlying hypertension or cerebral amyloid 
angiopathy; the lack of an intraventricular component favors the 
latter, as does the paucity of sequelae of chronic small vessel 
ischemic disease.  There is no central herniation.

CT HEAD ___: Large right putaminal hematoma has minimally 
increased in size and there is a minimal increase in midline 
shift to the left.  Basilar cisterns remain patent.

CXR ___: As compared to the previous radiograph, the lung 
volumes have 
slightly decreased.  There is moderate cardiomegaly and 
tortuosity of the 
thoracic aorta.  Minimal bilateral symmetrical apical 
thickening.  The course of the nasogastric tube is unremarkable. 
 The tube should be slightly advanced, given that the sidehole 
is at the level of the gastroesophageal junction.  No evidence 
of pneumonia or other pathologic parenchymal process.  The 
endotracheal tube has been removed in the interval. 

CT head ___: 
IMPRESSION: 
1.  No significant interval change in the large right 
parenchymal hemorrhage 
with surrounding edema centered in the basal ganglia. 
2.  Stable 4-mm leftward midline shift. 
3.  No evidence of obstructive hydrocephalus. 
  

TTE: 
The left atrium is mildly dilated. The right atrium is 
moderately dilated. No atrial septal defect is seen by 2D or 
color Doppler. Left ventricular wall thickness, cavity size and 
regional/global systolic function are normal (LVEF >55%). There 
is no ventricular septal defect. The right ventricular cavity is 
mildly dilated with normal free wall contractility. The 
diameters of aorta at the sinus, ascending and arch levels are 
normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened but 
aortic stenosis is not present. No masses or vegetations are 
seen on the aortic valve. No aortic regurgitation is seen. The 
mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. No mass or 
vegetation is seen on the mitral valve. Moderate (2+) mitral 
regurgitation is seen. The tricuspid valve leaflets are mildly 
thickened. There is mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. 
  

Swallow evaluation ___:
RECOMMENDATIONS: 
1. PO Diet: Nectar-thick liquids and pureed solids when 
optimally
awake/alert
2. Meds crushed in applesauce or other pureed solid
3. TID Oral care if taking POs, Q4 if NPO
4. 1:1 supervision with strict aspiration precautions: 
    - sit fully upright during/30 min after PO intake
    -feed only when awake, alert, and participatory
    -small bites and sips
    -slow pace
5. Encourage further discussion of long-term non-oral nutrition,
hydration and medication 
 
==============================================

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is an ___ year-old man with a history of afib on 
___ transferred to ___ from ___ after 
developing dense left hemiparesis and slurred speech, found to 
have large right basal ganglia IPH with midline shift.  While at 
the OSH, his anticoagulation (INR 2.1) was reversed with Profil 
9, 2units FFP and 10u vit K. He was intubated for airway 
protection at the OSH.  

# NEURO - right basal ganglia intraparenchymal bleed
At ___, he was monitored closely in the Neuro ICU from ___ 
through ___.  Exam most notable for left hemiparesis, rightward 
gaze deviation and eyelid opening apraxia.  Repeat CT head scans 
showed stable intraparenchymal hemorrhage in the right basal 
ganglia (roughly 6x3cm) with rim edema and slight midline shift 
(4mm).  Etiology of bleed was thought to be related to either 
underlying hypertension or cerebral amyloid angiopathy. No 
neurosurgical intervention was indicated.  He was successfully 
extubated on ___.  He intially required an NG tube for enteral 
tube feeding and medications. He then passed swallowing eval and 
tolerated a diet of puree and nectar thicken with aspiration 
precautions. However, given concerns over not taking in enough 
oral nutrition, the patient and his family agreed for PEG 
placement as well to supplement oral nutrition. He will need 
continual ___ to improve function and to reduce chance of 
contractures. Warfarin will likely be indefinitely held due to 
the ICH. He has been started on aspirin 81mg daily for stroke 
prevention given his atrial fibrillation.

# ___ - h/o atrial fibrillation
He has a lonstanding history of atrial fibrillation, rate 
controlled on diltiazem and previously anticoagulated with 
Coumadin.  His anticoagulation was reversed at OSH.  Home rate 
control with diltiazem was continued.  Dilt was switched to 
standing IV Metoprolol IV because of his ileus and then C diff 
colitis (see below). There was no evidence of RVR or cardiac 
decompensation.  Anticoagulation is likely going to be 
indefinitely held given his sizable intraparenchymal bleed in 
the setting of INR of only 2.1. He was started on aspirin 81mg 
daily in place of the warfarin. He takes dilt ER 240 daily at 
home but has been taking 30mg qid via PEG tube with HR running 
in the 90's. The dilt dose may be up-titrated as needed and as 
tolerated by his BP.

# ID: gram positive bacteremia and UTI. C diff colitis.
History of right toe cellulitis previously on dicloxacillin.  
This was restarted while inpatient and then discontinued.  His 
UTI is treated with 7 days of ceftriaxone.  His gram positive 
bactermia was treated with vancomycin (started on ___ and 
should be continued for 14 days.  He was also found to have C 
diff colitis on ___ and was started on PO vancomycin.

#GI: Ileus
He was noted to have large residual on TF. KUB identified ileus. 
 His NGT was placed to suction for 2 days.  He clinically 
improved and passed swallow eval and diet was advanced to puree 
and nectar thicken.

# PULMONARY
He was intubated for airway protection and easily extubated on 
___.    

# MSK
Recent right rib fracture after mechanical fall.  He was on 
standing tylenol for a few days for pain control and 
occasionally require oxycodone.

# TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:  
- His son, ___, and daughter, ___, live in ___. 
- His IV vancomycin for gram positive bactermia should be 
continued through ___.
- His PO vancomycin for C diff colitis should be continued 
through ___.
- He takes dilt ER 240 daily at home but has been taking 30mg 
qid via PEG tube with HR running in the 90's. The dilt dose may 
be up-titrated as needed and as tolerated by his BP.

activate EMS for stroke, stroke warning signs and symptoms, 
prescribed medications, need for followup)

5. Assessment for rehabilitation or rehab services considered? 
(x) Yes - () No [if no, reason not assessed: ____ ]

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were in ___ because of left arm and leg weakness due to a 
bleed in the right side of your brain likely caused by high 
blood pressure.  Your warfarin was discontinued to reduce the 
chance of future bleeds.  Physical therapy worked with you here 
and recommended rehab to help with your recovery.

Medication changes:
- we discontinued warfarin because you had a bleed in your brain
- we started aspirin 81mg daily to replace your warfarin
- we change the dose of your diltiazem to 30mg four times a day 
which can be given through the PEG tube
- we started IV vancomycin for your blood stream infection. 
Please take until ___
- we started PO vancomycin for your C diff colitis. Please take 
until ___

Please continue to the take medications as listed in the 
discharge medication list.

Please seek medical attention if you experience any of the 
danger signs listed

unwitnessed fall 
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
No major surgical or invasive procedures

 
History of Present Illness:
___ yo M with PMH of congenital deafness, HTN, osteoporosis who 
presents after unwitnessed fall in assisted living facility. He 
uses a walker and has had frequent falls which were being worked 
up as an outpatient. For this fall, he says he tripped, but he 
remembers the event and denies LOC. He was found on the floor 
sitting by the staff who called EMS. He hit his head on a 
picture he says. Apparently, he fell the night before but 
refused EMS at the time. Of note, he is being worked up as an 
outpatient for his frequent falls and the last neurology note 
suggested EMG and nerve conduction studies. They did not feel he 
fit a Parkinsonian picture but were concerned given his proximal 
muscle weakness and instability.  
.  
In the ED, initial VS were T 98.6, HR 75, BP 123/68, RR 18, 
O2sat 97% RA. He was given 1L IVF, tylenol for pain.  
.  
On the floor, he says he has some pain in his right shoulder but 
denies any other pain. No headache or change in vision. 
+incontinence of stool and urine which is chronic he says.  
.
On review of systems, denies fever, chills, night sweats, recent 
weight loss or gain. Denies headache, sinus tenderness, 
rhinorrhea or congestion. Denies cough, shortness of breath. 
Denies chest pain or tightness, palpitations. Denies nausea, 
vomiting, diarrhea, constipation or abdominal pain. No recent 
change in bowel or bladder habits. No dysuria. Denied 
arthralgias or myalgias.  
 
Past Medical History:
Frequent falls.
Hypertension.
Osteoporosis.
Congenital deafness.
Macular degeneration.
Vitamin B12 deficiency.

Urinary incontinence.
Insomnia.

exam so neuro exam is limited.

not very large. MMM, OP clear.

arms and legs bilaterally. Left arm rigidity. Left arm and leg 
appeared maybe weaker than right but again difficult to assess 
given lack of good patient participation. Toes mute bilaterally.

to light touch appears to be intact.

20% of the anterior vertebral body height. Age of this is 
indeterminate. Also, thoracolumbar scoliosis and prominent 
degenerative changes of the lumbar spine, worse at L1-L2 which 
is stable since the ___ study. 
.
CT T-SPINE W/O CONTRAST ___ 6:05 ___ 
1. Mild-to-moderate compression fracture of the T8 vertebral 
body (20%
anteriorly and 40% in the mid portion), with increased density 
of the superiorportion adjacent to the superior endplate, likely 
related to compress trabeculae and hence may represent an acute 
fracture. However, further assessment of the chronicity can be 
performed with MRI including sagittal STIR sequence.
2. No lytic lesions, cortical discontinuity or retropulsion of 
the posterior part of the body, no canal compromise.
3. Mild multilevel degenerative changes in the thoracic spine 
and at L1/2 as described above.
4. Focal nodularity of the right diaphragmatic crura/adjacent 
muscles, which may represent a normal variant.
5. Multiple hypodense areas in the right kidney, which may 
represent cysts
but are not adequately assessed on the present study. Ultrasound 
can be
considered.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ year-old male with congenital deafness, macular degeneration, 
in process of work-up for frequent falls s/p new fall with C7 
fracture.
.
# Spinal fracture: The patient was found to have an acute C7 
articular process fracture, for which he was evaluated by 
Neurosurgery and placed in a hard cervical collar.  Imaging of 
the thoracic and lumbar spine showed a T8 compression fracture, 
which Neurosurgery thought was old as patient without point 
tenderness.  The patient will follow up with Dr. ___ on 
___ at 11:30am.  He will need to call Dr. ___ office to 
schedule cervical and thoracic spine x-rays to be taken prior to 
the appointment.
.  
# R shoulder pain: Patient complained of right shoulder pain 
during his hospitalization but later reported that it was 
present prior to his fall.  Shoulder x-ray showed degenerative 
changes but no fracture or dislocation.  Patient was placed on a 
standing dose of Tylenol for pain management which can be 
switched to prn dosing by PCP with improvement. 
.
# Frequent falls: The patient's fall is most likely mechanical, 
as supported by the history of tripping over a cord and denial 
of syncope or vertigo. There was no evidence of an acute cardiac 
event on this admission nor on prior work-up. He is currently in 
the process of an outpatient work-up by Neurology for possible 
motor neuron disease as etiology of his falls.  He is scheduled 
for an EMG and nerve conduction study as an outpatient on 
___, to follow-up with Dr. ___ on ___.
. 
# Hyponatremia: The patient presented with hyponatremia, likely 
secondary to hypovolemia and poor PO intake. Pt was given a 
liter of normal saline, diet liberalized, and increased po diet 
(especially fluids) with supplements encouraged with 
improvement.
.  
# HTN: Patient continued on atenolol.  Aspirin initially held in 
setting of possible surgery but restarted at home dose.
. 
# BPH with incontinence: Patient continued on oxybutynin.  Of 
note, although there was concern for orthostatic hypotension 
with this medication, pt was not found to be orthostatic on exam 
and has tolerated this medication in the past.  
.  
# Macrocytic anemia: The patient has a known B12 deficiency, and 
he was continued on his home supplements. His hematocrit 
remained at his baseline throughout his admission.
.
# Osteoporosis: Patient continued on calcium, vitamin D and 
Fosamax.  
.
# Depression: Stable on escitalopram.  
.  
# Insomnia: Patient restarted on home dose of trazodone, which 
he tolerated well.
.
# Gerontology: Patient scheduled to follow up with ___ 
___, NP on ___ at 2pm and Dr. ___ on ___.  

 
Medications on Admission:
Cyanocobalamin 1000 mcg daily
Lexapro 10 mg daily 
Vitamin D 400 units twice a day  
Atenolol 25 mg daily  
ASA 325mg at bedtime
Folic Acid ___ mcg twice a day  
Oxybutinin SR 5 mg daily
Colace 100 mg twice a day 
Senna ___ cap at bedtime 
Calcium Carbonate 500mg TID with meals  
Acetaminophen 650 mg at bedtime  
Trazodone 100 mg at bedtime 
Fosamax weekly  
 

MVI daily  

 

Metamucil 1 tbsp daily 
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Cyanocobalamin 500 mcg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
2. Escitalopram 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
3. Cholecalciferol (Vitamin D3) 400 unit Tablet Sig: One (1) 
Tablet PO BID (2 times a day).  
4. Atenolol 25 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  
5. Folic Acid 1 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  

6. Oxybutynin Chloride 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 
times a day).  
7. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).  
8. Senna 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO HS (at bedtime).  
9. Calcium Carbonate 500 mg Tablet, Chewable Sig: One (1) 
Tablet, Chewable PO TIDAC (3 times a day (before meals)).  
10. Aspirin 325 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  

11. Acetaminophen 500 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO TID (3 
times a day).  
12. Trazodone 100 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO HS (at 
bedtime).  
13. Psyllium     Packet Sig: One (1) Packet PO DAILY (Daily).  
14. Alendronate 70 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a week. 
 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary:
- C7 fracture
Secondary:
- S/p multiple falls 
- Hypertension
- Congenital deafness
- Osteoporosis
- BPH with basline incontinence
- Macular degeneration

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital after you fell.  You were 
found to have a neck fracture on imaging.  You must keep your 
C-collar at all times while this heals - please do not remove it 
without first discussing with Dr. ___.  You also had an old 
compression fracture in your spine.  You will need to follow up 
with Neurosurgery for these issues and repeat x-rays prior to 
your visit.  Of note, although you were complaining of right 
shoulder pain, there was no evidence of a fracture.  You should 
continue to follow up with Neurology for work-up of your 
frequent falls.  

Your Tylenol was increased to 1000 mg three times a day for your 
right shoulder pain.  Once it improves, you may be able to take 
it only as needed - please discuss this with your doctor.  
Please continue to take all your home medications as prescribed. 
 

Please call your doctor or come to the ED if you have another 
fall, loss of consciousness, increasing neck or back pain, 
weakness or numbness in your extremities, or any other 
concerning symptoms.

Name:  ___              Unit No:   ___

Service: UROLOGY

Chief Complaint:
Hematuria
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Irrigation and clot removal from bladder (by hand)
Continuous bladder irrigation

 
History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ is an ___ yo Male with multiple medical problems 
with a recent admission for urosepsis in the setting of an 8 mm 
right midureteral stone, who was treated with IV antibiotics, 
and percutaneous nephrostomy tube for decompression.  Following 
his discharge, the patient had undergone right ureteroscopy, 
laser lithotripsy, ureteral stent placement and removal of his 
nephrostomy tube on ___.      

He saw Dr. ___ in clinic ___ for removal of his stent, 
however, it appeared that the stent had migrated up the ureter, 
and thus could not be removed in clinic.  The patient was to 
schedule a procedure with Dr. ___ to remove the stent, 
however, he presented today to the ED c/o decreased urination 
and suprapubic pain.  Denied hematuria at home.  Several 
attempts were made to pass a foley catheter in the ED, and a 14 
F was successfully placed, putting out dark bloody urine.  Thus, 
urology was consulted regarding his hematuria, and decrease 
urine output, and abdominal pain.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was admitted for managment of hematuria, likely 
caused by traumatic foley catheter placement in the setting of a 
history of enlarged prostate, and anticoagulation with lovenox.  
He was also having some abdominal pain, likely secondary to 
urinary retention.  This improved with the placment of a foley 
catheter and after evacuation of clots in the bladder.  After 
clot evacuation, he required CBI overnight and his urine cleared 
without clots on HD#1.  His lovenox was held until his hematuria 
resolved. It was determined that his ureteral stent did not need 
to be emergently removed.  He had no evidence of perforation as 
seen by CT, and correlated clinically on exam.  His UA was 
significant for infection, and he was started on Cipro.  His 
abdominal pain was significantly improved on HD#1, however 
remained in house until VNS services was available for him.  
Thus he was discharge on HD #5, with no fevers, no pain, foley 
catheter draining clear yellow urine with adequate output, 
tolerating a soft mechanical diet and at baseline activity 
level.    

 
 
Medications on Admission:
atorvastatin 80 mg daily
sinemet 12.5 mg/50 mg TID
enoxaparin 100 mg sc daily
glipizide xl 10 mg daily
metoprolol 100 mg daily
mirtazapine 30 mg po qhs
donepezil 10 mg daily
seroquel 12.5 mg daily
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Ciprofloxacin HCl 250 mg PO Q12H 
RX *ciprofloxacin 250 mg ONE tablet(s) by mouth twice a day Disp 
#*14 Tablet Refills:*0
2. Enoxaparin Sodium 100 mg SC DAILY 
60mg syringe with 40mg syringe for total daily dose of 100mg 
3. GlipiZIDE XL 10 mg PO DAILY 
4. Lisinopril 5 mg PO DAILY 
5. Metoprolol Succinate XL 100 mg PO DAILY 
hold for sbp <100, hr<60 
6. Mirtazapine 30 mg PO HS 
7. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  2.5 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg 0.5 (One half) tablet(s) by mouth Q6hrs Disp 
#*20 Tablet Refills:*0
8. Quetiapine Fumarate 12.5 mg PO BID 
9. Carbidopa-Levodopa (___) 0.5 TAB PO BID 
0.5 tablet twice per day 
10. Atorvastatin 80 mg PO DAILY 
11. Acetaminophen 325 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain 
12. Donepezil 10 mg PO HS 
13. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
RX *docusate sodium 100 mg ONE capsule(s) by mouth twice a day 
Disp #*60 Tablet Refills:*1

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Urinary tract infection, hematuria, ureteral stent migration

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Confused - always.
Level of Consciousness: Lethargic but arousable.
Activity Status: Bedbound.
Activity Status: Out of Bed with assistance to chair or 
wheelchair; known to be unable to perform activities of daily 
living. Lives at home with wife AND live-in caretaker.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Weigh yourself every morning, call MD if weight goes up more 
than 3 lbs.

-Please also review the provided handout w/nursing instructions 
on Foley catheter care and leg bag usage

-Resume your pre-admission/home medications INCLUDING LOVENOX, 
except as noted. Always call to inform, review and discuss any 
medication changes and your post-operative course with your 
primary care doctor

-___ may use ___ for pain control

-The MAXIMUM dose of Tylenol (ACETAMINOPHEN) is 4 grams (from 
ALL sources) PER DAY and remember that the prescribed narcotic 
pain medication may also contain Tylenol (acetaminophen) so this 
needs to be considered when monitoring your daily dose and 
maximum.

-Colace has been prescribed to avoid post surgical constipation 
and constipation related to narcotic pain medication. 
Discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops. Colace is a 
stool softener--it is NOT a laxative.

-Your Foley should be secured to the catheter secure on your 
thigh at ALL times until your follow up with the surgeon.

-Follow up in ___ weeks for definitive STENT management and 
foley removal. Until then, DO NOT have anyone else other than 
your Surgeon remove your Foley for any reason.

-Wear Large Foley bag for majority of time, leg bag is only for 
short-term when leaving house.

-Complete the prescribed antibiotic (Ciprofloxacin)

-resume your regular home diet and remember to drink plenty of 
fluids to keep hydrated and to prevent constipation

-___ medical attention for fevers (temp>101.5), worsening pain, 
drainage or excessive bleeding from incision, chest pain or 
shortness of breath.

-You have an indwelling ureteral stent that MUST be removed 
and/or exchanged in the next few weeks time. Please follow-up as 

advised.

You may experience some normal discomfort or pain associated 
with spasm of your ureter.  This is especially true when there 
is an INDWELLING URETERAL STENT. 

-Expect to see occasional blood in your urine and to experience 
urgency and frequency over the next month.

-You may experience some pain associated with spasm of your 
ureter. This is normal. 

-Max daily Tylenol (acetaminophen) dose is 4 grams from ALL 
sources, note that narcotic pain medication also contains 
Tylenol
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Name:  ___                Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Tegaderm Frame Style / Iron
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
chest pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Cardiac cath on ___ and ___
TEE/cardioversion ___

 
History of Present Illness:
___ w/ hx of chronic angina, HTN, DM, ESRD s/p renal transplant 
now making urine and not on dialysis, and angina presenting with 
chest pain for 2 days. CP is described as substernal, radiating 
to Rt side. Pain is exertional, no pain at rest. Chest pain 
feels diff from prior cp, now described as tightness, prior cp 
felt like pinching. Took Nitro SL x2 last night w/improvement in 
pain, nitro SL x1 this AM didn't help pain. Pt states has also 
had LH/dizziness started last week, became more frequent 2d ago. 
Denies syncope/pre-syncope Sx. Endorses palpitations this AM, 
+DOE and mild SOB at rest. Denies orthopnea, PND, ___ edema, 
vision changes. States dry weight is 162 lbs, he weighed himself 
last week, weighed 160 lbs. Denies missing medications. 
Denies hx of GIB, N/V/D. +chronic constipation. No F/C/NS, 

In the ED, his EKG showed atrial flutter with HR in the 140's. 
He was given metoprolol 5 mg IV x2 and his chest pain resolved. 
He received Dilt IV 15mg x2 and Dilt PO 30mg x1 for tachycardia. 
Patient was given 500cc x2 IVF. 
Labs/studies notable for: Negative Trops x 1, Cr 1.4. 

CXR showed: Stable appearance of the mediastinum with prominence 
of the main pulmonary artery, suggesting pulmonary hypertension. 
Mild cardiomegaly. No focal consolidation. 
 
On review of systems, he denies any prior history of stroke, 
TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the 
time of surgery, myalgias, joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, black 
stools or red stools. denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. 
denies exertional buttock or calf pain. All of the other review 
of systems were negative.  
 
Cardiac review of systems is notable for absence of paroxysmal 
nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, ankle edema, palpitations, syncope 
or presyncope.  

On presentation to the floor, patient feeling well without 
complaints. 
 
Past Medical History:
1. CARDIAC RISK FACTORS:  
HYPERCHOLESTEROLEMIA  
HYPERTENSION  
DIABETES TYPE II

- PUMP FUNCTION: >55%  
- PACING/ICD: None.  
- CHRONIC ANGINA  
 
3. OTHER PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:  
CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE  
h/o ERSD on hemodialysis since ___ bilateral AV fistulae  
s/p cadaveric renal transplant (R) anastomosed to right iliac  
artery/vein on ___  

IMPOTENCE  
LUNG NODULE  
OSTEOPENIA TOE FRACTURE  
BILATERAL KNEE PAIN (RIGHT >LEFT)  
ENLARGED LYMPH NODES    
DEPRESSION  
ALLERGIC RHINITIS H/O GI ULCER  
H/O TOE FRACTURE  
H/O GASTROINTESTINAL BLEEDING  

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Significant for hypertension in his mother. A granddaughter had 
an unspecified cardiomyopathy at age ___ that required heart 
transplant. Father with diabetes and prostate Ca. Mother with 
DM. Brother with 3x CVAs. 

 
Physical Exam:
PHYSICAL EXAM ON ADMISSION:
===========================
VS: 97.5, 139/82, 54-82, 18, 98% RA
Wt: 70.9 kg
General: NAD

CXR ___:
IMPRESSION:  
Stable appearance of the mediastinum with prominence of the main 
pulmonary 
artery, suggesting pulmonary hypertension.  Mild cardiomegaly.  
No focal 
consolidation. 

Cardiac cath ___:
Successful DES of RCA
Serial 70% lesions in LVX OM branch and 60% mid LAD
Femoral angiography via the sheath showed severe calcification 
and stenosis of the CFA
Recommendations: Continue aspirin uninterrupted indefinitely; 
clopidogrel minimum 6 months to ___ year
Anticoagulation for AF, optimally warfarin with INR 2.0-2.5
Rate control for AF - consider cardioversion after 3 weeks 
anticoagulation
Consider treatment of right CFA disease if leg claudication

ECHO ___:
The left atrium is mildly dilated. No atrial septal defect is 
seen by 2D or color Doppler. There is mild symmetric left 
ventricular hypertrophy. The left ventricular cavity size is 
normal. Due to suboptimal technical quality, a focal wall motion 
abnormality cannot be fully excluded. Overall left ventricular 
systolic function is probably mildly depressed (LVEF= 45 %). 
There is considerable beat-to-beat variability of the left 
ventricular ejection fraction due to an irregular rhythm. There 
is no ventricular septal defect. Right ventricular chamber size 
is normal with mild global free wall hypokinesis. The ascending 
aorta is mildly dilated. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are 
mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. No aortic 
regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly 
thickened. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is seen. The tricuspid 
valve leaflets are mildly thickened. There is moderate pulmonary 
artery systolic hypertension. There is a very small pericardial 
effusion. There are no echocardiographic signs of tamponade. 

Compared with the prior study (images reviewed) of ___, 
LV and RV systolic function have probably decreased.  

Catheterization ___:

Coronary Anatomy
Dominance: Right
Left main coronary artery: Normal.
Left anterior descending coronary artery:  There was a 50% 
stenosis 
in the mid LAD. The LAD was otherwise a normal vessel in  its 
proximal and  distal portions. The diagonal branches were free 
of significant disease.
Left circumflex coronary artery:  There was a 70-80% stenosis at 
the orgin of the OMB and a 70% stenosis in the mid portion of  
the large OMB. The AV LCx terminated in a small PLP. 
Right coronary artery: The stents were widely patent in the 
proximal 
and mid RCA.  At the distal portion of the RCA - there was a 
tubular 80% stenosis that led into the PDA and RPL.  
Femoral angiography: Common femoral artery puncture with 
extensive calcification and stenosis in the SFA, profunda 

Interventional Details
The indication for the procedure was recurrent pain after PCI 
and 
NSTEMI. Initial angiography revealed 70% stenosis of the distal 
OM1 and 70% stenosis proximal portion of the OM1. An 80% 
stenosis was also noted at the distal RCA. Final angiography on 
all lesions revealed no residual stenosis, no angiographically 
apparent dissection, no perforation and TIMI 3 flow. The patient 
left the cath lab free  of  angina and  in stable condition.
Impressions
1.  Three vessel coronary artery disease
2.  Successful drug eluting stent of ___ lesion in distal 
RCA
3.  Successful drug eluting stents of the ___
Recommendations
1.  Aspirin and clopidogrel
2.  Medical therapy

patient. A TEE was performed in the location listed above. I

Results were reviewed with the Cardiology Fellow involved with

Conclusions
The left atrium is dilated. Moderate spontaneous echo contrast 
is seen in the body of the left atrium. No mass/thrombus is seen 
in the left atrium or left atrial appendage. The left atrial 
appendage emptying velocity is depressed (<0.2m/s). The right 
atrium is dilated. No atrial septal defect is seen by 2D or 
color Doppler. LV systolic function appears depressed. There are 
complex (>4mm) atheroma in the descending thoracic aorta (clip 
70). The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened but 
aortic stenosis is not present. No aortic regurgitation is seen. 
The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. There is no 
mitral valve prolapse. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is seen.

CLINICAL IMPLICATIONS: No left atrial or left atrial appendage 
thrombus. Low left atrial appendage velocity with moderate SEC 
in the ___. Mild mitral regurgitation. Complex atheroma in 
the descending aorta. 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old male with history of chronic angina, HTN, DM, ESRD 
s/p renal transplant on tacro, sirolimus, and prednisone 
presenting with chest pain and shortness of breath found to have 
NSTEMI and atrial fibrillation.

# NSTEMI:
Patient presented with angina, with risk factors including HTN, 
DM, and ESRD. Patient noted to have elevated troponin that 
peaked at 0.11. Patient underwent cardiac catheterization on 
___ and received 3 drug eluting stents to the RCA. Patient 
continued to complain of chest pain, and so underwent 
catheterization on ___ and received a DES to a distal RCA 
lesion and one to the Obtuse marginal branch. Patient was 
continued on aspirin 81 mg and Plavix 75 mg daily. Atorvastatin 
80 mg daily started. The patient was discharged on 12.5mg 
Metoprolol succinate XL. 

# Atrial fibrillation
Patient presented with atrial fibrillation with CHADS score of 
3. He was continued on heparin drip and underwent 
transesophageal echocardiography and cardioversion with 
successful cardioversion to sinus rhythm. Metoprolol was 
adjusted for rate control and patient discharged on dose 
Metoprolol succinate XL 12.5. Warfarin started and bridged to 
therapeutic INR. Goal INR of ___ given other antiplatelet 
agents including aspirin and Plavix. Patient established with 
___ clinic at ___. TSH noted to be 
normal. 

# Systolic heart failure
Patient found to have depressed EF of 45%. Diminished EF with 
contribution from atrial fibrillation that may improve after 
cardioversion. Patient discharged on metoprolol succinate XL 
12.5mg and continued on enalapril. Weight on discharge noted to 
be 69.8kg.

# h/o ERSD s/p renal transplant (baseline Cr 1.3-1.7). 
Cr 1.4 on admission. Renal transplant consulted. Patient 
continued on prednisone 2.5 mg daily, sirolimus 2.5 mg daily, 
and tacrolimus 0.5 mg qAM and 1 mg qPM.
 
# Hypertension:
Patient continued on metoprolol and amlodipine. Enalapril 2.5 mg 
also continued. 
 
# Hypercholsteremia 
He was started atorvastatin 80 mg daily

# Type II Diabetes: 
While in-house, he was continued on glargine instead of detemir 
but should resume glargine at home. 

# COPD
Continued albuterol and Spiriva.

# BPH
Held home doxazosin while inpatient but continued on discharge
 
# GERD
His home omeprazole 20 mg daily was discontinued (but 
unfortunately his discharge worksheet does not reflect this) due 
to interaction of omeprazole with Plavix. He was started on 
pantoprazole 40 mg daily in place of omeprazole.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You came to the hospital with chest pain and were found to have 
a heart attack. You had a procedure called cardiac 
catheterization that opened up the blocked vessel in your heart 
with a stent. It is very important that you take Plavix and 
aspirin every day and not miss any doses to keep the stent open. 
Missing a dose of these medications could result in a heart 
attack. Please do not stop taking these medications unless told 
so by your heart doctor.

You were also found to have a condition called atrial 
fibrillation or a rapid heart rate. You were started on a 
medication called warfarin a blood thinner that will help 
prevent a stroke. You will need to have routine blood tests to 
monitor the level of blood thinner in your blood. You had a 
procedure called a cardioversion that helped your heart return 
to a normal rhythm. Your home metoprolol was decreased because 
your heart rate was well-controlled. 

You were also found to have systolic heart failure or decreased 
pump function of your heart. It is very important for you to 
weigh yourself every morning and call your heart doctor if your 
weight goes up by more than 3 lbs. in 2 days. Your weight on 
discharge was 69.8 kg (153 pounds).

Additionally, we have stopped your omeprazole and replaced it 
with a medication called pantoprazole for your reflux. We have 
also decreased your home amlodipine to 5 mg once a day from 
twice a day in order to add a new medication (Imdur) which will 
help prevent chest pain.  

It was a pleasure being involved in your care,

Your ___ Team

Robotic assisted-total laparoscopic hysterectomy, bilateral 
salpingo-oophorectomy, lysis of adhesions

 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ yo G3P2 who was recently diagnosed 
with EIN following a D&C.  She presented to her PCP with 
complaints of menometrorrhagia and underwent endometrial biopsy 
in the office.  This revealed secretory endometrium and a likely 
polyp.  She subsequently underwent hysteroscopy D&C to reveal 
multiple polyps and EIN arising in one of the polyps.  She 
continues to experience heavy bleeding.  She denies pain, 
urinary symptoms, changes in bowel habits and weight changes. 
She presents for robotic assisted total laparoscopic 
hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. 

 
Past Medical History:

deficiency, left rotator cuff tear.

___, meniscus ___, D&C ___

___.  Regular cycles, now heavier.

___

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted to ___ on ___ following 
an uncomplicated robotic-assisted laparoscopic hysterectomy, 
bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, and lysis of adhesions for 
complex endometrial hyperplasia with atypia.  Please see full 
operative report for details.  She was placed on telemetry due 
to her obstructive sleep apnea for which she used her home CPAP.

In the early morning following surgery, ___, Ms. ___ 
___ had an episode of low urine output.  Her exam 
revealed no signs or symptoms of bleeding and she responded to a 
500cc bolus.  She also had an episode of chest pressure with 
stable vital signs and a normal EKG, history and exam most 
consistent with GERD.  The patient was given protonix and tums 
which resolved her symptoms.  Her electrolytes were repleted as 
needed. Her home antihypertensives were started that morning. 
Later that day she met all milestones. The patient was 
tolerating a regular diet, her pain was well controlled on PO 
pain medications, she was voiding and ambulating independently, 
and was passing flatus.  She was discharged home with follow-up 
scheduled with Dr. ___.

Home

Discharge Condition:

Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear ___,

You were admitted to the gynecologic oncology service after 
undergoing the procedures listed below. You have recovered well 
after your operation, and the team feels that you are safe to be 
discharged home. Please follow these instructions:  

* Take your medications as prescribed.  
* Do not drive while taking narcotics.  
* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol  
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs  
* No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment  
* Nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no douching, no sex) for 12 
weeks  
* No heavy lifting of objects >10lbs for ___ weeks.  
* You may eat a regular diet  
  
Incision care:  
* You may shower and allow soapy water to run over incision; no 
scrubbing of incision. No bath tubs for 6 weeks.  
* You should remove your port site dressings ___ days after your 
surgery. If you have steri-strips, leave them on. If they are 
still on after ___ days from surgery, you may remove them.   
 
To reach medical records to get the records from this 
hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.

text:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: CARDIOTHORACIC
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Shortness of breath
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
s/p Coronary artery Bypass Grafting /Aortic Valve 
Replacement(Left internal mammary artery grafted to left 
anterior descending artery. Saphenous vein grafted to Obtuse 
Marginal/Right coronary artery)/ (#21mm ___ tissue Aortic 
___

 
History of Present Illness:
___ year old man with past medical history of hypertension, 
hyperlipidemia, chronic atrial fibrillation, referred for 
cardiac catherization for evaluation
of coronary artery disease and aortic stenosis.  The patient 
presented with chest pain in the setting of rapid atrial 
fibrillation, and was found to have positive cardiac biomarkers 
at OSH as well as severe atrial stenosis on echocardiography 
with estimated valve area of 0.5 cm2 and EF 60%. Transferred to
___ for cardiac cath which revealed CAD. ___ was consulted 
for evaluation for AVR/CABG.  He underwent dental extractions 
___ in preparation for
surgery.  He was then transferred to rehab for antibiotic 
therapy for lower leg cellulitis.  He was treated with 
Vancomycin and Cipro and was eventually discharged to home.  He 
was home for 9 days and then was found to have a UTI by his PCP 
and was admitted to ___ on ___ and was treated 
with Imipenem. His foley was changed and he was sent back to 
rehab on ___ and
was transferred here today for surgery in the morning.  He had a 
power PICC placed last week.  He had a negative urine culture 
on___.

 
Past Medical History:
- Hypertension
- Chronic atrial fibrillation, on aspirin and not anticoagulated 
___ recurrent epistaxis on warfarin
- Diastolic congestive heart failure (EF 60%)
- Aortic stenosis
- H/o cervical fracture age ___ s/p C3-5 laminectomy, resulting 
in mild atony ___ muscles and neurogenic bladder, with 
indwelling Foley catheter ___ years
- Gastroesophageal reflux disease
- Benign prostatic hyperplasia
- Multiple UTIs
- CKD stage I-II
- S/p skin cancer resection left shoulder ___ years ago
- BLE draining cellulitis x ___ weeks
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
There is no family history of premature coronary artery disease 
or sudden death. Father with ___ vascular disease leading 
to bilateral amputation at ___, CVA at ___. Mother with HTN died 
at ___ secondary to complication of CVA.
 
Physical Exam:
Pulse: 86 Resp: 18 O2 sat: 98% RA
B/P  Right: 93/62   Left: 
Height:     Weight:

General:
Skin: Dry [x] intact [x]
HEENT: PERRLA [x] EOMI [x]
Neck:  Supple [x] Full ROM [x]
Chest: Lungs clear bilaterally [x]
Heart: RRR [x]  Irregular []  Murmur
Abdomen: Soft [x] non-distended [x] non-tender [x]  bowel sounds
+ [x]
Extremities: Warm [x], well-perfused [x]  Edema Varicosities:
None []bilat. redness on calves
Neuro: Grossly intact

Femoral      Right: 2+  Left: 2+
DP           Right: dop Left: dop
___           Right: dop Left: dop
Radial       Right: 2+  Left: 2+

Carotid Bruit        Right: no   Left: no

 
Pertinent Results:

___ 06:05PM BLOOD WBC-10.0 RBC-5.16 Hgb-10.9* Hct-36.2* 
MCV-70* MCH-21.1* MCHC-30.1* RDW-18.6* Plt ___

K-4.4 Cl-104 HCO3-28 AnGap-13

TotBili-0.5
Discharge
___ 08:50AM BLOOD WBC-13.1* RBC-4.71 Hgb-11.3* Hct-36.7* 
MCV-78* MCH-24.0* MCHC-30.8* RDW-20.6* Plt ___
___ 08:50AM BLOOD Plt ___
___ 03:13AM BLOOD ___ PTT-41.0* ___

___ 04:13AM BLOOD Glucose-78 UreaN-19 Creat-0.8 Na-142 
K-4.6 Cl-106 HCO3-25 AnGap-16
ECHOCARDIOGRAPHY REPORT
Date/Time: ___ at 08:33    ___ MD: ___, MD 

Test Type: TEE (Complete) Sonographer: ___, MD 
Doppler: Full Doppler and color Doppler Test Location: 
Anesthesia West OR cardiac 
Contrast: None Tech Quality: Adequate 
Tape #: 2010AW1-: Machine: Philips 
Echocardiographic Measurements  
Results  Measurements  Normal Range  
Left Ventricle - Ejection Fraction:  40% to 45%  >= 55%  
Aortic Valve - Peak Gradient:  *61 mm Hg  < 20 mm Hg  
Aortic Valve - Mean Gradient:  36 mm Hg     
Aortic Valve - LVOT diam:  2.1 cm     
Aortic Valve - Valve Area:  *0.6 cm2  >= 3.0 cm2  
Findings  
LEFT ATRIUM: Mild spontaneous echo contrast in the body of the 
LA. Mild spontaneous echo contrast in the ___. No thrombus in 
the ___. 
RIGHT ATRIUM/INTERATRIAL SEPTUM: Normal interatrial septum. 
LEFT VENTRICLE: Mildly depressed LVEF. 
RIGHT VENTRICLE: Moderate global RV free wall hypokinesis. 
AORTA: Normal ascending aorta diameter. Simple atheroma in 
descending aorta. 
AORTIC VALVE: Severely thickened/deformed aortic valve leaflets. 
Critical AS (area <0.8cm2). Trace AR. 
MITRAL VALVE: Moderately thickened mitral valve leaflets. 
Moderate (2+) MR. 
___ VALVE: Mild to moderate [___] TR. 
PULMONIC VALVE/PULMONARY ARTERY: Physiologic (normal) PR. 
PERICARDIUM: No pericardial effusion. 
GENERAL COMMENTS: A TEE was performed in the location listed 
above. I certify I was present in compliance with ___ 
regulations. The patient was under general anesthesia throughout 
the procedure. The TEE probe was passed with assistance from the 
anesthesioology staff using a laryngoscope. No TEE related 
complications.  
Conclusions  
Pre-CPB:
Mild spontaneous echo contrast is seen in the body of the left 
atrium. 
Mild spontaneous echo contrast is present in the left atrial 
appendage. 
No thrombus is seen in the left atrial appendage. 
Overall left ventricular systolic function is mildly depressed 
(LVEF= 40 - 45 %), with moderate global free wall hypokinesis. 
There are simple atheroma in the descending thoracic aorta. 
The aortic valve leaflets are severely thickened/deformed. There 
is critical aortic valve stenosis (valve area <0.8cm2). Trace 
aortic regurgitation is seen. 
The mitral valve leaflets are moderately thickened. Moderate 
(2+) mitral regurgitation is seen. 
There is no pericardial effusion. 
Post-CPB:
Patient is AV-Paced, on low dose Phenylephrine.
Good biventricular systolic fxn. EF now 45 - 50%.
Prosthetic aortic valve is in place with no leak and no AI. Mean 
residual gradient = 9 mmHg.
MR is 1+ - 2+.
Aorta intact.   
  I certify that I was present for this procedure in compliance 
with ___ regulations.

Electronically signed by ___, MD, Interpreting 
physician ___ ___ 12:39  
CHEST (PORTABLE AP) Study Date of ___ 4:45 ___ 
Final Report CHEST RADIOGRAPH  
INDICATION: Status post CABG and thoracocentesis.  
FINDINGS: As compared to the previous examination, the signs of 
pulmonary 
edema have decreased. Nonetheless, small bilateral pleural 
effusions are 
still seen. In almost unchanged manner, a retrocardiac 
atelectasis is shown.  
Moderate cardiomegaly. 
The ___-Ganz catheter has been removed, the venous introduction 
sheath is in unchanged position. 
The study and the report were reviewed by the staff radiologist. 
 
___. ___ 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
On ___ ___ went to the operating room and underwent 
Coronary artery bypass grafting x3 with a left internal mammary 
artery to left anterior descending artery andreverse saphenous 
vein graft to the distal right coronary artery and the obtuse 
marginal artery. And Aortic valve replacement with a 21-mm 
___ Ease
pericardial valve, size 21 mm, model number ___ with ___. 
Please see operative report for further details. He tolerated 
the procedure well and was transferred to the CVICU in critical 
but stable condition. He was sedated, intubated and required 
inotropes and pressors to augment his cardiac function. He awoke 
neurologically intact and on POD#1 he was extubated without 
difficulty. All lines and drains were discontinued in a timely 
fashion. Postoperatively he went back into his chronic atrial 
fibrillation. He was treated medically to rate control him. No 
anticoagulation per ___ as he has a history of recurrent 
epistaxis while on Coumadin in the past as well as being a high 
fall risk. He remainded in the CVICU while weaning off drips and 
maintaining hemodynamic stability. Postoperative Ciprofloxacin 
was started prophylactically for the UTI treated preop. While in 
the CVICU, ___ became delusional and was having visual 
hallucinations. All narcotics were discontinued and he was 
treated with Haldol and Seroquel with good response. POD#6 he 
was transferred to the step down unit for further monitoring. 
Physical therapy was consulted for evaluation of strength and 
mobility.  He remaind hemodynamically stable in rate controlled 
AFib. POD#8 he was cleared for discharge to ___ at ___ 
___. All follow up appointments were advised.

 
Medications on Admission:
Imipenem 500 mg IV q 8 hours
ASA 325 mg PO daily
Lovenox
Lipitor 80 mg PO daily
Lopressor 75 mg PO daily
Finasteride 5 mg PO daily
Lasix 40 mg PO daily
Diltiazem 30 mg PO QID
                     

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Aspirin 81 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: One (1) 
Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily).  
2. Ranitidine HCl 150 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
3. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).  
4. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q4H (every 
4 hours) as needed for pain.  
5. Bisacodyl 10 mg Suppository Sig: One (1) Suppository Rectal 
DAILY (Daily) as needed for constipation.  
6. Magnesium Hydroxide 400 mg/5 mL Suspension Sig: Thirty (30) 
ML PO HS (at bedtime) as needed for constipation.  
7. Atorvastatin 80 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
8. Heparin (Porcine) 5,000 unit/mL Solution Sig: 5000 (5000) 
units Injection TID (3 times a day).  
9. Finasteride 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 
 
10. Quetiapine 25 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO TID (3 times 
a day).  
11. Captopril 25 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO TID (3 times a 
day).  
12. Miconazole Nitrate 2 % Powder Sig: One (1) Appl Topical BID 
(2 times a day) as needed for itching.  
13. Insulin Regular Human 100 unit/mL Solution Sig: sliding 
scale  Injection ASDIR (AS DIRECTED): AC&QHS.  
14. Diltiazem HCl 30 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO QID (4 
times a day).  
15. Metoprolol Tartrate 50 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO TID 
(3 times a day).  
16. Lasix 40 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a day.  
17. Potassium Chloride 10 mEq Tablet Sustained Release Sig: Two 
(2) Tablet Sustained Release PO once a day.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
CAD
s/p Coronary artery Bypass Grafting /Aortic Valve 
Replacement(Left internal mammary artery grafted to left 
anterior descending artery. Saphenous vein grafted to Obtuse 
Marginal/Right coronary artery)/ (#21mm ___ tissue Aortic 
___
-hypertension, hyperlipidemia, chronic
atrial fibrillation (on
ASA, no coumadin ___ recurrent epistaxis on warfarin) diastolic
CHF (EF 60%) AS, h/o cervical fx age ___ s/p C3-C5 laminectomy,
resulting in mild atony ___ muscles and neurogenic bladder,
indwelling Foley x ___ years, GERD, BPH, multiple urinary tract
infections, CKD stage I-II, skin cancer resection left shoulder 
___
years ago, BLE draining cellulitis x ___ weeks, h/o MRSA

 
Discharge Condition:
Alert and oriented x3, nonfocal. 
Ambulating with  assistive device at baseline/wheelchair
Foley->gravity(neurogenic bladder)
Incisional pain managed with Tylenol only
Incisions: 
Sternal - healing well, no erythema or drainage 
Leg Right/Left - healing well, no erythema or drainage. 
___ (B) 

 
Discharge Instructions:
Weigh yourself every morning, call MD if weight goes up more 
than 3 lbs.
Shower daily including washing incisions gently with mild soap, 
no baths or swimming until cleared by surgeon. Look at your 
incisions daily for redness or drainage.

No lotions, cream, powder, or ointments to incisions. 
Each morning you should weigh yourself and then in the evening 
take your temperature, These should be written down on the chart 
.
No driving for approximately one month, until follow up with 
surgeon.
No lifting more than 10 pounds for 10 weeks.
Please call with any questions or concerns (___).
Females: Please wear bra to reduce pulling on incision, avoid 
rubbing on lower edge of sternal wound.

 

**Please call cardiac surgery office with any questions or 
concerns (___). Answering service will contact on call 
person during off hours.**

text:
Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
pneumaturia 
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
1. Robotic sigmoid colectomy with stapled #31
    coloproctostomy.
2. Robotic takedown of splenic flexure.

 
History of Present Illness:
___ year old male seen in clinic by Dr. ___ evaluation of 
Diverticulitis. Surgery was planned and the patient presented 
for surgery on ___.
 
Past Medical History:
PMH: gout
PSH: knee surgery x2 
 
Physical Exam:
General: doing well, ambulating, tolerating a regular diet
VSS
Neuro: A&OX3
cardio/Pulm: rrr, no shortness of breath
Abd: surg incisions intact, abdomen non distended
___: no lower extremity edema
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 07:50AM BLOOD WBC-8.1 RBC-2.71* Hgb-8.1* Hct-24.9* 
MCV-92 MCH-30.0 MCHC-32.7 RDW-14.9 Plt ___
___ 01:30PM BLOOD Hct-24.9*
___ 02:30AM BLOOD WBC-8.6 RBC-2.74*# Hgb-8.3*# Hct-25.3* 
MCV-92# MCH-30.1 MCHC-32.7 RDW-15.2 Plt ___
___ 12:39PM BLOOD Hct-29.1*#
___ 07:50AM BLOOD Glucose-91 UreaN-4* Creat-0.7 Na-143 
K-4.0 Cl-104 HCO3-28 AnGap-15
___ 02:30AM BLOOD Glucose-102* UreaN-11 Creat-0.9 Na-138 
K-4.1 Cl-107 HCO3-24 AnGap-11
___ 12:39PM BLOOD Na-141 K-3.9 Cl-107
___ 07:50AM BLOOD Calcium-9.0 Phos-3.3 Mg-1.6
___ 02:30AM BLOOD Calcium-8.3* Phos-3.1 Mg-2.0
___ 12:39PM BLOOD Mg-2.1
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ did quite well post-operatively on the Inpatient 
Colorectal Surgery Service. On ___ the patient tolerated 
clear liquids all postoperative laboratory values were stable. 
The patient complained of sudden onset R shoulder pain and 
agitation. EKG showed a right bundle branch block. He had 
negative cardiac enzymes and this was likely related to 
post-operative pain. On ___ the foley catheter was removed 
and the patient voided without issue. He tolerated a clear 
liquid diet. He had not passed flatus. He was transitioned to 
pain medications by mouth. On ___ the JP  drain was removed 
and the patient passed flatus and his diet was advanced to 
regular which was tolerated without issue. He was discharged 
home with appropriate discharge instructions and in good 
clinical condition.

 
Medications on Admission:
allopurinol ___, cipro 500'', gemfibrozil 600'', vicodin, 
indomethacin 50', lorazepam 1 qhsprn, simvastatin 20', MVI 
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q8H:PRN pain 
do not take more than 3000mg in 24 hours or drink alcohol while 
taking 
RX *acetaminophen 325 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every eight (8) 
hours Disp #*50 Tablet Refills:*0
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID:PRN constipation 
RX *docusate sodium 100 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth twice a day 
Disp #*60 Capsule Refills:*0
3. Simvastatin 20 mg PO QPM 
4. HYDROmorphone (Dilaudid) ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 
do not drink alcohol or drive a care while taking this 
medication 
RX *hydromorphone [Dilaudid] 2 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every 
four (4) hours Disp #*50 Tablet Refills:*0
5. Allopurinol ___ mg PO DAILY 
6. Gemfibrozil 600 mg PO BID 
7. Lorazepam 1 mg PO QHS:PRN sleep 
8. Indomethacin 50 mg PO Q24H 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Colovesical fistula with acute sigmoid diverticulitis and 
phlegmon.

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital after a Laparoscopic Colectomy 
for surgical management of your sigmoid diverticulitis You have 
recovered from this procedure well and you are now ready to 
return home. Samples from your colon were taken and this tissue 
has been sent to the pathology department for analysis. You will 
receive these pathology results at your follow-up appointment. 
If there is an urgent need for the surgeon to contact you 
regarding these results they will contact you before this time. 
You have tolerated a regular diet, are passing gas and your pain 
is controlled with pain medications by mouth. You may return 
home to finish your recovery.  
 
Please monitor your bowel function closely. You may or may not 
have had a bowel movement prior to your discharge which is 
acceptable, however it is important that you have a bowel 
movement in the next ___ days. After anesthesia it is not 
uncommon for patients to have some decrease in bowel function 
but you should not have prolonged constipation. Some loose stool 
and passing of small amounts of dark, old appearing blood are 
expected. However, if you notice that you are passing bright red 
blood with bowel movements or having loose stool without 
improvement please call the office or go to the emergency room 
if the symptoms are severe. If you are taking narcotic pain 
medications there is a risk that you will have some 
constipation. Please take an over the counter stool softener 
such as Colace, and if the symptoms do not improve call the 
office. If you have any of the following symptoms please call 
the office for advice or go to the emergency room if severe: 
increasing abdominal distension, increasing abdominal pain, 
nausea, vomiting, inability to tolerate food or liquids, 
prolonged loose stool, or extended constipation.  
 
You have ___ laparoscopic surgical incisions on your abdomen 
which are closed with internal sutures and a skin glue called 
Dermabond. These are healing well however it is important that 
you monitor these areas for signs and symptoms of infection 
including: increasing redness of the incision lines, 
white/green/yellow/malodorous drainage, increased pain at the 
incision, increased warmth of the skin at the incision, or 
swelling of the area. Please call the office if you develop any 
of these symptoms or a fever. You may go to the emergency room 
if your symptoms are severe. There is a site in your lower right 
abdomen where the JP drain once was in place. Please monitor 
this for the same symptoms of infection as listed above, please 
call the office if the site is bleeding or if there is 
white/grey/green/foul smelling pus draining from site. Please 
call the office if you are changing the dressing more than twice 
daily. Please call with any concerns. Cover with Dry sterile 
dressing. Ok to shower and reapply dressing after shower.   

You may shower; pat the incisions dry with a towel, do not rub. 
The small incisions may be left open to the air. If closed with 
steri-strips (little white adhesive strips) instead of 
Dermabond, these will fall off over time, please do not remove 
them. Please no baths or swimming for 6 weeks after surgery 
unless told otherwise by your surgical team.
 
You will be prescribed a small amount of the pain medication 
Oxycodone. Please take this medication exactly as prescribed. 
You may take Tylenol as recommended for pain. Please do not take 
more than 3000mg of Tylenol daily. Do not drink alcohol while 
taking narcotic pain medication or Tylenol. Please do not drive 
a car while taking narcotic pain medication.  

No heavy lifting greater than 6 lbs for until your first 
post-operative visit after surgery. Please no strenuous activity 
until this time unless instructed otherwise by Dr. ___ Dr. 
___.  
 
Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care! Our hope 
is that you will have a quick return to your life and usual 
activities. Good luck!  

 
Followup Instructions:
___

MCV-94 MCH-31.7 MCHC-33.5 RDW-17.2* Plt ___fter initial evaluation in the ED, Mr. ___ was admitted to 
the TICU for further evaluation and monitoring. On ___ he was 
stable and was transferred to the floor. The following details 
his hospital course by systems:

Neuro: He remained alert and oriented throughout his course 
without neurological defecits. Pain initially managed IV 
dilaudid. Once patient had adequate pain control and remained 
stable, he was transitioned off the dilaudid PCA to an oral 
regimen. 

Cardiovascular:
At the moment of admission patient's vital signs were stable, 
HCT was 42, no signs or symptoms of organs hypoperfusion. 
However over the course of 2 days his hematocrit dropped to 21. 
Patient received 2U pRBC's. Repeat CTA demonstrated splenic 
laceration with multiple foci of either active extravasation or 
small pseudoaneurysm at the lower pole similar compared to 
admission CTA. Increased in size of left renal and perirenal 
hematoma/known rupture of left renal cyst with hematoma layering 
within the cyst and increased  retroperitoneal hematoma along 
the lower pole of the left kidney. No evidence of active 
extravasation. 
Small amount of dense fluid layering within the pelvis. Stable 
appearance of a small intramuscular hematoma of the left 
obturator internus muscle. 
On ___ patient was tachycardic to 100s, SBP down to 100, 
diaphoresis and pre-syncope (no CP/SOB) with change in posture, 
relieved with supine. EKG with sinus, 96, NA/NI, no STEMI, TWI 
III. Provided 1L LR bolus and repeated basic labs and troponin. 
Hct down to 19, and again transfused 2 units pRBC's. Pt remained 
with no CP/SOB but intermitent tachycardia. Abdomen became 
increasingly firm and tender.
Therefore, he was taken to ___ for splenic pseudoaneurysm, and 
underwent gelfoam embolization of inferior splenic artery. 
Postprocedure, his hematocrit remained stable. He was noted to 
be slightly hypertensive on ___ and was started on metoprolol 
and then transitioned to lisinopril per his home regimen. He 
continued to remained persistently hypertensive with a sBP in 
the 160's and so his lisinopril dose was increased from 10 mg to 
20 mg daily.

Pulmonary:
Initially in the ED his O2 sat was 86% on RA. He was placed on 
supplemental O2 via NC, which was weaned with pain control and 
incentive spirometry and pulmonary toileting. His respiratory 
status remained uncompromised and his O2 sats remained ?90% on 
RA.

GI/GU:
Patient remained NPO for the first days of his hospitalization 
due to concern of continue intraabdominal bleeding. After 
Angiogram his hematocrit remained stable then diet was advanced 
to regular which he tolerated without abdominal pain, 
nausea/vomiting. He was also started on a bowel regimen given 
his decreased mobility and administration of narcotics. A foley 
catheter was placed on admission and his I&O's were closely 
monitored. On ___ his urine output remained adequate and the 
foley was removed, at which time he voided without difficulty.

Mental Status: Clear and coherent.

Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker
