Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital after falling from a 
scaffolding. You sustained multiple injuries including pelvic 
fractures, left arm and elbow fractures, fractures in the bony 
processes of your lumbar spine, and bleeding and bruising in 
your spleen and left kidney.

Your arm and elbow fractures were repaired in the operating room 
by the orthopedic surgeons. You should remain nonweightbearing 
on your left arm and follow up with orthopedics at the 
appointments listed below.

Your pelvic fractures are nonoperative and you may bear weight 
as tolerated on both of your legs.

You had a procedure in interventional radiology called gelfoam 
embolization to control the bleeding from your spleen. You have 
no further evidence of bleeding.

You had an IVC filter placed to prevent blood clots in your 
lungs because of your increased risk for this related to your 
injuries.

The fractures in the bony prominences of your spine do not 
require intervention. You are being given medication to control 
your pain.

Your blood pressure was elevated while you were in the hospital 
so your home dose of lisinopril was increased from 10 to 20 mg 
daily. Please follow up with your primary care provider after 
discharge from rehab to discuss future management of your 
medications and blood pressure.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ generally healthy who presents with two days of epigastric 
pain and vomiting with laboratory and ultrasonographic picture 
concerning for acute pancreatitis. 

Acute Pancreatitis

Initially patient was kept NPO and received IV narcotics. On 
HD#2 she was feeling better and able to transition to PO pain 
medications (which she took very rarely) and a clear diet. She 
was discharged home able to tolerate POs.

There was no clear etiology of her pancreatitis. She denied any 
Etoh use and her RUQ ultrasound was unremarkable. Triglycerides 
and calcium were normal. A follow-up appointment was made with 
the pancreatic clinic at ___ to see if further work-up is 
necesssary and whether there is any role of cholecystectomy 
after this first time unexplained pancreatitis episode.

Possible UTI

She had some WBC in her urine and culture grew group b strep. 
Though she was relatively asx (she reported some blood in 
urine), I chose to treat with ciprofloxacin x 3 days for 
uncomplicated UTI (pen allergic).

Name:  ___                     Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE

Fever, somnolence
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None
 
History of Present Illness:
Mr ___ is a ___ with relapsed AML on palliative decitabine 
and a h/o of afib with a pacemaker who was admitted from clinic 
with fever yesterday; he has been treated for pneumonia and is 
being transferred to the FICU for hypoxia and increased work of 
breathing. 

Currently he has a WBC of 3.2, 77% blasts. Yesterday in clinic 
was d9 of his decitabine, and it was discontinued as he was 
found to be somnolent with T=104.4. On admission he was started 
on vanc/cefepime/azithromycin and since then has continued to 
spike but fever curve is downtrending. In addition on admission 
his Cr was at 1.5 from 1.1 and he got 3L NS. Overnight he was 
satting high 80's on RA, and improved to high 90's on 
supplemental O2 by NC however he was noted to be tachypneic. ABG 
showed resp alkalosis and CXR showed pulmonary edema. He has no 
known history of CHF.  He was also noted to have a possibly new 
murmur on exam. His last ECHO from ___ showed only mild AS. 
 

Prior to transfer vitals were 149/70 96% on 2L NC, RR 30's-40's, 
HR 110's. He was given 20mg IV lasix, and made urine with some 
blood and a clot. EKG showed 1mm STD's in V4-V6 new from prior. 
He was AOx3 this AM, now he's spilling things and not making 
sense, he feels confused, head CT read pending but prelim shows 
no abnormality. LP was not attempted due to concern for CNS 
seeding. He has not had a BM in ___ days.  On the floor he is 
less confused but unable to complete sentences although he is 
satting at 95% NC 2L.

 
Past Medical History:
PAST ONCOLOGIC HISTORY:  
Diagnoses with NPM+ AML following presentation  
for fatigue with elevated WBC. Initial course complicated by  
synocpal event prompting PPM placement.  
- Dectiabine C1, ___  
- Decitabine C2, ___. Complicated by admission  

for consitpation and AF.  
- Decitabine C3, ___  
- Decitabine C4, ___  
- Decitabine C5, ___  
- Decitabine C6, ___ 
- MIDAC 5 day course started ___
 
PAST MEDICAL/SURGICAL HISTORY:

syndrome- on warfarin  
-Prostate cancer ___ 9 on hormonal therapy. on Casodex  
- HTN  
- Gout  
- Chronic kidney disease- baseline cr. 1.1-1.3  
-CAD- cardiac cath with normal LMCA with two-vessel CAD with 75% 
mid LAD and 70% origin of PDA

STUDIES:
CXR ___
Left basal linear opacity reflects area of atelectasis and less 
likely to 
represent an infectious process.  On the other hand, there is 
right upper lobe opacity that appears to be new and may reflect 
infection.  Heart size and mediastinum are stable.  Pacemaker 
leads terminate in the right atrium and right ventricle.  No 
appreciable pleural effusion is seen.  
IMPRESSION: Suspicion for right upper lobe pneumonia. 

CT HEAD ___
No acute intracranial process identified. 

CT CHEST NON CONTRAST ___:
1. Multiple peribronchovascular lung nodules, also with 
confluent appearance in the right lower lobe and surrounding 
ground-glass opacity are suggestive of fungal infection such as 
Aspergillus. However the recent onset of these consolidation is 
not typical of fungal infection, so other etiologies, such as 
vasculitis or bacterial infection cannot be excluded.   
2. Single enlarged mediastinal lymph node alongside descending 
aorta.  
3. In one of the series the trachea, where the patient is likely 
during expiration,  is markedly narrowed. This crescentic 
appearance is suspicious for tracheobronchomalacia.   
4. There are no bone lesions. 

Lower Extremity Ultrasound ___
IMPRESSION:  No deep vein thrombosis in the left upper 
extremity.

Portable CXR ___
As compared to the previous radiograph, the widespread bilateral 

parenchymal opacities, likely reflecting a combination of 
pulmonary edema and infection, are constant in appearance.  They 
have neither increased nor decreased since the previous exam.  
Currently, there are no larger pleural effusions and the size of 
the cardiac silhouette is mildly enlarged.  No pneumothorax.  No 
new parenchymal changes. 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
FICU Course:
___ with h/o AML with normal cytogenetics and NPM+ s/p 6 
cycles of decitabine and a single cycle of mid dose cytarabine, 
recently started on salvage decitabine 1 week ago for 1 
increased peripheral blasts who presents with fever.  

#HYPOXEMIA, FEVERS : Patient came in with sats in the ___.  
After being placed on 2L NC, he was satting in the ___ but still 
unable to speak full sentences and tachypnoeic in the ___.  
Etiology was felt to be most consistent with infection given 
fevers and bandemia on CBC. PE was also on the 
differential(given history of malignancy, tachypnoeia and 
dropping sats, sub-therapeutic INR of 1.6). Patient's Wells 
scoring is 3 and puts him at a moderate risk of having developed 
a PE.  However, given overall low suspicion for PE, elevated Cr, 
and infection as a likely alternative explanation for hypoxemia, 
CTA was not pursued.  Initial CXR concering for RUL pneumonia 
and patient started on treatment for HCAP with vanc, cefepime, 
and azithromycin.  Patient did not improve and was noted to by 
tachypneic, increased oxygen requirement, and very confused.  
Patient bolused 3L fluid on admission, CXR shows some blunting 
of costo-phrenic angles and fluid in the fissures indicative of 
pulmonary edema. Patient given 40mg IV lasix x1.  Patient was 
transferred to the ICU.  Bilateral LENIs were performed showing 
no clot burden in the legs.  Patient has no history of HF and 
recent ECHO in ___ showed mild AS. Repeat ECHO ___ showed LVEF 
70% with mild LVH and stable AS.  CT done in the unit was 
concerning for fungal pneumonia and patient was started on 
ambisome.  In addition, patient developed AF with RVR and 
started on an amiodraone drip.  His rate was well-controlled and 
his breathing improved and he was transferred back to the floor. 
 That evening patient became very delirious, agitated, pulling 
at face mask, and not sleeping at all.  He was given ativan and 
haldol to help control his agitation.  The next morning patient 
went back into a fib with RVR as well as continued agitation.  
He was transferred back to the ICU for rate control as well as 
hypoxia.  His respiratory status did not improve in the ICU and 
at this time his family decided to make him CMO.  He was 
transferred back to the floor and the family wished to 
discontinue the antibiotics.  His pain and agitation were 
controlled with ativan and dilaudid.  He passed away comfortably 
on ___ @ 2:24AM from respiratory failure secondary to 
pneumonia.  

#ALTERED MENTAL STATUS: Patient has had increased confusion over 
the last few days.  Likely etiology from infection in chest.  
Important to exclude any CNS infections given setting of 
immunosuppression and CT head showed no intracranial process. 
Decitabine can also cause confusion but again, given this is 
patient's ___ cycle this is unlikely.  Cefepime can also 
increase patient's confusional state.  Patient was very 
constipated which is a likely etiology. Electrolytes are all 
within normal limits and UA was clean.  Blood cultures and urine 
cultures showed no growth. His mental status continued to wax 
and wane with his fevers.   
 
# Atrial fibrillation and sick sinus syndrome, s/p pacemaker. 
CHADS score is 2.  
Coumadin was held as platelets 22 whilst in the ICU. While 
initially in the FICU, the patient had several episodes of AFib 
with RVR associated with worsening respiratory status likely 
from pulmonary edema.  He remained relatively nonresponsive to 
nodal blockade (metoprolol, diltiazem drip, esmolol drip) and 
required two separate occasions of IV amiodarone load.  After 
converting to sinus rhythm, the patient's amiodarone was 
discontinued and he was transferred to the floor.  There, he 
converted back to AFib with RVR with worsening O2 requirement.  
Patient was given Metoprolol 5mg IV x3 and 25mg PO as well as 
haldol and morphine for agitation.  His tachycardia did not 
respond however he developed hypotension and was not able to 
recieve additional beta-blocker.  Later that afternoon, his 
pressures improved and he was given verapamil for rate control 
without improvement, for which he was transferred to the ICU on 
___ for further management.  The EP team was consulted and 
had initially recommended restart amiodarone.  However, the 
patient spontaneously converted back to sinus rhythm before the 
amiodarone was started.  EP recommended that for further 
episodes of AFib w/ RVR that the patient be started on verapamil 
and calcium gluconate.  He was transferred back to the floor 
where he remained in sinus rhythm.

#THROMBOCYTOPENIA: Most likely etiology reduced platelet 
production from bone marrow suppression from AML disease.  
Patient has had low platelets in the past and been very 
responsive to platelet transfusion (up to 100s), supporting the 
idea of decreased production even more so.  Patient was 
transfused one unit of platelets in the ICU.

#) AML: normal cytogenetics, recent relapse and increase in 
blast count in the periphery with thrombocytopenia, bone marrow 
biopsy results are pending. Now on hydrea 2000mg BID as a 
temporizing measure pending decitabine activity. He previously 
had an episode of nystagmus following cytarabine, raising 
concern for possible cerebellar toxicity, seen by neuro who 
agreed, avoiding further cytarabine doses.  Decitabine was held 
given fevers.  Hydroxyurea 2g BID was continued.  

#) Acute on Chronic kidney disease: baseline Cr is 1.1-1.2, 
admission creatinine is 1.5. Likely ___ fever and poor PO 
intake.  He was managed with IV fluids and medications were 
renally dosed.  His creatinine continued to climb to as high as 
2.9.  His urine was spun and it had casts suggestive of ATN.  He 
renal function did not improve with fluids.  

#) Hypertension  
- continued metoprolol, held lisinopril for above  

#) Gout  
- continued allopurinol renally dosed  

#) Prostate cancer, ___ 9. Consideration being given to XRT 
therapy, though per outpatient notes, likely this will be put on 
hold ___ relapsed leukemia.  
- continued finasteride 5mg daily and goserelin (which is a subQ 
implant)

text:
Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Erythromycin Base / Iodine / Iopamidol / Nitrofurantoin / 
Penicillins / Sulfa (Sulfonamide Antibiotics) / Ciprofloxacin / 
Flagyl
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
R leg pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None
 
History of Present Illness:
Patient is an ___ yo woman with PMHx sig. for giant cell 
arteritis on steroids and PVD with 7 stents in the RLE and 2 
stents in the LLE who presents from ___ with 
RLE ulcerations and worsening pain.  Patient was at rehab for 
recent hip fracture on ___.  She was hospitalized at ___ 
___, seen by Plastic Surgery there.  She was 
transferred to rehab on ___.  There she was noted to have 
multiple skin wounds on her R arm, L wrist, R leg, L thigh, all 
treated with bacitracin, xeroform, wrapped in Kling.  Patient 
has ___ pain wtih dressing changes.  She is followed by wound 
RNs, found to have extensive gangrenous changes of the skin wtih 
ulcerations along almost the entire R leg to mid-thigh, felt to 
require multiple surgical debridements of the necrotic tissue.  
She was given IV ativan 0.25 mg and IV dilaudid 1.75 mg and then 
became lethargic but arousable prior to ED presentation.  She 
has been afebrile.  She had a recent UTI, finished CTX on 
___.  She was sent to ___ for evaluation with Dr. ___.

In the ED, initial VS were: 98.4 70 154/51 18 100% 2L NC.  Labs 
were notable for WBC 11.1 (3% bands), HCT 25.7, K 5.5.  Vascular 
surgery was consulted, found b/l +dopplerable DP pulses, did not 
feel her PVD was the reason for her ulcerations.  She is being 
admitted to medicine for pain control and wound care.  
 
Review of Systems:   Pt denies fever, chills, headache, 
rhinorrhea or congestion, chest pain or tightness, palpitations, 
cough, shortness of breath, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, 
constipation, abdominal pain, dysuria, urinary frequency. All 
other review of systems negative.  
 
Past Medical History:
Giant cell arteritis with PMR - steroid dependent
Secondary adrenal insufficiency from chronic steroids/Addison's 
disease
Peripheral arterial vascular disease
Moderate carotid artery stenosis
Type II DM with peripheral neuropathy and proteinuria, diet 
controlled
COPD
Osteoporosis
HTN
Coronary artery disease, s/p MI in ___
h/o thrombophlebitis
LBP
GERD c/b esopheal stricture
H/o lacunar CVA ___ incidentally seen on CT scan without deficit

PSH: 
Bilateral CIA and REIA stenting ___ revised ___
Pacemaker placement for CHB
Appy
TAH
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Patiet is an orphan.  Daughter had a MI at ___ yo, breast cancer, 
and melenoma.
 
Physical Exam:
Vitals:  97.9, 102/61, 70, 17, 99 on 1L
Gen: NAD, alert, answers appropriately, not oriented to place or 
time  
HEENT: PERRL, MMM, thrush, sclera anicteric, not injected  
Neck: no LAD, no JVD, R side of neck very tender (per daughter, 
this is not new)  
Cardiovascular: RRR normal s1, s2, II/VI systolic murmur at LUSB 
 
Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes, 
rales or rhonchi  
Abd: normoactive bowel sounds, soft, non-tender, non distended 
Extremities:  R ___ with diffuse superficial ulceration and 
extreme tenderness; R hip surgical incision c/d/i   
NEURO: limited due to lack of cooperation, PERRL, face 
symmetric, no tongue deviation  
Integument: diffuse ecchymoses, skin tears, stage I sacral ulcer 
 
Psychiatric: appropriate, pleasant, not anxious
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 05:30PM BLOOD WBC-11.1* RBC-2.75* Hgb-8.9* Hct-25.7* 
MCV-94 MCH-32.4* MCHC-34.7 RDW-15.9* Plt ___
___ 05:32AM BLOOD WBC-18.3* RBC-3.00* Hgb-9.5* Hct-27.2* 
MCV-91 MCH-31.7 MCHC-34.9 RDW-16.1* Plt ___
___ 06:10AM BLOOD WBC-12.1* RBC-3.01* Hgb-9.4* Hct-28.3* 
MCV-94 MCH-31.1 MCHC-33.1 RDW-16.4* Plt ___

Baso-0 ___ Myelos-0
.
___ 07:15AM BLOOD ESR-97*
___ 07:15AM BLOOD CRP-100.3*
___ 05:30PM BLOOD Glucose-107* UreaN-21* Creat-0.6 Na-134 
K-5.5* Cl-95* HCO3-26 AnGap-19
___ 05:12AM BLOOD ALT-10 AST-13 LD(LDH)-259* AlkPhos-118* 
TotBili-0.4
___ 05:08AM BLOOD Albumin-2.9*
___ 06:00PM BLOOD Glucose-107* Lactate-1.2 K-5.3
___ 11:52AM URINE RBC-<1 WBC-2 Bacteri-NONE Yeast-NONE 
Epi-<1 TransE-<1
___ 11:52AM URINE Blood-NEG Nitrite-NEG Protein-TR 
Glucose-NEG Ketone-10 Bilirub-NEG Urobiln-NEG pH-5.0 Leuks-NEG
.
Blood culture (___): No growth to date.
Urine culture (___): No growth.
.
CXR: Right pectoral pacemaker. Moderate cardiomegaly without 
evidence of pulmonary edema. Tracheal deviation due to a thyroid 
nodule. No acute changes in the lung parenchyma. 
.
Right hip x-ray: Status post right hip hemiarthroplasty without 
hardware 
complication. 
.
Right knee x-ray: Bones are osteopenic. No erosive changes are 
identified to suggest osteomyelitis at this time. If there is 
clinical concern, MRI may be helpful for further assessment. No 
localizing information is given on the request to indicate the 
site of the ulcer about the knee. 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo F with giant cell arteritis, PMR on steroids, secondary 
addison's from chronic steroid use, CAD, HTN, DM2 and severe PVD 
with multiple lower extremity stents in the common iliac and 
right iliac arteries admitted with diffuse severe skin 
ulceration of multiple extremities and probable osteomyelitis 
involving the right lower extremity. 

The patient has a long history of skin integrity issues which 
are felt to be multifactorial associated with chronic steroid 
use and chronic PVD. It is unclear if her inflammatory 
conditions contribute to the skin problems. The distribution of 
ulcers is not consistent with simple pressure sores. After 
recent hip fracture requiring surgical repair and rehab stay, 
the patient was noted to have progressive severe, diffuse 
ulcerations involving the right lower extrmeity, left lower 
extremity and right upper extremity. On admission she had 
findings concerning for stage 4 ulceration diffusely in the 
right lower extremity with possible visualized bone or tendon. 
She was seen by vascular surgery consult who felt that with 
dopplerable pulses a primary vascular explanation was unlikely. 
General surgery recommended skin flap to aid in wound healing, 
however, the patient was not interested in surgical management 
as this was not consistent with her goals of care. Therefore, 
the patient was managed conservatively with daily wound care and 
dressing changes, optimization of nutritional status and empiric 
vancomycin for probable osteomyelitis 

The patient had signs of a systemic infectious process with 
rising WBC from admit of 11 to a peak of 18. She had an ESR of 
97 and CRP of 100.3. UA, urine culture and blood cultures are 
negative to date. CXR did not reveal a source of infection. 
There was high concern for either associated cellulitis or 
osteomyelitis given the deep ulcerations, most notable on the 
right lower extremity with possible visualized bone or tendon on 
admission. X-ray of the deepest, right knee ulceration did not 
show signs of osteo. She did not have a surgical scraping or 
sampling on admission and her skin healed enough to cover the 
deeper tissue and therefore no subsequent sample was taken. She 
was empirically started on vancomycin and will complete a 
planned 6 week course via ___ line.

The patient had severe pain with dressing changes. Initially she 
was started on long-acting pain medications with short acting 
breakthrough doses at the time of dressing changes. However, the 
patient had periods of delirium and somnolence. Therefore, she 
was taken off of long-acting pain medications and instead given 
scheduled pre-dressing change doses with good effect.

On CXR the patient was incidentally found to have signs of 
volume overload. She was started on standing daily lasix. It was 
difficult to assess I/O's due to incontinence however clinically 
she showed improvement in volume status and appeared euvolemic 
on discharge.

The patient has a history of anemia, probable anemia of chronic 
disease. Her Hct trended down during her hospitalization and she 
received 1 unit of PRBC's with a good Hct response.

Incidental findings:

Thyroid nodule, seen on chest x-ray with tracheal deviation. If 
no prior work-up and patient interested in diagnosis and 
treatment, could follow-up with thyroid ultrasound.

The remainder of the ___ medical issues including giant 
cell arteritis, PMR, PVD, secondary addison's, CAD, DM2, COPD, 
HTN were stable. The patient was continued on aspirin, coumadin, 
prednisone and the remainder of her home medication regimen.

The patient is DNR/DNI.
Contact:  Daughter/HCP ___ ___, 
___

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
hypothermia
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
History of Present Illness: ___ yo man with h/o alcoholism, 
glaucoma (legally blind) was out drinking last night and found 
down in the snow since 3:30am and found to be hypothermic to 
___ at 7:30am. Apparently he was out walking in the snow 
intoxicated last night trying to find his friend who owed him 
money. He then dropped his cane and his pants started to fall 
down and in the effort to pull up his pants fell in the snow and 
was down for likely approximately 4 hours. He thinks he landed 
on his hip but does not remember which one. He tried to yell for 
help without success. He thinks he lost consciousness for 
periods at a time. He then recalls waking up again and yelling 
for help after which someone shoveling snow luckily found him 
and called EMS. EMS found his temp on the field to be ___. They 
warmed him with blankets and brought him to the ED.  
  
In the ED, initial vs were: 96.8 95 134/84 20 100% NRB. He only 
made 250cc of urine throughout his Tmin was 33.5C. He warmed 
nicely with a warming blanket. His labs were notable for an 
anion gap of 20, bicarb of 12, lactate of 5.5 after 3LNS, Cr of 
1.9, CK of 549. The patient was given 5L of NS, and 1 L of ___ after BS of 50. His last set of vitals prior to transfer 
were 36.3 (___) 102/59 14 98%2LNC.  
 
On the floor, the patient denied any symptoms and wanted to eat 
a meal.  
  
Review of systems:  
(+) Per HPI, does report new mild sore throat and cough with 
sputum.  
(-) Denies fever, chills, night sweats, recent weight loss or 
gain. Denies headache, sinus tenderness, rhinorrhea or 
congestion. Denies cough, shortness of breath, or wheezing. 
Denies chest pain, chest pressure, palpitations, or weakness. 
Denies orthopnea, weight changes. Denies nausea, vomiting, 
diarrhea, constipation, abdominal pain, or changes in bowel 
habits. Denies dysuria, frequency, or urgency. Denies 
arthralgias or myalgias. Denies rashes or skin changes.  

 
Past Medical History:
1) Glaucoma - legally blind  
2) Alcoholism  
3) Lost to medical care for ___ years  

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Brother died of alcoholic cirrhosis. Two sisters died of breast 
cancer at unknown age. 
 
Physical Exam:
On Admission to the MICU:
Vitals: T: 99.6 BP: P: R: 18 O2:  
General: Alert, oriented, thin elderly man in no acute distress  

HEENT: Sclera anicteric, MMM, oropharynx clear, surgical pupils  

Neck: supple, JVP midway up neck at 45 degrees, no LAD  
Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes, rales, 
ronchi, diffusely reduced breath sounds  
CV: Regular rate and rhythm, normal S1 + S2, no murmurs, rubs, 
gallops  
Abdomen: soft, non-tender, non-distended, bowel sounds present, 
no rebound tenderness or guarding, no organomegaly  
GU: foley with clear yellow urine  
Ext: warm, well perfused, 2+ pulses, no clubbing, cyanosis or 
edema  
Neuro: CN ___ intact, ___ UE flexion/extension bilaterally, ___ 
RLE flexion/extension of hips/calves ___ pain per patient all 
___ on LLE. Light touch intact throughout. Patellar reflexes 1+ 
bilaterally. Downgoing toes bilaterally. Pt answering questions 
normally.  

 
Pertinent Results:
Admission Labs:
___ 07:50AM BLOOD WBC-12.4* RBC-4.13* Hgb-14.1 Hct-41.5 
MCV-101* MCH-34.1* MCHC-34.0 RDW-14.6 Plt ___
___ 07:50AM BLOOD Neuts-75* Bands-8* Lymphs-11* Monos-6 
Eos-0 Baso-0 ___ Myelos-0
___ 07:50AM BLOOD ___ PTT-30.7 ___
___ 07:50AM BLOOD Glucose-79 UreaN-20 Creat-1.9* Na-137 
K-3.9 Cl-102 HCO3-12* AnGap-27*
___ 07:50AM BLOOD ALT-47* AST-85* CK(CPK)-549* AlkPhos-95 
TotBili-0.5
___ 07:50AM BLOOD Calcium-10.2 Phos-7.6* Mg-2.5
___ 02:14PM BLOOD calTIBC-300 VitB12-205* Folate-8.5 
___ Ferritn-213 TRF-231

Tox:
___ 07:50AM BLOOD Acetone-NEGATIVE
___ 09:30AM BLOOD Osmolal-314*
___ 07:50AM BLOOD ASA-4.1 ___ Bnzodzp-NEG 
Barbitr-NEG Tricycl-NEG

ABG:
___ 02:39PM BLOOD ___ pO2-64* pCO2-28* pH-7.33* 
calTCO2-15* Base XS--9 Comment-ROOM AIR

Lactate:
___ 09:36AM BLOOD Lactate-5.5*
___ 02:39PM BLOOD Lactate-1.4

Surveillance labs:
___ 06:00AM BLOOD WBC-4.8 RBC-3.44* Hgb-11.2* Hct-32.7* 
MCV-95 MCH-32.6* MCHC-34.3 RDW-15.1 Plt Ct-83*
___ 06:00AM BLOOD Glucose-95 UreaN-9 Creat-0.7 Na-139 
K-3.0* Cl-110* HCO3-22 AnGap-10
___:00AM BLOOD ALT-32 AST-58*
___ 06:00AM BLOOD Calcium-8.6 Phos-2.6* Mg-1.6

Studies:
ECG Study Date of ___  8:01:06 AM 
Sinus rhythm with borderline sinus tachycardia. Prominent T 
waves are 
non-specific and may be within normal limits but clinical 
correlation is 
suggested. No previous tracing available for comparison.  
TRACING #1 
 
BILAT HIPS (AP,LAT & AP PELVIS) Study Date of ___ 8:46 AM 
IMPRESSION: No evidence of fracture or dislocation. Radiopaque 
amorphous 
bodies measuring up to 1.1 cm overlie the lateral aspect of the 
femoral neck and proximal shaft. 
  
Radiopaque amorphous bodies measuring up to 1.1 cm overlie the 
soft tissue 
lateral to the left femoral neck and proximal femoral shaft, 
difficult to 
discern whether external to the patient or foreign bodies. 
Clinical 
correlation advised. 

CHEST (PORTABLE AP) Study Date of ___ 4:06 ___ 
IMPRESSION: Opacities at the left and right base. These could be 
further 
characterized by a PA and lateral radiograph as they could 
represent early 
pneumonia or aspiration. 

Micro biology:
___ 2:02 am URINE      Source: ___. 

URINE CULTURE (Preliminary): 
PROTEUS MIRABILIS.    10,000-100,000 ORGANISMS/ML.. 
PRESUMPTIVE IDENTIFICATION. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
# Hypothermia: The most likely etiology is exposure to the 
elements in a blizzard for four hours. Patient remained 
euthermic after rewarming and has no signs or sx of frostbite 
damage to his extremities. His glucose and electrolytes have 
remained stable. His EKG and telemetry reveal no arrythmias. No 
e/o coaggulopathy with normal INR and normal fibrinogen.
 
# Anion gap metabolic acidosis: Patient initially presented with 
an anion gap acidosis without a concominant nongap acidosis most 
likely from a combination of lactic acidosis and alcoholic 
ketoacidosis that has come down after feeding and rehydration. 
His lactate was likely elevated secondary to hypothermia and 
peripheral vasoconstriction and has now resolved to 1.4 after 
rewarming and rehydration. He has subsequently developed a 
concominant hyperchloremic nongap acidosis after 5L of NS. His 
VBG confirmed this metabolic acidosis of 7.33 (which is 
reassuring level) with appropriate respiratory compensation. 
 
# Oliguric acute kidney injury: Most likely secondary to 
rhabdomyelysis and possibly dehydration. Improved markedly after 
fluid rescucitation. Currently making adequate urine. 

# Rhabdomyelysis: Likely from being down overnight and possibly 
from shivering/hypothermia. His CK trended downward and his 
creatinine improved to 0.7. His UA showed blood without RBCs, 
making myoglobinuria likely.
 
# Megaloblastic anemia: Most likely secondary to chronic 
alcoholism. His MCV improved with nutritional supplementation. 
His B12 was low, so we started B12 supplementation.
 
# Fall: Most likely a combinaion of deconditioning, blindness 
leading to poor co-ordination, alcoholic neuropathy and 
low-level neurological irritability from etoh withdrawl. 
Physical therapy evaluated him and recommended a SNF for rehab.

# Thrombocytopenia: Likely from myelosuppression from alcohol 
abuse. Other possibilities include chronic liver dysfunction 
such as cirrhosis. He has a palpable liver tip, but does not 
have splenomegaly. Would benefit from abstinence of alcohol.
 
# Alcoholism: Patient arrived intoxicated with elevated alcohol 
levels and alcohol on his breath. He was monitored with a CIWA 
scale, but did not score, and he was started on supplementation 
with thiamine, folate, multivitamin, and vitamin B12.

# Transfer of care: He was transferred to rehab for strength and 
stability training. He will need PCP ___ upon discharge 
from his rehab facility.
 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Medications:
1. folic acid 1 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  

2. thiamine HCl 100 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
3. multivitamin     Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 
 
4. cyanocobalamin (vitamin B-12) 100 mcg Tablet Sig: 0.5 Tablet 
PO DAILY (Daily).  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary:
Hypothermia
Lactic acidosis
Alcohol ketoacidosis
Myoglobinuria
Acute renal failure
Megaloblastic anemia
Thrombocytopenia
Alcohol abuse
Secondary:
Glaucoma, legally blind

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
Mr. ___, 

It was a pleasure taking part in your care. You were admitted 
after being found in the snow and your temperature was low. You 
were taken warmed up and monitored in the ICU overnight. 

During your stay, you had multiple lab abnormalities that were 
likely because of your alcohol intake as well as falling and 
being out in the cold for multiple hours.

You were given IV fluids to help your kidney function, and 
antibiotics for a urinary tract infection. We started you on a 
lot of nutrition supplements (vitamins) to help supplement your 
diet. 

Physical therapy worked with you, and because you were unsteady 
they recommended a short stay at a rehab facility to help get 
you strong enough to go home.

We made the following changes to your medications:
-START thiamine 100mg daily
-START folic acid 1mg daily
-START multivitamin 1 tab daily
-START Vitamin B12 50mcg daily
-START Ciprofloxacin 500mg twice a day for 7 days (until 
___

Please choose a primary care physician to follow you as an 
outpatient
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Augmentin / Vancomycin
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Palpitations
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Pacemaker placement
 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year-old woman with his known AF, SSS, 
Turner's syndrome with aortic coarctation s/p repair at age ___, 
hypothyroidism, mediastinal Schwannoma, and chronic pericardial 
effusion who presents with palpitations and subsequent 
bradycardia. She noted that she has always had a low heart rate 
at baseline, but starting having episodes of sudden 
lightheadedness dating ___. This was diagnosed in ___ to be AF 
with RVR. She has previously been treatd with CCB and BB, but 
was unablt to tolerate due to resultant bradycardia and 
hypotension (though it appears that when she spontaneously 
breaks from AF with RVR, she typically has sinus bradycardia). 

Today, she noted the onset of palpitations and a vague feeling 
of
being unwell. She did not have lightheadedness or dizziness and 
was not diaphoretic. She went to work and saw her 
enodcrinologist, where she was notedc to have an irregular HR. 
She was seen in the office by Dr. ___ found her to be 
in AF with a rapid rate to the 180s. He gave her 25mg of 
metoprolol tartrate in the office and brought her to the ED. 

In the ED, initial vitals were: 96.8 180 118/89 16 99% RA. Her 
ECG was notable for AF with RVR. Her labs were all WNL except 
for PLT 112. She was given another dose of metoprolol tartrate 
50mg. One hour after this dose, she still had not converted. She 
was seen by the cardiology attending, and flecainide 50mg was 
given. After this was given, she was noted to have a 9-second 
conversion pause. She developed hypotension at 61/27 and 
bradycardia to 41. She was symptomatic with lightheadedness and 
dizziness. She was placed in ___ and given 1L IVF and 
1g calcium gluconate with resolution of her hypotension. She 
noted that her palpitations had resolved, however, she still 
remained bradycardic and had soft SBPs. She was started on 
dopamine at 2.5 mcg/kg/min and her HR improved to 47 and BP to 
95/48. She was admitted to the CCU for further management.

On arrival to the ___ (being followed by the CCU team), she 
was in no acute distress. All of her symptoms had resolved. She 
was weaned off the dopamine and was maintaining SBPs in the 
90-100s and HR in the mid-high ___.
 
Past Medical History:
-atrial fibrillation
-SSS
-Turner syndrome
-status post coarctation of the aorta repair
-repair of her webbed neck 
-posterior mediastinal mass (Schwannoma) 
-allergic rhinitis
-hypothyroidism
-osteoarthritis and osteoporosis
-alopecia
-lichen sclerosus
-vitamin D deficiency
-hyperparathyroidism
-cholelithiasis
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Father who died from MDS that converted to leukemia.  He also 
had blood clots and heart disease.
 
Physical Exam:
ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAM
=======================
VS: T 98.3, BP 103/61, HR 52, RR 14, O2 sat 98%
Gen: In no acute distress, stature is short.
HEENT: Sclera anicteric, MMM, oropharynx clear, EOMI, PERRL
Neck: Supple, JVP not elevated, no LAD
CV: Regular rate and rhythm, normal S1 + S2, no murmurs, rubs, 
gallops

Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___

Chief Complaint:
pericardial effusion with cardiac tamponade
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
pericardiocentesis and drain placement
 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ F with a distant PMH of breast cancer who 
was transferred to ___ ___ from ___ 
where she had presented from her rehab with progressive dyspnea 
x 2 weeks. At ___, she was seen by pulmonary for a large left 
sided pleural effusion found on chest radiograph.  CT scan of 
the chest showed large left pleural effusion and a moderate to 
large right pleural effusion w/o lymphadenopathy. There were 
diffuse interstital abnormalities of the left lung concerning 
for lymphangitic spread of tumor. She underwent a thoracentesis 
which showed a pH 7.4, LDH 248, c/w exudative effusion, with 
gram stain negative and NGTD on culture and pending cytology. 
She was treated with a 5 day course of ceftriaxone. A TTE showed 
a moderate sized paricardial effusion with no signs of 
tamponade. The patient was transferred here at the family's 
request.  
.
Upon arrival to ___, she underwent repeat transthoracic echo 
on ___ which revealed preserved EF of 55% but also showed a 
pericardial effusion with sustained RA collapse and right 
ventricular diastolic collapse, consistent with cardiac 
tamponade. She was taken to the cath lab for pericardiocentesis.
.
Prior to her admission, she denied fevers, chills, or any viral 
syndrome, but endorsed nausea and constipation for several 
months. However, she did move her bowels this AM prior to going 
for echo. She denies chest pain. She reports decreased energy 
since her pelvic fracture in ___, for which she was at 
rehab prior to ___ presentation. She reports increased thirst 
and some increased "thickness" of her legs since her pelvic 
fracture. At rehab, she was most recently walking with the 
assistance of a walker. Othewise, otherwise all other ROS were 
negative in detail.  
 
Past Medical History:
# Breast Cancer:  
# s/p lumpectomy of left breast, XRT and tamoxifen

Cardiology
=============

TTE ___
Overall left ventricular systolic function is normal (LVEF>55%). 
There is a moderate sized pericardial effusion. There is 
sustained right atrial collapse, consistent with low filling 
pressures or early tamponade. There is right ventricular 
diastolic collapse, consistent with impaired fillling/tamponade 
physiology.   
.
TTE ___ 
Left ventricular wall thickness, cavity size, and global 
systolic function are normal (LVEF>55%). Significant aortic 
regurgitation is present, but cannot be quantified. Mitral 
regurgitation is present but cannot be quantified. There is a 
trivial/physiologic pericardial effusion. There are no 
echocardiographic signs of tamponade. 
Compared with the prior study (images reviewed from post tap) of 
___, no change.   
.
Cardiac Cath ___
1. Emergent pericardiocentesis for pericardial tamponade with 
removal of 
380 cc of bloody fluids. 
2. Persistent elevation of pericardial pressure indicative of 
constrictive effusive etiology. 
3. Pericardial drain left in place. 
4. Repeat 2D echocardiogram in AM. 

.
============
Radiology
============
Chest X ray ___
 
Bilateral pleural effusions have not significantly changed in 
the interim and the slightly better aeration of the right lung 
base may be due to 
redistribution of the fluid. The pericardial drainage has been 
removed. There is no pneumothorax. There is no evidence of 
pneumomediastinum. 
.
Chest X ray ___
Bilateral pleural effusions, larger on the left. No 
pneumothorax. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo woman with a history of breast cancer who is transferred 
to the CCU after TTE revealed pericardial effusion cuasing 
tamponade physiology, s/p pericardiocentesis and drain 
placement.
.
# Pericardial effusion with tamponade - Had pericardiocentesis 
and drain placement ___ with subsequent removal the following 
day. Given persistently elevated pericardial pressures after 
drainage, this is likely constrictive disease. Etiology thought 
to be likely malignant given history of BrCA and coincident 
pleural effusions with CT chest showing suspicion of 
lymphangitic spread of CA, but cytology was negative. However, 
sensitivity for cytology is only between 67 and 92 percent. 
Cultures from pericardial fluid no growth to date at time of 
discharge. Repeat TTE showed no signs of tamponade. Patient was 
started on indocin for pain. She was monitored for 24 hours in 
the CCU before transfer to the floor. Plan for patient to have 
cardiology follow up with repeat TTE next week. 
.
#. Pleural effusions - these were most suspicious for malignancy 
given that OSH CT scan also with interstial process of the left 
lung. Has large right pleural effusion that has not been tapped. 
There was no evidence of empyema or parapneumonic effusion. Pt 
now s/p 5 day course of ceftriaxone at OSH. No current evidence 
of pneumonia. CXR over 2 days showed stability. Cytology will 
need to be followed up from ___ (___).  Patient 
was maintained on oxygen while in house to keep peripheral 
saturations greater than 90. 
.  
#. Afib: Recently diagnosed. On diltiazem and digoxin for rate 
control. Not currently anticoagulated given fall risk and 
possible procedures. Dig level ok at 1.8. Continued on diltiazem 
and digoxin for rate control, but digoxin changed to 0.125 mg 
daily. Discharged without anticoagulation pending followup with 
cardiology next week. Please hold all anticoagulation until 
after patient is seen in follow-up.   
.  
#. Failed voiding trial: Foley removed 1 day prior to discharge 
but did not void. Foley was replaced on the day of dicharge with 
appropriate urine output. 
.
# CODE STATUS:
-- After discussion with patient and family, she is DNR/DNI 
.
# EMERGENCY CONTACT:  
-- HCP ___ ___  
.

Discharge Diagnosis:
1. Lumbar spinal stenosis, L2 to L5.
2. Degenerative disk disease, L2 to L5.
3. Right lower extremity radiculopathy with foot drop.
4. L3-4 large right-sided disk herniation.
5. Low back pain.

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Lumbar Decompression Without Fusion

You have undergone the following operation: Lumbar Decompression 
Without Fusion

Immediately after the operation:

                Activity:You should not lift anything greater 
than 10 lbs for 2 weeks.You will be more comfortable if you do 
not sit or stand more than~45 minutes without moving around.

                Rehabilitation/ Physical ___ times a 
day you should go for a walk for ___ minutes as part of your 
recovery.You can walk as much as you can tolerate.Limit any kind 
of lifting.

                Diet:Eat a normal healthy diet.You may have 
some constipation after surgery.You have been given medication 
to help with this issue.

                Brace:You may have been given a brace.If you 
have been given a brace, this brace is to be worn when you are 
walking.You may take it off when sitting in a chair or lying in 
bed.

                Wound Care: Remove the dressing in 2 days.If 
the incision is draining cover it with a new sterile dressing.If 
it is dry then you can leave the incision open to the air.Once 
the incision is completely dry (usually ___ days after the 
operation) you may take a shower.Do not soak the incision in a 
bath or pool.If the incision starts draining at anytime after 
surgery,do not get the incision wet.Cover it with a sterile 
dressing and call the office.

                You should resume taking your normal home 
medications.

                You have also been given Additional Medications 
to control your pain.Please allow 72 hours for refill of 
narcotic prescriptions,so please plan ahead.You can either have 
them mailed to your home or pick them up at the clinic located 
on ___ 2.We are not allowed to call in or fax narcotic 
prescriptions(oxycontin,oxycodone,percocet) to your pharmacy.In 
addition,we are only allowed to write for pain medications for 
90 days from the date of surgery.

                Follow up:            

               Please Call the office and make an appointment 
for 2 weeks after the day of your operation if this has not been 
done already.

                At the 2-week visit we will check your incision, 
take baseline X-rays and answer any questions.We may at that 
time start physical therapy.

                We will then see you at 6 weeks from the day of 
the operation and at that time release you to full activity.

Please call the office if you have a fever>101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit and/or drainage from your wound.

Brief Hospital Course:
BRIEF SUMMARY
=============
Mr. ___ is a ___ year old man with no significant past medical 
history who presented to the ED with worsening respiratory 
symptoms ___ the setting of treatment with amoxicillin. He was 
found to be hypoxemic, febrile, and tachypnic, with a CXR 
revealing a right lower lobe pneumonia. He was initially treated 
with ceftriaxone and azithromycin, but this was transitioned to 
levofloxacin and the patient improved. He did experience a few 
loose bowel movements and was tested for C. diff, however this 
returned as negative. He was discharged to complete a 7 day 
course of levofloxacin and follow up with his primary care 
physician.

ACUTE ISSUES
# COMMUNITY ACQUIRED PNEUMONIA: Patient presented with worsening 
dyspnea, cough, fever, malaise after 72 hour treatment for CAP 
as outpatient, also found to have new oxygen requirement. On 
exam, the patient was noted to be tachypnic. No significant 
co-morbidities. Was placed on ceftriaxone and azithromycin by 
nightfloat physician but this was switched to PO levaquin the 
following morning. Sputum gram stain showed GPCs ___ chains but 
culture grew commensal respiratory flora. His cough was treated 
with guaifenesin w/ codeine syrup, tessalon perles, and 
albuterol/ipratropium nebs. He improved significantly and was 
able to be weaned from oxygen. He was discharged to complete a 7 
day course of levofloxacin 750 mg daily

 # Diarrhea: The patient reported several loose, watery bowel 
movements during his course, likely from his antibiotic regimen. 
A C. diff assay was performed which was negative. He was given 
IVF for hydration.

 CHRONIC ISSUES  
 # OSTEOARTHRITIS  
 -- continued naproxen BID as needed for OA 
 
 # HEALTH MAINTENANCE  
 -- likely should be on daily aspirin given age 
 

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
===================
-The patient will need to complete a 7 day course of 
levofloxacin
-Consider daily aspirin 81 mg given patient's age
